A 5-year-old girl with end-stage kidney failure from renal dysplasia received a living donor kidney
transplant from her mother. Her allograft reveals immediate graft function. Her posttransplant
immunosuppression includes 5 doses of injectable rabbit anti-thymocyte globulin, 1 mg/kg per dose,
and a rapid taper of intravenous steroids. For oral maintenance immunosuppression, she is initially
prescribed tacrolimus and mycophenolate mofetil twice daily liquid under an oral steroid-avoidance
protocol. She is able to maintain appropriate 12-hour trough tacrolimus levels. Her serum creatinine
level is steady at 0.3 mg/dL (27 μmol/L), and her only test result abnormality is a persistent
leukopenia, with white blood cell counts in the 2,500 to 3,000/μL (2.5-3.0 × 109/L) range.
At 3 months, the tacrolimus is switched to sirolimus once daily. During the next few weeks, you notice
that her trough sirolimus levels are consistently undetectable. Her other blood test results remain the
same, and she is still asymptomatic.
Of the following, the MOST likely reason for the undetectable sirolimus levels is
options: drug interaction between mycophenolate and sirolimus medications
faster metabolism of sirolimus in children than in adults
leukopenia that prevents detection of intracellular sirolimus levels
new-onset nonadherence in the child to taking sirolimus
explanation:
B. faster metabolism of sirolimus in children than in adults
In the patient described in the vignette, the most likely reason for undetectable sirolimus levels in this
very young child is faster metabolism of the drug. The drug levels are measured in serum, not the
intracellular white blood cell compartment, as is done with cysteine levels. At her age, her parents will
be administering the drug, and new-onset nonadherence is unlikely. In young children, compounding
errors, dosing errors, and stability with liquid preparations also need to be considered. Sirolimus and
mycophenolate do not significantly affect each other’s metabolism. Racial differences may also have
a bearing on drug metabolism.
The immunosuppression medications that are used for children after organ transplantation are the
same that are used in adults. Thus, the induction medications, rabbit anti-thymocyte globulin,
basiliximab, and alemtuzumab, are the same in both age groups. Similarly, oral maintenance
medications in both groups currently include the calcineurin inhibitors (CNIs; cyclosporine,
tacrolimus), DNA synthesis inhibitors (azathioprine, mycophenolate mofetil, mycophenolate sodium),
steroids, and mammalian target of rapamycin inhibitors (mTORis; sirolimus, everolimus). The
immunosuppression protocols also generally follow a similar pattern in adults or children. Most but not
all programs currently administer 1 induction agent followed by 2 or 3 oral maintenance agents, 1
from each group. The mTORis, if used, are generally administered 3 months after transplant to avoid
wound healing problems and are generally used in a CNI-sparing regimen, although they may be
used in combination with any of the other agents.
All the oral maintenance agents were initially tested in adult kidney transplant recipients. Dose
recommendations in the US Food and Drug Administration approval inserts were therefore based
entirely on adult patients. Therapeutic drug monitoring and concentration-controlled dosing (ie, based
on drug levels vs fixed dosing) are recommended for the CNIs and mTORis but not for DNA synthesis
inhibitors or steroids, given the high variability in area under the curve (AUC) exposure at similar
dosage for CNI and mTORi drugs. Dosing in children then had to be extrapolated down based on
assumptions and case report experience. Dosing recommendations on a per kilogram or per square
meter basis that are currently practiced for children are given in the Table.
Table. Starting Dosages of Maintenance Immunosuppressive Agents
Drug Starting Dose
Tacrolimus 0.05-0.1 mg/kg per dose twice daily
Cyclosporine 3-4 mg/kg per dose twice daily
Mycophenolate 450-600 mg/m2 per dose, twice
daily
Azathioprine 1-3 mg/kg per dose once daily
Prednisone 0.5-2 mg/kg per dose once daily
Sirolimus 1 mg/m2 once daily
Notably, one of the main differences between children and adults is the faster drug metabolism in the
former, especially in very young children. Such differences were first shown for cyclosporine. Hence,
many young children required not twice-daily but 3-times-daily dosing for cyclosporine. Similar faster
metabolism has been reported by Schachter et al for sirolimus, necessitating twice-daily rather than
once-daily dosing of this drug in very young children.
For the mycophenolate preparations, fixed dosing is currently practiced because most data suggest
poor correlation between trough levels of drug or its metabolite with AUC exposure. Cyclosporine and
tacrolimus affect mycophenolate differently. A dose-dependent cyclosporine-induced inhibition of
mycophenolic acid glucuronidation occurs, which is not seen with tacrolimus. Therefore, a lower
mycophenolate exposure occurs with concomitant cyclosporine, and relatively higher mycophenolate
exposure occurs with concomitant tacrolimus. Thus, the currently recommended mycophenolate

mofetil dose in pediatric patients with concomitant cyclosporine is higher at 600 mg/m2 per dose twice
daily; the recommended mycophenolate mofetil dose with concomitant tacrolimus or without a
concurrent calcineurin inhibitor is lower at 450 mg/m2 per dose twice daily. However, some data
suggest that concentration controlled dosing of mycophenolate may be more appropriate for children
with these drugs. Paradoxically, trials of steroid avoidance in children found excessive leukopenia
with mycophenolate, necessitating lowering of mycophenolate mofetil dosing to 300 mg/m2 per dose.
Both steroids and cyclosporine are metabolized by the CYP3A4 isoenzyme of the cytochrome P450
catalytic system. Theoretically, high steroid concentrations during a rejection episode could
competitively inhibit cyclosporine metabolism, increasing its systemic concentration and decreasing
its dose requirements.
PREP Pearls
 Faster immunosuppressive drug metabolism occurs in children.
American Board of Pediatrics Content Specification(s)
 Understand the principles governing immunosuppressive drug dosages for children receiving renal transplants
Suggested Readings
 Cooney GF, Habucky K, Hoppu K. Cyclosporin pharmacokinetics in paediatric transplant recipients. Clin
Pharmacokinet. 1997;32(6):481-495. doi: http://dx.doi.org/10.2165/00003088-199732060-00004
 Schachter AD, Meyers KE, Spaneas LD, et al. Short sirolimus half-life in pediatric renal transplant recipients on
a calcineurin inhibitor-free protocol. Pediatr Transplant. 2004;8(2):171-177.
doi: http://dx.doi.org/10.1046/j.1399-3046.2003.00148.x
 Tönshoff B, David-Neto E, Ettenger R, et al. Pediatric aspects of therapeutic drug monitoring of mycophenolic
acid in renal transplantation. Transplant Rev (Orlando). 2011;25(2):78-89.
doi: http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.trre.2011.01.001

A 15-year-old girl is brought in for evaluation of elevated blood pressure. She has been experiencing
frequent headaches, weight loss, flushing, palpitations, and sweating for the past few years. Her
mother, father, and maternal grandmother have hypertension. Her physical examination findings are
notable for a height of 155 cm, weight of 50 kg, body mass index of 20.8, blood pressure of 160/100
mm Hg, and heart rate of 110 beats/min. Her skin was warm and moist with I/VI systolic ejection
murmur. Otherwise, her examination findings were normal.
The results of a 24-hour urine test are shown below.
Epinephrine (reference range, 1-10 μg/24 h) 69 μg/24 h
Norepinephrine (reference range, 10- 1,242 μg/24 h
100 μg/24 h)
Vanillylmandelic acid Elevated
Abdominal magnetic resonance imaging reveals a 6-cm suprarenal mass.
Of the following, the MOST appropriate initial treatment for the hypertension is
options: clonidine
isradipine
labetalol
phenoxybenzamine
explanation:
D. phenoxybenzamine
The patient described in the vignette presents with typical findings for pheochromocytoma (PCC).
PCCs are catecholamine-secreting tumors that are a rare cause of secondary hypertension (present
in 0.2%-0.6% of patients with hypertension). Norepinephrine and epinephrine lead to hypertension by
stimulation of α- and β-adrenergic receptors (Figure 1).
Figure 1. Simplified diagram of ɑ- and β-adrenergic receptors.
Initial treatment of PCC-induced hypertension focuses on α-adrenergic blockade. There are protocols
for both α -selective adrenergic blockers (prazosin, terazosin, doxazosin) and α - and α -blockers
1 1 2
(phenoxybenzamine, phentolamine). Most recent guidelines recommend nonselective α-blockade
(with phenoxybenzamine or phentolamine) slightly over α -selective blockers (eg, prazosin) as initial
1
therapy. Thus, the most appropriate initial treatment for the hypertension of the patient described in
the vignette is phenoxybenzamine. Nonselective α-blockers are associated with less risk of
hypertensive crisis but more risk of postoperative hypotension (phenoxybenzamine has a half-life of
24 hours). The downsides of α -selective blockers is that they often are insufficient on their own to
1
control blood pressure and give higher risk for hypertensive crises. However, they pose less risk of
postoperative hypotension. Thus, if using α -selective blockade as initial therapy, it is often
1
recommended to use it in combination with a calcium channel blocker (amlodipine or nifedipine or
nicardipine). Unfortunately, there are limited studies comparing multidrug regimens. Although calcium
channel blockers may be used in addition to α-blockade, isradipine is not the preferred initial therapy,
making isradipine the incorrect choice for the patient in the vignette. Clonidine is an α -agonist and
2
would not be a first-line therapy for PCCs.
A common adverse effect of β-blockade with nonselective agents is reflex tachycardia. In general, this
is treated with β-blockade. However, if β-blockade is introduced before α-blockade, it can lead to
unopposed α-stimulation and vasoconstriction without opposition by the vasodilating β -receptors,
2
leading to hypertensive crisis and pulmonary edema. The pulmonary edema can be further worsened
by the negative inotropic effect of the β-blockade.
Although labetalol targets α -, β -, and β -receptors, its use has been associated with hypertensive
1 1 2
crisis, and it is therefore not recommended as initial therapy. Thus, labetalol should not be used for
the patient in the vignette.
Usually, β-blockade is begun 10 to 14 days before surgery, with a goal of controlling blood pressures
to less than 130/80 mm Hg and no blood pressure higher than 160/90 mm Hg for 24 hours before

surgery (in adults). Heart rate should be less than 80 beats/min (in adults). β-Blockade–induced
orthostatic hypotension is expected and treated with hydration and high salt intake. β-Blockers are
used when needed for tachycardia. In addition to preoperative α-blockade, patients should undergo
electrocardiography and echocardiography to assess for risk of arrhythmias and dilated
cardiomyopathy. An additional preoperative criterion is that the electrocardiogram free of ST-T
changes for at least 1 week, with no more than 1 premature ventricular contraction every 5 minutes.
Among 30 pediatric patients treated at the Mayo Clinic during a 30-year period, hypertension,
palpitations, and headache were the most common presenting symptoms associated with PCC.
Hypertension can be paroxysmal or sustained. Other common presenting symptoms include anxiety,
tremor, syncope, weight changes, and tachycardia. Some patients are diagnosed with PCC despite
being asymptomatic; for example, there are guidelines for screening asymptomatic patients with
genetic syndromes where the risk for PCC is high (as high as 30% in patients with von Hippel-Lindau
syndrome).
PCCs are neuroendocrine tumors that originate from the neural crest–derived chromaffin cells of the
adrenal medulla. Paragangliomas are similar tumors that originate from neural crest–derived ganglia
outside the adrenal gland (and may be derived from either parasympathetic or sympathetic ganglia).
Historically, PCCs were reported to follow the rule of 10s (10% familial, 10% bilateral, and 10%
malignant), but recent studies have found that tumor location and malignancy risk vary with
underlying genetic mutations. Approximately one-third of PCCs and paraganglioma tumors are now
known to have germline mutations (sporadic or familial) in more than 25 susceptibility genes. An
additional third of tumors have somatic mutations in these genes. Thus, approximately 60% of tumors
have identifiable gene mutations. The susceptibility genes include 3 genes associated with
syndromes that can have PCCs as a manifestation: NF1 (neurofibromatosis type 1), VHL (von Hippel-
Lindau disease), and RET (multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2). Many of the susceptibility genes
encode members of the succinate dehydrogenase complex or Krebs cycle. Mutations in these
and VHL and HIF2A (hypoxia inducible factor 2α) are thought to affect hypoxia and vascular
endothelial growth factor signaling pathways. Another set of mutations, including those
of TMEM127 and MAX, are thought to affect mammalian target of rapamycin signaling.
Catecholamines and metanephrines, as well as vanillylmandelic acid (VMA) and homovanillic acid
(HVA), are all derived from dopamine (Figure 2).
Figure 2. Simplified diagram of catecholamine production and metabolism.

Tyrosine is converted to dopamine by tyrosine hydroxylase in multiple organs, including central
nervous system, sympathetic nerves, adrenal and extra-adrenal chromaffin cells, gastrointestinal
tract, and kidney. Chromaffin cells of the adrenal medulla convert norepinephrine to epinephrine. The
catecholamines are metabolized to metanephrines and then to VMA and HVA. In part because of the
challenges of 24-hour urine collection, many advocate for screening for PCC in children using plasma
metanephrines. Serum levels are very low (relative to urine), and so initially some laboratories had
difficulty with making the assay reliable, but it has been increasingly commercially available. Plasma
normetanephrine and metanephrine are more often elevated in PCC than plasma catecholamines
and have a sensitivity of 97% and a specificity of 96%. The diagnosis is often confirmed using other
studies. In the case series of the Mayo Clinic, 93% had a diagnosis of a catecholamine-secreting
tumor confirmed using urinary 24-hour excretion for fractionated catecholamines (dopamine,
norepinephrine, and epinephrine), metanephrine, normetanephrine, VMA, and HVA. These urinary
studies have varying rates of specificity and sensitivity. Urinary fractionated metanephrines have a
high sensitivity (97%) and are useful for ruling out the diagnosis but have a low specificity. Urinary
catecholamines have a high specificity (99%) and are useful for confirming a diagnosis. Urinary VMA
also have a high specificity (95%) but low sensitivity. Imaging studies (computed tomography or
magnetic resonance imaging) or iodine-123-meta-iodobenzylguanidine or fluorodopa positron
emission tomography may be used to localize the tumor.
Surgical resection is the preferred treatment of nonmetastatic PCCs. Because of catecholamine
secretion, tumor resection can be complicated by life-threatening hypertension (with catecholamine
release during tumor manipulation) and hypotension (due to residual effects of antihypertensives after
tumor removal). Thus, careful perioperative planning and close blood pressure, heart rate, and
glucose monitoring by the anesthesiology team is needed. Because of the rarity of PCCs, there are
few randomized clinical trials, and controversy continues to surround many perioperative
recommendations. However, mortality rates were as high as 45% before α-adrenergic blockade was
introduced as standard of care and are now closer to 3%. Patients with PCCs tend to be
hypovolemic, and volume expansion preoperatively is also recommended by many.
PREP Pearls
 Up to 60% of pheochromocytomas are associated with somatic or germline genetic mutations.
 β-Blockade before ɑ-blockade in treatment of pheochromocytoma-induced hypertension can precipitate a
hypertensive crisis.
 Preoperative ɑ-blockade and close perioperative monitoring are critical to avoid mortality during surgical
resection of pheochromocytomas.
American Board of Pediatrics Content Specification(s)
 Know how to treat hypertension secondary to a pheochromocytoma and the strategies to optimize operative
management
Suggested Readings
 Fishbein L, Orlowski R, Cohen D. Pheochromocytoma/paraganglioma: review of perioperative management of
blood pressure and update on genetic mutations associated with pheochromocytoma. J Clin Hypertens.
2013;15(6):428-434. doi: http://dx.doi.org/10.1111/jch.12084
 Fishbein L. Pheochromocytoma and paraganglioma: genetics, diagnosis, and treatment. Hematol Oncol Clin
North Am. 2016;30(1):135-150. doi: http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.hoc.2015.09.006

 Kinney M, Narr BJ, Warner MA. Perioperative management of pheochromocytoma. J Cardiothorac Vasc
Anesth. 2002;16(3):359-369. doi: http://dx.doi.org/10.1053/jcan.2002.124150
 Pacak K, Eisenhofer G, Ahlman H, et al. Pheochromocytoma: recommendations for clinical practice from the
First International Symposium. Nat Clin Pract Endocrinol Metab. 2007;3(2):92-102.
doi: http://dx.doi.org/10.1038/ncpendmet0396
 Pham TH, Moir C, Thompson GB, et al. Pheochromocytoma and paraganglioma in children: a review of
medical and surgical management at a tertiary care center. Pediatrics. 2006;118(3):1109-1117
DOI: http://dx.doi.org/10.1542/peds.2005-2299
 Pillai S, Gopalan V, Smith RA, Lam AK. Updates on the genetics and the clinical impacts on
phaeochromocytoma and paraganglioma in the new era. Crit Rev Oncol Hematol. 2016;100:190-208.
doi: http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.critrevonc.2016.01.022

A 7-year-old boy with a group A Streptococcus throat infection that began about 3 weeks ago
presents with gross hematuria and swelling. Physical examination findings are normal except for a
blood pressure of 120/80 mm Hg. Laboratory investigations reveal normal blood chemistry test results
and complete blood cell count and low serum C3 level. Patient is diagnosed with acute
poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis.
Of the following, the incidence of poststreptococcal acute glomerulonephritis in the United States is
options: decreasing because of aggressive measures focused on acute rheumatic fever because the 2 diseases are caused by the same bacterial strains
decreasing because of decreased impetigo rates from increased access to medical care and changes in the bacterial causes of cellulitis
increasing because of increased immigration from developing countries, where the incidence of the disease is high
increasing because of increasing antibiotic resistance seen in the bacterial strains that cause cellulitis
explanation:
B. decreasing because of decreased impetigo rates from increased access to medical care and
changes in the bacterial causes of cellulitis
The incidence of poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN) in the United States is decreasing
because of decreased impetigo rates from increased access to medical care and changes in the
bacterial causes of cellulitis. Although PSGN and rheumatic fever are both decreasing in incidence,
and possibly because of similar reasons, the 2 diseases are not caused by the same strains of group
A Streptococcus (GAS). Nephritogenic strains of GAS are opacity factor positive, whereas
rheumatogenic strains are factor negative.
PSGN is the best known form of postinfectious glomerulonephritis. The association of dark and
scanty urine after scarlet fever has been known for centuries. Because it was later discovered in the
1920s that scarlet fever was caused by an infection with group A Streptococcus, this postscarlatinal
renal disease was correctly termed PSGN. PSGN has historically been the most common cause of
glomerulonephritis in children worldwide and in the United States, with a global burden estimated at
close to 500,000 cases annually. However, there have been changes in the epidemiology of this
disorder with improvements in global health care, causing shifts in population susceptibility, reported
incidence, and possibly even disease severity.
Like many diseases, the reporting of the worldwide incidence of PSGN is limited by the manner of
reporting by individual nations. For PSGN, most of the reported international data are based on
hospitalization rates for the disease with the overall incidence estimated as a ratio of actual cases to
the number of hospitalized cases. Using this method, despite its limitations, the most recent estimates
from 2007 predicted that there 472,000 incident cases of PSGN worldwide, with 456,000 cases in
developing nations alone. This gave an annual incidence of 9.3 cases per 100,000 persons in
developing countries. However, this may underestimate the true incidence of PSGN in many
developing countries because they may lack the medical infrastructure to track, let alone report, such
data.
Despite the limitations, longitudinal studies of PSGN hospitalizations have found a decreasing
incidence of the disease worldwide. This decrease in incidence has been reported in less developed
(Chile, Venezuela, Mexico, Nigeria, India) and developed (China, Singapore, South Korea, Italy,
Australia) countries. Reasons cited for the decreasing incidence worldwide are improvement of
access to medical care (ie, antibiotics) and improved public hygiene in many of the less developed
world. Despite a decreasing overall incidence in countries with higher indexes of health, there are still
small epidemics or clusters of cases reported from poorer communities within these countries,
located in either rural or aboriginal settings, where care may not be the same as in other regions of
these nations.
Similar to the rest of the world, the incidence of PSGN in the United States is also decreasing. The
pediatric nephrology group in Memphis reported a decrease in annual hospitalization rates for PSGN
of 80% from the 1960s (31 patients per year) to the 1980s (5.9 patients per year). Similarly, the
group in Jacksonville, Florida, documented a decreasing annual incidence of 2.18 hospital cases per
100,000 persons in their early cohort (1957-1973) vs only 0.64 cases in their later cohort (2000s). In
both these studies there was a shift in the antecedent infection causing PSGN seen between the 2
eras, with pyoderma being the predominant cause in the early cohorts and pharyngitis in the later
cohorts. In fact, the Florida study also found that the incidence of impetigo causing PSGN had
decreased 5-fold, whereas the incidence of pharyngitis was statistically unchanged, although slightly
increased. Both studies also saw a shift in the demographics of patients who developed PSGN, from
mostly African Americans to whites and from urban to rural inhabitants, as well as the time of year of
presentation from the autumn (peak time for impetigo) to the winter and spring.

The given reasons for the decreasing incidence of PSGN in the United States are similar to those
given for developing countries: better health care delivery, more widespread use of antibiotics, and
improved socioeconomic conditions. However, there may be additional factors as well. The Florida
study noted that there had been a significant change in the predominant cause of pyodermal
infections in their region, from Streptococcus pyogenes to Staphylococcus aureus. This shift in
impetigo-causing agents has also been seen in other countries, and it remains unclear whether this is
an effect of greater antibiotic use for GAS cellulitis or the increasing resistance of S aureus to certain
antibiotics.
Another cause is a possible decrease in the overall virulence of the bacterium. GAS is commonly
subtyped by its surface M proteins, which help determine its virulence. Since the 1970s, however, it
has been known that another protein, serum opacity factor, may be a determinant of secondary
sequelae of GAS infection. Opacity factor–positive strains, which consist of a certain subset of M
subtypes, have been associated with causing glomerulonephritis, explaining their classification as so-
called nephritogenic strains. Interestingly, opacity factor–negative strains include those that may be
rheumatogenic. The epidemiology of PSGN and acute rheumatic fever, the other significant
complication of GAS, are not perfectly in parallel to each other because they are caused by different
GAS strains. Thus, the 2 disorders have biological and epidemiologic differences, although both are
decreasing in incidence worldwide.
Nephritogenic strains of GAS may also be further subdivided into those that primarily cause
pharyngitis (M types 12, 1, 4, and 25) and those that primarily cause pyoderma (types 49, 2, 42, 56,
57, and 60). The change in overall serotypes, from pyodermal to pharyngitic strains, may be causing
less severe disease and, therefore, less need for hospitalization. In addition, there has been evidence
of frameshift mutations to the genes involved in capsular production seen in strains found in carriers
of GAS, which may allow for better survival of these strains within the host at the expense of their
overall virulence, such that many of the disease strains causing pharyngitis in some hosts are less
virulent overall.
The natural history of PSGN in the United States is the presentation of acute nephritis (hematuria,
edema, hypertension, oliguria) following a latent period after the GAS infection. This latent period may
vary from 7 to 10 days in the case of pharyngitis to 2 to 4 weeks in the case of cellulitis. These
symptoms typically improve after 2 to 7 days, with the visible hematuria often resolving first followed
by an increase in urine volume and rapid resolution of edema. Serum C3 is typically decreased at
time of presentation and will gradually increase back to normal levels during the next 4 to 6 weeks.
There is thought to be limited long-term sequelae from the disease in most cases, with protracted
microscopic hematuria being the most common finding. A few cases may manifest as nephrotic
syndrome or as a rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis, with severe impairment of renal function
requiring intervention.
However, in developing countries, PSGN remains a common cause of acute and chronic kidney
injury. Single-center reports from equatorial regions of the world (Africa, the Middle East, India, and
South America) have cited PSGN as the cause of acute kidney injury in 5% to 50% of all hospitalized
pediatric patients. These reports often cite a greater need for intervention in these patients, with
short-term dialysis, mechanical ventilation, and treatment of heart failure often noted. There are also
reports of higher rates of long-term sequelae, specifically protracted proteinuria and hypertension,
within these populations. Australian aboriginals who had PSGN have a 6-fold greater risk of
macroalbuminuria compared with those who did not, whereas high rates of impaired renal function
have been reported after large outbreaks of PSGN. These discrepancies in disease acuity and
chronicity are not easily explained because they may be secondary to genetic predisposition, overall
populations studied (because many international studies may also include adults who are more
susceptible to long-term sequelae), or differences in GAS strain virulence.

PREP Pearls
 Poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN) has historically been the most common cause of
glomerulonephritis in children worldwide and in the United States, but the incidence of this disease has
significantly decreased in both developed and underdeveloped nations.
 Much of the decline in PSGN in the United States is from a reduction in pyodermal infections, leading to
nephritis, which may be attributable to ready and prompt treatment of impetigo or a shift in the bacterial causes
of cellulitis from predominantly ꞵ-hemolytic Streptococcus to Staphylococcus aureus.
 Acute rheumatic fever and PSGN are both complications of group A Streptococcus infections, but they are
caused by different bacterial strains; therefore, the 2 diseases are epidemiologically different and are extremely
rarely seen in the same patient.
American Board of Pediatrics Content Specification(s)
 Know the natural history and epidemiology of post-infectious glomerulonephritis
Suggested Readings
 Ilyas M, Tolaymat A. Changing epidemiology of acute post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis in Northeastern
Florida: a comparative study. Pediatr Nephrol. 2008;23:(7)1101-1106. doi: http://dx.doi.org/10.1007/s00467-
008-0778-1
 Rodriguez-Iturbe B, Musser JM. The current state of poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis. J Am Soc Nephrol.
2008;19(10):1855-1864. doi: http://dx.doi.org/10.1681/ASN.2008010092
 VanDeVoorde RG III. Poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis: the most common acute
glomerulonephritis. Pediatr Rev. 2015;36(1):3-13. doi: http://dx.doi.org/10.1542/pir.36-1-3

You are designing a clinical trial and developing the data collection forms. You want to collect
information regarding household income and instead of leaving a blank area for the participant to
report his/her income you decide to provide the following choices he or she can choose from: less
than $50,000, $50,000 to $75,000, $75,001 to $100,000, and greater than $100,000
Of the following, the BEST way to describe this income variable is
options: continuous variable
dichotomous variable
nominal variable
ordinal variable
explanation:
D. ordinal variable
In the vignette, there are 4 distinct categories of income, with the continuous variable category
indicating the lowest income level and the ordinal variable category indicating the highest income
level. This classifies this variable as an ordinal value.
A continuous variable is a quantitative, numerical data point with an infinite number of possibilities
along a continuum, such as height, weight, blood pressure, IQ, and yearly income. One family’s
yearly income may be $80,125, another may be $80,126.50, and yet another may be $81,100.16.
This is in contrast to a categorical variable, which is a qualitative, discrete variable with a limited
number of possibilities. There are 3 main types of categorical variables: dichotomous, nominal, and
ordinal.
Dichotomous variables are variables or descriptive characteristics that can only be divided into 2
categories, for example, has disease/doesn’t have disease, yes/no, or male/female.
Variables with more than 2 categories are either nominal or ordinal variables. Examples are eye color
(green, blue, brown), race (per US Census Bureau: white, black/African American, American
Indian/Alaska Native, Asian, Native Hawaiian/other Pacific Islander), and Likert pain scales (no hurt,
hurts little bit, hurts little more, hurts even more, hurts whole lot, hurts worst). When the categorical
variable has an order or hierarchy to it (hurts worst > no hurt), this is considered an ordinal
variable. When there is no order/hierarchy (eye color, race), then the variable is a nominal variable.
Sometimes variables that could be continuous variables (eg, income level) are collected or reported
as categorical variables (as described in the vignette: <$50,000, $50,000-$75,000, $75,001-
$100,000, >$100,000) instead of being reported as a distinct/exact number (ie, $80,101). Another
common example of this is with blood pressure (ordinal variables: normotensive, prehypertensive,
stage I hypertension, stage II hypertension) instead of being reported as a continuous variable
(135/88 mm Hg). This is occasionally done for ease of reporting or describing study populations or
because of statistical considerations (calculating an odds ratio, investigating for interaction, etc).
PREP Pearls
 Variables are either continuous or categorical.
 Categorical variables can further be described as dichotomous (2 distinct choices), nominal (>2 categories, no
order/hierarchy), or ordinal (>2 categories with a specific order/hierarchy).
American Board of Pediatrics Content Specification(s)
 Distinguish types of variables (eg, continuous, categorical, ordinal, nominal)
Suggested Readings
 Shoben AB. Summary measures in statistics. In: Epidemiology and Biostatistics. Berlin, Germany: Springer
Science+Business Media LLC; 2009:153-62.

A 6-year-old girl was seen by her pediatrician for a well-child visit. She had normal growth and
development and normal physical examination findings. A urine dipstick test result was positive for
glucose (100-300 mg/dL [5.6-16.6 mmol/L]) but was otherwise normal. Blood chemistry revealed a
normal serum creatinine concentration and a blood glucose concentration of 90 mg/dL (5.0 mmol/L).
Repeated urine dipstick tests and urinalyses consistently revealed the presence of glucose in the
urine in the absence of hyperglycemia. Review of systems is unremarkable, including the absence of
gastrointestinal symptoms. Family history is noncontributory.
Of the following, the gene that is MOST likely to be mutated in this patient is
options: glucose transporter type 2 (GLUT2)
insulin growth factor 1 receptor (IGF1R)
sodium-glucose cotransporter type 1 (SGLT1)
sodium-glucose cotransporter type 2 (SGLT2)
explanation:
D. sodium-glucose cotransporter type 2 (SGLT2)
The patient described in the vignette has significant glucosuria in the absence of gastrointestinal
symptoms or glycogen storage disease and therefore most likely has mutations in the sodium-
glucose cotransporter type 2 (SGLT2) gene. There are no known mutations of glucose transporter
type 1 (GLUT1) that cause renal glucosuria. Although all 3 transporters, sodium-glucose
cotransporter type 1 (SGLT1), SGLT2, and glucose transporter type 2 (GLUT2), regulate transport of
glucose in many organs, SGLT2 is present almost exclusively in renal proximal tubules.
Accordingly, SGLT2 loss of function is the primary cause of renal glucosuria.
The girl in the vignette has a condition called renal glucosuria. In the absence of hyperglycemia and
increased filtered glucose, there are 2 main causes of glucosuria. The first disorder, primary or
familial renal glucosuria (FRG), occurs as an isolated abnormality characterized by glucosuria in the
absence of hyperglycemia and in the absence of a generalized tubular dysfunction (as in Fanconi
syndrome). The second disorder, glucose-galactose malabsorption, presents in infancy, usually as
severe diarrhea and dehydration. Not all patients with glucose-galactose malabsorption present with
glucosuria; if present, it is usually mild. Both disorders are caused by impaired glucose transport in
the proximal tubule.
Glucose transport in the proximal tubule is mostly transcellular. The early segments (S1 and S2) of
the proximal tubule are responsible for the reabsorption of the bulk of filtered glucose, and the
remainder is reabsorbed in the late proximal segment (S3). A family of sodium-glucose cotransporters
located at the apical membrane couples the uptake of glucose to sodium. A member of this
family, SGLT2, mediates apical glucose uptake in the early proximal tubule (S1 segment). This is a
high-capacity, low-affinity transporter and has a stoichiometry of sodium to glucose of 1. In the late
proximal tubule (S3 segment), SGLT1 is responsible for apical sodium uptake. SGLT1 is a high-
affinity, low-capacity cotransporter and has a stoichiometry of sodium to glucose of 2:1. The transport
of glucose across the basolateral membrane occurs by facilitated diffusion and is mediated by
another family of glucose transporters (GLUTs), which are sodium independent. In the early proximal
tubule, GLUT2 is responsible for basolateral glucose transport, whereas GLUT1 is the main
transporter in the late proximal tubule.
Inherited FRG can be autosomal recessive or autosomal dominant and is caused by mutations in
the SGLT2 gene. The most severe form of FRG, type 0, is caused by loss-of-function mutations
of SGLT2, resulting in complete absence of renal tubular reabsorption of glucose. Patients with type
A and type B usually present with less severe forms of FRG and harbor hypomorphic mutations
in SGLT2. Patients with FRG, including those with the most severe form (type 0), are generally
asymptomatic. Of note, SGLT2 inhibitors are now a treatment of diabetes mellitus in adults and work
by increasing renal glucose excretion. In contrast, patients with the glucose-galactose malabsorption
syndrome are usually symptomatic (gastrointestinal symptoms). Glucose-galactose malabsorption is
an autosomal recessive disease caused by mutation of SGLT1 (gene SLC5A1); given that the role of
SGLT1 is minor in renal reabsorption of glucose, glucosuria in these patients is usually mild or
absent. Loss-of-function mutations of the gene encoding GLUT2 (SLC2A2) cause a rare autosomal
recessive glycogen storage disease known as Fanconi-Bickel syndrome. Glucosuria is also a
manifestation of GLUT2 mutations because it is involved in basolateral uptake of glucose.
PREP Pearls
 Isolated renal glucosuria is usually caused by inherited mutations in sodium-glucose cotransporter 2 (SGLT2)
and less commonly in SGLT1 or glucose transporter 2 (GLUT2).

 Patients with renal glucosuria due to SGLT2 mutations are asymptomatic, whereas patients
with SGLT1 mutations are usually associated with glucose-malabsorption syndrome and gastrointestinal
symptoms.
American Board of Pediatrics Content Specification(s)
 Know the molecular and genetic basis of renal glucosuria
Suggested Readings
 Santer R, Kinner M, Lassen CL, et al. Molecular analysis of the SGLT2 gene in patients with renal glucosuria. J
Am Soc Nephrol 2003;14:2873–2882. doi: http://dx.doi.org/10.1097/01.ASN.0000092790.89332.D2
 Turk E, Zabel B, Mundlos S, Dyer J, Wright EM. Glucose/galactose malabsorption caused by a defect in the
Na+/glucose cotransporter. Nature. 1991;350:354–356. doi: http://dx.doi.org/10.1038/350354a0

You are seeing a new patient for initial evaluation of hypertension. The patient is an obese, 15-year-
old boy who was seen 2 weeks ago by his pediatrician for a well-child visit. Blood pressure measured
during triage was 142/91 mm Hg. Blood pressure measured by his pediatrician during the visit was
139/89 mm Hg (95th percentile for his age, sex, and height is 133/83 mm Hg). He was diagnosed
with hypertension, counseled on a heart healthy lifestyle, and referred for evaluation.
In your office, you perform 3 blood pressure measurements by manual auscultation, which are as
follows: 135/80, 127/78, and 122/75 mm Hg. Physical examination findings are notable only for
obesity, and you note that his body mass index (calculated as weight in kilograms divided by square
of height in meters) is 38.
Of the following, the BEST next step in the management of this patient is
options: arrange for him to return to your office in a week for repeat blood pressure measurements
begin treatment with an antihypertensive medication while he continues to work on a heart healthy lifestyle
initiate an evaluation for secondary causes of hypertension, including laboratory tests, renal ultrasonography, and echocardiography
prescribe weight loss and a heart healthy lifestyle with follow-up in 6 months
explanation:
A. arrange for him to return to your office in a week for repeat blood pressure measurements
For the patient described in the vignette, the next best step in management is to arrange for him to
return to your office in a week for repeat blood pressure (BP) measurements. The mean BP
measurement for the patient described in the vignette is 128/78 mm Hg, which is less than the 95th
percentile (133/83 mm Hg). His obesity should prompt a discussion and education about therapeutic
lifestyle change, including weight loss, but follow-up of 6 months would be inappropriate at this time. If
the patient has sustained elevations in his BP at or above the 95th percentile, then he should undergo
a workup, including laboratory tests, renal ultrasonography, and echocardiography. Because he has
not yet been confirmed to be hypertensive, an evaluation for secondary causes is not necessary. An
antihypertensive medication should be prescribed to children with hypertension if their hypertension is
secondary; if they have evidence of end-organ damage, such as left ventricular hypertrophy; if they
have diabetes as a comorbidity; if they are symptomatic; or if a trial of therapeutic lifestyle change has
failed. This child does not meet any of these criteria.
A diagnosis of hypertension is made when there is evidence of sustained elevation in BP at or above
the 95th percentile for an individual’s age, sex, and height percentile. These BP measurements
should be obtained via manual auscultation and should be repeated on 3 separate occasions with 3
measurements obtained at each encounter. If the mean of all these (≥9) manual measurements is the
95th percentile or higher, the individual is diagnosed with hypertension. Once the diagnosis of
hypertension is made in a pediatric patient, a laboratory and imaging evaluation should be
undertaken, and counseling on a heart healthy lifestyle, including weight loss when appropriate,
should be initiated. Essential to this is the repeated measurement of BP. BP measurements often
decrease over time with sequential measurements. Two possible explanations for this are the
statistical phenomenon of regression to the mean and accommodation to the measurement. As with
any clinically obtained measurements where there is intraindividual variability, repeating the
measurement allows one to get closer to the truth. The more times a measurement is repeated, the
lower the variance and the increased likelihood of obtaining an accurate result. Repeating a
measurement also allows one to be more comfortable and familiar with the method (an
accommodation effect), which can further facilitate accurate measurement.
The importance of repeated measurement in the diagnosis of hypertension was well described in a
study by Sorof et al in 2004. In this school-based screening study, the investigators measured BP
among more than 5,100 children. All children with a mean of 3 seated BPs greater than 95th
percentile were asked to return for repeat measurements. If on the second screen their mean BPs
remained greater than the 95th percentile, they were asked to return a third time for another set of BP
measurements. The investigators calculated hypertension prevalence among this population using
measurements from only the first visit, the first 2 visits, or all 3 visits. Among this population, if
hypertension was diagnosed based only on the 3 measurements obtained at the first visit, the
prevalence of hypertension would be 19%. However, if hypertension was diagnosed after confirming
that BPs remained above the 95th percentile on both the first and second visits, the hypertension
prevalence was almost half that initial estimate (9.5%). Finally, if hypertension was diagnosed based
on sustained elevations of BP above the 95th percentile on all 3 occasions (the current clinical
recommendations), the prevalence of hypertension was even lower at 4.5%.
PREP Pearls
 A diagnosis of hypertension can only be made once an individual’s mean manual blood pressure from 3
separate visits is confirmed to be at or above the 95th percentile for an individual’s age, sex, and height
percentile.

 Blood pressure measurements decrease over time with sequential measurements because of regression to the
mean and accommodation to the measurement.
 An antihypertensive medication should be prescribed to children with hypertension if their hypertension is
secondary; if they have evidence of end-organ damage, such as left ventricular hypertrophy; if they have
diabetes as a comorbidity; if they are symptomatic; or if a trial of therapeutic lifestyle change has failed.
American Board of Pediatrics Content Specification(s)
 Know the role of multiple blood pressure measurements in the diagnosis of hypertension
Suggested Readings
 Brady TM, Redwine KM, Flynn JT. Screening blood pressure measurement in children: are we saving
lives? Pediatr Nephrol. 2014;29(6):947-950. doi: http://dx.doi.org/10.1007/s00467-013-2715-1
 Expert Panel on Integrated Guidelines for Cardiovascular Health and Risk Reduction in Children and
Adolescents; National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute. Expert Panel on Integrated Guidelines for
Cardiovascular Health and Risk Reduction in Children and Adolescents: summary report. Pediatrics.
2011;128(suppl 5):S213-S256. doi: http://dx.doi.org/10.1542/peds.2009-2107C
 Sorof JM, Lai D, Turner J, Poffenbarger T, Portman RJ. Overweight, ethnicity, and the prevalence of
hypertension in school-aged children. Pediatrics. 2004;113(3, pt 1):475-482.

A 2-year-old boy is seen in the emergency department with a several day history of watery diarrhea.
He has been drinking plain water but does not want to drink other fluids. His heart rate is 120
beats/min, blood pressure is 80/60 mm Hg, and capillary refill time is prolonged. Laboratory data
reveal the following: sodium 128 mEq/L (128 mmol/L); potassium, 3.2 mEq/L (3.2 mmol/L); chloride,
99 mEq/L (99 mmol/L); bicarbonate, 20 mEq/L (20 mmol/L); urea nitrogen, 25 mg/dL (8.9 mmol/L);
creatinine, 0.5 mg/dL (44 μmol/L; and calcium, 9.8 mg/dL (2.45 mmol/L).
Of the following, the MOST likely description of this child’s clinical status is
options: hypertonic dehydration
hypotonic dehydration
hypotonic euvolemia
isotonic dehydration
explanation:
B. hypotonic dehydration
Hyponatremia is defined as a serum or plasma sodium level less than 135 mEq/L (135 mmol/L). It is
among the most common electrolyte abnormalities in children. Hypotonic dehydration is defined as
loss of total body water with true hyponatremia in which the serum osmolality is less than normal. A
decrease in serum sodium level, and hence a decrease in serum osmolality, can lead to neurologic
findings and in severe cases significant morbidity and mortality, especially in those with acute
changes in serum sodium concentration.
The serum sodium concentration is determined by the ratio between sodium salts and water in the
extracellular fluid compartment. Thus, the serum sodium concentration in a child with hypovolemia
varies with the relative loss of solute to water. Changes in the serum sodium concentration play an
important role in deciding the type and speed of fluid repletion therapy, especially in children with
severe hyponatremia or hypernatremia.
The development of hyponatremia in the setting of dehydration reflects net solute loss in excess of
water loss. Normally, sodium losses in diarrhea are not hypertonic to plasma. Rather, solute and
water are lost in equal proportions. In the presence of normal thirst mechanisms, ingested water is
retained because hypovolemia-induced secretion of antidiuretic hormone limits water excretion and
the serum sodium concentration is lowered.
In isonatremic dehydration, the serum sodium concentration is between 135 and 145 mEq/L (135-145
mmol/L). In this setting, solute is lost in proportion to water loss. For example, in patients with
secretory diarrhea, the solute concentration of the diarrheal fluid can be similar to the plasma solute
concentration, and the serum sodium concentration is not affected.
In hypernatremic dehydration, the serum sodium is greater than 145 mEq/L (145 mmol/L), reflecting
water loss in excess of solute loss. In children with viral gastroenteritis, such as rotavirus, the sodium
concentration of the diarrheal fluid typically ranges from 40 to 100 mEq/L (40-100 mmol/L). Loss of
this relatively dilute fluid will tend to induce hypernatremia if there is insufficient water intake, which
increases renal sodium reabsorption, aggravating hypernatremic dehydration.
Fever or tachypnea often accompany pediatric illness associated with hypovolemia, resulting in
increased insensible water losses, especially in young children. Water is, again, lost in excess of
solute, contributing to an increase in serum sodium concentration. A similar effect is seen with dilute
urinary losses in children with diabetes insipidus.
PREP Pearls
 Hypotonic dehydration is present when the serum sodium concentration is less than 135 mEq/L (135 mmol/L)
in the setting of dehydration.
 Hypotonic dehydration usually occurs when volume loss occurs and the thirst mechanism is intact, resulting in
ingestion of free water that then causes hyponatremia.
American Board of Pediatrics Content Specification(s)
 Know how to define hypotonic dehydration
Suggested Readings
 Edelman IS, Leibman J, O'Meara MP, Birkenfeld LW. Interrelations between serum sodium concentration,
serum osmolarity and total exchangeable sodium, total exchangeable potassium and total body water. J Clin
Invest.1958;37:1236-1256. doi: http://dx.doi.org/10.1172/JCI103712

 Freedman SB, Vandermeer B, Milne A, et al. Diagnosing clinically significant dehydration in children with acute
gastroenteritis using noninvasive methods: a meta-analysis. J Pediatr. 2015;166:908-916.
doi: http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.jpeds.2014.12.029
 Rose BD. New approach to disturbances in the plasma sodium concentration. Am J Med. 1986;81:1033-1040.
doi: http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/0002-9343(86)90401-8

A 7-year-old boy is seen in the emergency department because of swelling, tea-colored urine, and
irritability. On physical examination, he has generalized edema and a blood pressure of 129/83 mm
Hg. His other vital signs are normal. Urinalysis reveals proteinuria (2+), 10 to 20 white blood cells per
high-power field, more than 100 red blood cells per high-power field, and a urine protein to creatinine
ratio of 0.9. Serum electrolytes are normal, blood urea nitrogen level is 29 mg/dL (10.4 mmol/L), and
creatinine level is 1.1 mg/dL (97 μmol/L). He has a history of streptococcal pharyngitis (strep throat)
diagnosed 2 weeks earlier, and the antistreptolysin O titer was significantly elevated.
Of the following, the MOST likely abnormalities in serum complement concentrations are
options: low C3 and low C4 levels
low C3 and normal C4 levels
normal C3 and low C4 levels
normal C3 and normal C4 levels
explanation:
B. low C3 and normal C4 levels
Complement abnormalities are noted in several forms of glomerulonephritis (Table).
Table. Hypocompletemic and Normocomplementic Glomerulonephritis (GN)
ANCA, antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibody; MPGN, membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis; RPGN,
rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis.
For the patient described in the vignette, low C3 and normal C4 levels are the most likely
abnormalities in serum complement concentrations because these are seen in postinfectious
glomerulonephritis and membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis type II (also called dense deposit
disease). Low C3 and low C4 levels are not likely because these are seen in forms of
glomerulonephritis that are caused by activation of the classic complement pathway, such as
systemic lupus glomerulonephritis and membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis type I and type III.
Normal C3 and low C4 levels are not usually seen in glomerulonephritis. Normal C3 and normal C4
levels are seen in normocompletemic glomerulonephritis (Table).
In approximately 85% to 95% of patients with postinfectious glomerulonephritis, C3 levels are
significantly low in the first 2 weeks of the disease course. C3 levels typically return to normal within 6
to 8 weeks of the initial presentation. In postinfectious glomerulonephritis, C4 levels are usually
normal, indicating activation of the alternative complement pathway.
Postinfectious glomerulonephritis is usually associated with a mild decrease in glomerular filtration
rate, which is detected by an increase in serum creatinine levels. These levels usually return to
normal after the initial diagnosis. Acute kidney injury that requires dialysis is uncommon.

Urinalysis in patients with postinfectious glomerulonephritis reveals hematuria with red blood cells
that are typically dysmorphic, with or without red blood cell casts. There are varying degrees of
proteinuria and often pyuria. Nephrotic-range proteinuria of greater than 1,000 mg/m2 per day or 40
mg/m2 per hour is uncommon and occurs in approximately 5% of cases at presentation. The
urinalysis should be performed on a freshly voided specimen.
In 85% to 95% of case of postinfectious glomerulonephritis, the preceding infection is with specific
nephritogenic strains of group A β-hemolytic streptococcus. Poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis can
present as sporadic or during an epidemic of group A streptococcal infection. In 10% to 15% of cases
of postinfectious glomerulonephritis, the preceding infection is with another agent.
Because patients with poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis can present weeks after an antecedent
infection, only approximately 25% of patients will have a positive throat or skin culture result. In
patients with impetigo, there is an increased likelihood of obtaining a positive skin culture result.
Elevated titers of antibodies to extracellular streptococcal products is evidence of a recent group A
streptococcal infection. Results of the streptozyme test, which measures 5 different streptococcal
antibodies, are positive in more than 95% of patients with pharyngitis and approximately 80% of those
with skin infections. The interval between acute glomerulonephritis after skin infection (2-4 weeks) is
longer than the one after throat infection (1-3 weeks).The streptozyme test includes antibodies to
antistreptolysin, antihyaluronidase (AHase), antistreptokinase, anti-nicotinamide-adenine
dinucleotidase, and anti-DNase B antibodies. These antibodies can be measured individually as well.
After a pharyngeal infection, the antistreptolysin, anti-DNAse B, anti-nicotinamide-adenine
dinucleotidase, and AHase titers are commonly elevated, whereas only the anti-DNAse B and AHase
titers are elevated after a skin infection. This elevation is due to lipid and cholesterol esters in the skin
interfering with the recognition of the other antigens.
Postinfectious glomerulonephritis is usually diagnosed based on clinical findings and a laboratory
finding of acute nephritis, including hematuria with or without red blood cell casts, variable degrees of
proteinuria, edema, and hypertension.
PREP Pearls
 Laboratory findings in postinfectious glomerulonephritis include mild acute kidney injury, hematuria gross or
microscopic, proteinuria, pyuria, and low C3 and normal C4 levels.
 When the preceding infection is a group A streptococcal infection, there is also serologic evidence of a
previous streptococcal infection.
American Board of Pediatrics Content Specification(s)
 Know the laboratory evaluation for the diagnosis and management of post-infectious glomerulonephritis
Suggested Readings
 Cameron JS, Vick RM, Ogg CS, et al. Plasma C3 and C4 concentrations in management of
glomerulonephritis. Br Med J .1973;33(5882):668-672.
 Lewis EJ, Carpenter CB, Schur PH. Serum complement component levels in human glomerulonephritis. Ann
Intern Med. 1971;75(4):555-560. doi: http://dx.doi.org/10.7326/0003-4819-75-4-555
 Wyatt RJ, Forristal J, West CD, et al. Complement profiles in acute post-streptococcal
glomerulonephritis. Pediatr Nephrol. 1988;2(2):219-223.

You are reviewing the literature regarding risk factors for progression of chronic kidney disease with
one of the medical students rotating on your service. You discuss the findings of the Effect of Strict
Blood Pressure Control and ACE Inhibition on the Progression of CRF in Pediatric
Patients (ESCAPE) trial (http://www.nejm.org/doi/pdf/10.1056/NEJMoa0902066) and read that “the
hazard ratio for progression to the end point with intensified blood-pressure control was 0.65 (95%
confidence interval [CI], 0.44 to 0.94; P=0.02).” The student asks what the P value of .02 means.
Of the following, the response that BEST explains how to interpret the P value in this study is
options: ninety-eight of 100 children with intensified blood pressure control will have a 35% decreased risk of progressing to the end point
the probability of finding a hazard ratio of 0.65 or lower if there were actually no difference in risk factors between the groups is 2%
the probability that the null hypothesis is true and that there is no difference between the groups of blood pressure control on chronic kidney disease progression is greater than 2%
there is a 98% chance that the true hazard ratio is 0.65
explanation:
B. the probability of finding a hazard ratio of 0.65 or lower if there were actually no difference in risk
factors between the groups is 2%
When designing a research study, one must first generate a hypothesis. This hypothesis (the
alternative hypothesis, which is generally that those with an exposure are more likely to have an
outcome than those without the exposure or that those receiving an intervention are more likely to
have an outcome than those who do not receive the intervention) is then tested against the null
hypothesis (generally that there is no difference in outcome between those who were exposed vs
those who were not or in those who received the intervention vs those who did not). Because we can
never know the truth, we use the P value to help determine how much confidence we can have that
the observed association or effect was real and not due to chance alone.
The P value is the probability of obtaining the observed result (a hazard ratio of 0.65 in the vignette
above) or a result more extreme than observed (ie, a hazard ratio smaller than 0.65) when the null
hypothesis is actually true (there is no difference between those with intensified blood pressure
control and those without intensified blood pressure control). In other words, the P value tells you how
often these results would occur by chance alone if there really was no difference between those with
intensified blood pressure control vs nonintensive blood pressure control. Using the example in the
vignette, if the truth is that there is no difference between groups and you repeat the trial 100 times,
you would observe a hazard ratio of 0.65 or lower 2 of the 100 times by chance alone. Therefore, the
best way to explain how to interpret the P value in the study mentioned in the vignette is that the
probability of finding a hazard ratio of 0.65 or lower if there were actually no difference in risk factors
between the groups is 2%.
It is important to recognize that the P value does not tell you the probability of obtaining the observed
result; that probability is called the likelihood of the test statistic and is much smaller (the P value is
the probability of achieving the observed result or one more extreme). The P value also does not tell
you anything about the precision of the estimate (ie, 95% of the time you will get a hazard ratio
between 0.55 and 0.75 or 95% of the time you will get a hazard ratio of 0.15 and 0.99; you get that
information from the confidence interval) or about the clinical significance of the findings.
PREP Pearls
 The P value is the probability of obtaining the observed result or a result more extreme than observed when
the null hypothesis is actually true.
 The P value also does not tell you anything about the precision of the estimate or about the clinical significance
of the findings.
American Board of Pediatrics Content Specification(s)
 Interpret a p-value
Suggested Readings
 Dawson B, Trapp RG. Research questions about on group. In: Foltin J, Lebowitz H, Fernando N, eds. Basic
and Clinical Biostatistics. New York, NY: Lange Medical Books; 2004:109-110.
 Wuhl E, Trivelli A, Picca S, et al. Strict blood-pressure control and progression of renal failure in children. N
Engl J Med. 2009;361(17):1639-1650. doi: http://dx.doi.org/10.1056/NEJMoa0902066

A 9-year-old white girl with end-stage kidney disease caused by nephronophthisis is being evaluated
for a kidney transplant. Her parents, both also white, are interested in being considered for living
donor evaluation. Her mother is 37 years old, has group A+ blood type, has no medical problems, is
not taking any medications, and works as a clerk. Her father is 40 years old, has group B+ blood type,
has mild hypertension well controlled with 1 medication, and works as a store manager on a night
shift. The child has group AB+ blood type. The parents ask you about the long-term medical risk that
they would undertake if either were the donor.
Of the following, the MOST correct statement about medical risk of living kidney donation is
options: the 90-day postoperative mortality risk for the donor is approximately 1%
the risk of end-stage kidney disease in living donors is the same as that in the general population
the risk of major cardiovascular events is lower after donation than in age-matched healthy nondonors
white race donors have the highest risk of end-stage kidney disease among all racial group
explanation:
B. the risk of end-stage kidney disease in living donors is the same as that in the general population
The risk of end-stage kidney disease in living donors is the same as that in the general population,
although the risk is slightly higher when compared with healthy nondonors. The 90-day mortality after
living kidney donation is 0.031% not 1%. The risk of major cardiovascular events is similar or slightly
higher, not lower, in donors than in matched healthy nondonors. In addition, black race donors, not
white race donors, have the highest risk of end-stage kidney disease among all racial groups.
Living kidney donation offers a special opportunity for children with end-stage kidney disease to
receive a kidney transplant. This is the only time that surgeons will perform a major surgery on a
healthy person for no medical benefit to the donor but for the medical benefit of someone else.
Therefore, donors undergo an extensive workup to ensure that they are healthy enough to donate
and that medical risks to the donor are minimized. Nevertheless, the medical risks to the donor are
not zero. Such risks include donor death in the early postdonation period, major adverse
cardiovascular events, end-stage kidney disease (ESKD), hypertension, gestational hypertension,
and hyperuricemia or gout (Table ).
The risk of donor death after living kidney donation is very low. Data from a study by Segev et al,
using a linkage of Organ Procurement and Transplant Network registry data with the Social Security
Death Master File for 80,347 living donors between 1994 and 2009, revealed a 90-day mortality
estimate of 3.1 per 10,000 (or 0.031%). This mortality rate did not change significantly during the 15-
year study period. In fact, the concept that transplant professionals promoted for a long time was that
kidney donors live longer. This concept was popularized on the basis of general population
comparisons and limited follow-up but with obvious confounding by the fact that living donors undergo
medical evaluation and rigorous selection for good health at the time of donation. Therefore, a key
aspect in determining such risks is the selection of the comparison population.
For major cardiovascular events, data indicate similar or only slightly higher risk. Garg et al compared
2028 living kidney donors in Ontario, Canada (1992–2009), with 20,280 healthy, demographically
matched nondonors (ie, a healthier population that went through a donor evaluation but were not
selected) and found that the risk of death or major cardiovascular events during a median 7 years of

follow-up (maximum, 18 years) was lower in donors than in healthy nondonors. The risk of death-
censored major cardiovascular events alone was similar among donors and nondonors (1.7 vs 2.0
events per 1,000 person-years). In another study, Mjoen et al found a slightly higher cardiovascular
mortality after living donation than in healthy nondonors, with a median follow-up of 15 years.
The risk of ESKD after kidney donation does not exceed ESKD rates in the general population. An
analysis of living kidney donors in the United States between 1994 and 2003 quantified a
postdonation ESKD rate of 0.134 per 1,000 person-years during a mean follow-up of 9.8 years, which
was not higher than the ESKD rate in the general population. However, again, the general population
is a limited comparison group given the robust medical evaluation that donors undertake.
Recent studies with individuals selected for baseline good health as the comparison group suggest
that donation is associated with a small increase in the risk of ESKD, although the absolute
postdonation risk remains low. Grams et al found that the 15-year observed risks of ESKD after
donation among kidney donors in the United States were 3.5 to 5.3 times as high as the projected
risks in the absence of donation. In the same study, when considered by race, black living donors had
the highest absolute incidence of ESKD and the highest risk attributable to donation. Currently, the
living donor also undertakes certain financial risks, including unpaid time from work, wages lost,
potentially incomplete coverage of medical costs, and loss of eligibility for life insurance.
PREP Pearls
 Living kidney donation is generally safe because the donors undergo careful evaluation and selection.
 There are small medical risks to the donor, primarily a low risk of mortality within 90 days of donation and a
slight increase in risk of later end-stage kidney disease compared with a healthy nondonor population.
American Board of Pediatrics Content Specification(s)
 Identify the long-term medical and financial risks to the living donor

The glomerular filtration rate (GFR) of the developing mammalian kidney increases after birth in all
species examined.
Of the following, the MOST important factor that causes the immediate postnatal increase in GFR is
options: decreased plasma oncotic pressure
increased glomerular ultrafiltration coefficient
increased net glomerular ultrafiltration pressure
increased renal plasma flow
explanation:
B. increased glomerular ultrafiltration coefficient
Elegant single-nephron micropuncture studies performed in maturing rats and guinea pigs have
documented that the postnatal increase in net ultrafiltration pressure (P ) is modest (2.5-fold) and
uf
accounts for only approximately 10% of the 25-fold increase in glomerular filtration rate (GFR) during
postnatal maturation. The maturational increase in glomerular plasma flow, which is mediated by
changes in intrarenal vasoactive hormonal systems (angiotensin II, kinins, prostaglandins,
endothelin), contributes to the postnatal increase in P . However, the major factor that mediates the
uf
postnatal increase in GFR is the progressive increase in ultrafiltration coefficient (K) caused by
f
enhanced glomerular surface area (8- to 10-fold) attributable to the recruitment of superficial
nephrons in renal cortex and a modest increase in membrane permeability (1.3-fold). Thus, the most
important factor that causes the immediate postnatal increase in GFR is increased glomerular K.
f
The process of glomerular filtration is first initiated between 9 and 12 weeks of gestational age. In
general, there is good correlation between GFR with gestational age. The GFR is low during fetal life
and increases only slightly (2-fold) between 28 and 34 weeks’ gestational age. However, after
approximately 34 weeks and completion of nephrogenesis, the GFR increases markedly (up to 5-
fold). Thus, a premature infant will have a small increase in GFR until 34 weeks of gestation.
Postnatally, there is a rapid rise in GFR factored to kidney weight and body surface area; GFR
reaches adult values by 2 years of age. The nonlinear increase in GFR (accelerated after
nephrogenesis is complete) is conserved among other mammalian species. Overall, the maturational
increase in absolute GFR from term birth to adulthood is approximately 25-fold.
The physiologic determinants of glomerular filtration dynamics include the following:
 The filtration characteristics of glomerular basement membrane–glomerular K
f
 The P , which is the difference between the mean glomerular transcapillary hydraulic pressure
uf
(glomerular capillary minus Bowman space hydraulic pressures) and the mean colloid osmotic
pressures over the length of the glomerular capillary
 Glomerular plasma flow
The capillary hydrostatic pressure favors filtration, whereas the capillary colloid osmotic pressure and
the Bowman space hydrostatic pressure oppose it. Thus, the maturational rise in single-nephron GFR
(SNGFR) can be described in the following formula: SNGFR = K × P , where K is the glomerular
f uf f
ultrafiltration coefficient and P is the net ultrafiltration pressure, defined earlier. K is the product of the
uf f
total surface area available for filtration and the hydraulic conductivity (permeability) of the glomerular
membrane.
PREP Pearls
 The glomerular filtration rate (GFR) is low during fetal life and increases only slightly between 28 and 34
weeks’ conceptional age. However, after approximately 34 weeks, the GFR increases markedly within 1 week
as nephrogenesis is completed.
 After birth, the GFR continues to increase rapidly relative to kidney weight and body surface area until GFR
reaches adult levels by approximately 2 years of age.
 The major factor that mediates the postnatal increase in GFR is the progressive increase in glomerular
ultrafiltration coefficient or Kf.

American Board of Pediatrics Content Specification(s)
 Know the factors contributing to the increase in glomerular filtration rate after birth
Suggested Readings
 Robillard JE, Nakamura KT, Matherne GP, Jose PA. Renal hemodynamics and functional adjustments to
postnatal life. Semin Perinatol. 1988;12(2):143-150.
 Satlin LM, Woda CB, Schwartz GJ. Development of function in the metanephric kidney. In: Vize PD, Woolf AS,
Bard BL, eds. The Kidney: From Normal Development to Congenital Disease. 2004:267-325.
 Spitzer A, Edelmann CM Jr. Maturational changes in pressure gradients for glomerular filtration. Am J
Physiol. 1971;221(5):1431-1435.

You are consulting on a 3-month-old girl for nephrocalcinosis. She was born at 24 weeks’ gestation
because of placental abruption. She was intubated for 2 weeks and then received continuous positive
airway pressure ventilation until 2 weeks ago. She required multiple transfusions of packed red blood
cells for anemia. She received furosemide after the red blood cell transfusions for fluid overload. She
had feeding intolerance and required total parenteral nutrition and is now tolerating 24-calorie per
ounce formula.
Decreased calcium reabsorption in which of the following nephron segments is the MOST likely risk
factor for nephrocalcinosis in this patient?
options: collecting duct
distal convoluted tubule
proximal tubule
thick ascending loop of Henle
explanation:
D. thick ascending loop of Henle
For the patient described in the vignette, decreased calcium reabsorption in the thick ascending loop
(TAL) of Henle is the most likely risk factor for nephrocalcinosis.
Nephrocalcinosis is defined as calcification of the renal parenchyma and was first reported in 1982 in
a cohort of premature infants who had received furosemide. Most of the crystals are likely calcium
oxalate. Reports on the incidence of nephrocalcinosis vary widely, from as low as 7% to as high as
64% of premature infants with gestational ages younger than 32 weeks or birth weights less than 1.5
kg. Diagnosis relies on detection of increased echogenicity in the renal medulla. Differences in
incidence may vary with differences in the premature population studied and in diagnosis of
nephrocalcinosis by ultrasonography.
Increased renal medullary echogenicity can also be observed with renal candidiasis, cytomegalovirus
infection, acute renal failure, polycystic kidney disease, and renal vein thrombosis or as a transient
phenomenon of unclear origin after birth in full-term and premature infants (sometimes referred to as
stasis nephropathy). In addition to prematurity, nephrocalcinosis can be manifestations of diseases,
including primary hyperoxaluria, distal renal tubular acidosis, glucose-galactose malabsorption,
Bartter syndrome, Williams syndrome, and hereditary hypercalciuria with hypophosphatemic rickets.
There are multiple risk factors for nephrocalcinosis in premature infants (Table ).
Table. Risk Factors for Nephrocalcinosis in Premature Infants
White race
Male sex
Family history of kidney stone
Hypercalciuria
Hyperoxaluria (primary or secondary to gastrointestinal issues)
Acidosis
High calcium intake
Low phosphorus intake
Total parenteral nutrition
Furosemide
Caffeine/theophylline
Glucocorticoids
Nephrotoxins (eg, gentamicin)
First, low urinary flow rates in premature infants allow for stasis. A second major factor is that urinary
calcium excretion is higher in preterm infants. Calcium in the body is distributed between bone and
extracellular (serum) and intracellular spaces. A total of 99% of calcium in the body is in the bones.
Growth and bone accretion require net positive accumulation of calcium, from 0.9% of body weight at
birth to 2% of body weight in the adult. This correlates with a positive calcium balance of 150 to 200
mg/d. The extracellular calcium concentration and total body calcium balance is regulated by
absorption and secretion in the gut, bone formation or reabsorption, and urinary calcium excretion.
Calcium is actively transported across the placenta during fetal development, with most occurring in
the third trimester. Intestinal calcium absorption is higher in infants (40%-80%) vs adults (20%-25%).
Premature infants received high calcium (and phosphorus) formulas, which are risk factors for
nephrocalcinosis. In extracellular plasma, 40% to 45% of calcium is protein bound, predominantly by
albumin. Only unbound calcium or calcium salts are filtered by the glomerulus. Binding of calcium is
pH dependent, and acidosis decreases bound calcium. Acidosis is also a risk factor for
nephrocalcinosis associated with prematurity. This may be in part caused by the effects of acidosis

on increasing the filtered calcium load. Acidosis may also stimulate calcium release from bone to act
as a buffer. Finally, acidosis may decrease urinary citrate (a stone inhibitor) excretion.
In the adult kidney, approximately 65% of calcium is reabsorbed in the proximal tubule, 25% in the
TAL, 8% in the distal tubule, and approximately 2% is excreted. In the proximal tubule, calcium
reabsorption occurs paracellularly driven by sodium and hydrogen exchanger (NHE3) reabsorption.
This absorption is influenced by claudins, which determine the permeability of the proximal tubule to
calcium. Parathyroid hormone (PTH) inhibits NHE3 and can therefore affect calcium excretion.
Claudins 16 and 19 are the major regulators of paracellular permeability of the TAL to calcium. Loss-
of-function mutations in the genes for claudins 16 and 19 are associated with familial
hypomagnesemia with hypercalciuria and nephrocalcinosis. Elevated interstitial calcium activates the
basolateral calcium-sensing receptor (CaSR). The activated CaSR inhibits the NKCC2 cotransporter
and modulates claudins, thereby diminishing calcium reabsorption in states of hypercalcemia.
In contrast, PTH stimulates calcium reabsorption in the TAL (Figure ).
Figure. Furosemide effects on calcium reabsorption in the thick ascending limb of Henle.
In the distal convoluted tubule and connecting duct, there is transcellular reabsorption of calcium.
Calcium enters via apical TRPV5 channels, binds intracellular calbindin D-28k, and exits via the
basolateral sodium-calcium exchanger or via calcium adenosine triphosphatase. TRPV5 expression
is increased by 1,25-hydroxyvitamin D and PTH, thereby increasing calcium reabsorption. In the
collecting duct, there are minimal effects on calcium excretion, but apical calcium-sensing–like
receptors inhibit water reabsorption and stimulate acidification in the setting of high urinary calcium,
which may serve to prevent urinary stone formation.
Many medications, including furosemide, caffeine, and glucocorticoids, are risk factors for
nephrocalcinosis because of their effects on increasing urinary calcium excretion. Some studies
indicate furosemide is one the most important contributors to nephrocalcinosis. Caffeine and
theophylline likely increase urinary calcium excretion because of their diuretic (increased filtered
calcium) and natriuretic effects.

PREP Pearls
 Nephrocalcinosis is a common complication of prematurity.
 Paracellular absorption of calcium in the thick ascending limb is dependent on the sodium reabsorption via the
the furosemide sensitive NKCC2 cotransporter.
American Board of Pediatrics Content Specification(s)
 Know the importance of furosemide as a risk factor for neonatal calcium-containing stones and
nephrocalcinosis
Suggested Readings
 Edvardsson VO, Goldfarb DS, Lieske JC, et al. Hereditary causes of kidney stones and chronic kidney
disease. Pediatr Nephrol. 2013;28(10):1923-1942. doi: http://dx.doi.org/10.1007/s00467-012-2329-z
 Moor MB, Bonny O. Ways of calcium reabsorption in the kidney. Am J Physiol Renal
Physiol. 2016;310(11):F1337-F1350. doi: http://dx.doi.org/10.1152/ajprenal.00273.2015
 Schell-Feith EA, Kist-van Holthe JE, van Zwieten PH, et al. Preterm neonates with nephrocalcinosis: natural
course and renal function. Pediatr Nephrol. 2003;18(11):1102-1108. doi: http://dx.doi.org/10.1007/s00467-003-
1235-9
