A 10-year-old girl with end-stage renal disease caused by juvenile nephronophthisis is scheduled for
a kidney transplant at your center in 2 days. She has a zero panel reactive antibody level. Her mother
is the projected donor: a 1-haplotype match with a negative cross-match. Your current transplant
protocol states that in this low-risk situation either rabbit antithymocyte globulin or basiliximab can be
used as induction therapy, followed by tacrolimus and mycophenolate as maintenance agents. The
mother has heard of an agent called belatacept being used in some adults. Your new transplant
coordinator relays this information and asks you how the different agents work.
Of the following, the MOST correct statement about mechanism of action of immunosuppressive
agents is
options: belatacept inhibits the CD40-CD40 ligand costimulatory pathway
daclizumab and basiliximab bind to the interleukin 2 receptor
mycophenolate and azathioprine bind to the CD52 receptor
tacrolimus and cyclosporine bind to the same intracellular binding protein
explanation:
B. daclizumab and basiliximab bind to the interleukin 2 receptor
The most correct statement about the mechanism of action of the immunosuppressive agents
mentioned in the vignette is that daclizumab and basiliximab bind to the interleukin 2 receptor.
Belatacept does not target the CD40–CD40 ligand pathway, mycophenolate and azathioprine do not
target the CD52 receptor, and cyclosporine and tacrolimus do not bind to the same binding protein.
Use of multiple agents with different targets allows for enhanced overall immunosuppressive potency
while limiting each agent’s individual toxicity. The original agents used were total body irradiation, 6-
mercaptopurine, and corticosteroids. Later agents are more focused on inhibiting the interaction
between the antigen-presenting cell and the T cell, typically the activation process of the CD4 T cell.
The agent 6-mercaptopurine, its later derivative azathioprine, and the unrelated agents
mycophenolate mofetil and mycophenolate sodium all act as anti–T-cell proliferative agents, inhibiting
DNA synthesis.
The calcineurin inhibitors cyclosporine and tacrolimus both act to inhibit a downstream molecule
calcineurin that eventually acts on the promoter region of the IL2 gene involved in T-cell activation.
However, they initially bind to different intracellular proteins (tacrolimus binds to FK-binding protein,
whereas cyclosporine binds to cyclophilin) before converging toward calcineurin. Conversely,
sirolimus initially binds to the same intracellular protein as tacrolimus, the FK-binding protein, but then
diverges to inhibit a separate pathway, known as the mammalian target of rapamycin (mTOR), which
then inhibits cell cycling.
Corticosteroids also inhibit IL2 gene activation by multiple mechanisms and are believed to have
additional undiscovered mechanisms of immunosuppressive action.
Starting with the development of antilymphocyte globulin at the University of Minnesota, several
biologic agents have been developed that target either multiple epitopes on immune cells (polyclonal
agents such as horse- or rabbit-derived antithymocyte globulins) or specific single epitopes on
immune cells (monoclonal agents such as the older OKT3 and more recent basiliximab, daclizumab,
and alemtuzumab). These agents are typically administered as prophylaxis in the early perioperative
period or as rescue agents in the treatment of rejection. Rituximab targets the CD20 receptor on the
B cell and can be used as prophylaxis or rescue therapy.
More recently, belatacept was developed as a costimulatory blockade agent, blocking the CD28-B7
pathway. Unlike other biologic injectables, this agent acts as a maintenance drug being administered
monthly. Drugs that target other costimulatory pathways, such as the CD40-CD40 ligand, have been
tried or are in development. Each drug and its target are shown in the Figure.

Figure: Mechanisms of action Courtesy of V. Dharnidharka
Many of these same drugs are also used in native kidney disease, especially in glomerular diseases
that are believed to have some component of immune dysregulation. Thus, cyclosporine, tacrolimus,
azathioprine, mycophenolate, mTOR inhibitors, corticosteroids, and rituximab have all been used in
one or more glomerular diseases. Cyclophosphamide, not mentioned previously, is another agent
that has been used in primary glomerular disease. It is an alkylating agent that binds to and cross-
links DNA, thus interfering with DNA replication.
PREP Pearls
 Transplant professionals use multiple immunosuppressive agents to suppress the immune rejection response.
 Use of multiple agents with different targets allows for enhanced overall immunosuppressive potency while
limiting each agent’s individual toxicity.
American Board of Pediatrics Content Specification(s)
 Know the mechanisms of action of immunosuppressive drugs used to treat kidney disease
Suggested Readings
 Sayegh, MH, Turka, LA.The role of T-cell costimulatory activation pathways in transplant rejection. N Engl J
Med. 1998;338(25):1813-1821. doi:http://dx.doi.org/10.1056/NEJM199806183382506

 van Gelder T, van Schaik RH, Hesselink DA. Pharmacogenetics and immunosuppressive drugs in solid organ
transplantation. Nat Rev Nephrol. 2014;10(12):725-731. doi: http://dx.doi.org/10.1038/nrneph.2014.172
 Wohlfahrtova M, Viklicky O. Recent trials in immunosuppression and their consequences for current
therapy. Curr Opin Organ Transplant. 2014;19(4):387-394.
doi: http://dx.doi.org/10.1097/MOT.0000000000000093

A 13-year-old girl with reflux nephropathy and stage 3 chronic kidney disease has a serum creatinine
level of 1.8 mg/dL (159 μmol/L) and an estimated glomerular filtration rate of 35 mL/min/1.73 m2. She
was prescribed calcitriol and calcium carbonate after which she missed a couple of clinic
appointments. Now she presents with recurrent abdominal pain, anxiety, headaches, fatigue,
weakness, and an unexplained weight loss of 2 kg during the last month with polyuria without
polydipsia. Her physical examination reveals mild dehydration, and her blood pressure, which was
previously normal, is now 140/90 mm Hg.
Serum biochemistry results are as follows: creatinine, 2.8 mg/dL (248 μmol/L); sodium, 138 mEq/L
(138 mmol/L); potassium, 3.8 mEq/L (3.8 mmol/L), bicarbonate, 25 mEq/L (25 mmol/L); chloride, 102
mEq/L (102 mmol/L); serum calcium, 12.3 mg/dL (3.08 mmol/L); phosphorus, 5.3 mg/dL (1.71
mmol/L); parathyroid hormone, 40 pg/mL (40 ng/L); alkaline phosphatase, 150 U/L (2.5 μkat/L);
albumin, 4.2 g/dL (42 g/L); 25-hydroxyvitamin D, 35 ng/mL (87 nmol/L); and 1,25-hydroxyvitamin D,
35 pg/mL (91 pmol/L). Renal ultrasonography did not reveal any significant new findings.
Of the following, which is the MOST likely cause of this patient’s symptoms and laboratory results?
options: complications from her phosphate binder therapy
nonadherence with her diet and medications
tertiary hyperparathyroidism
undiagnosed pyelonephritis, leading to further renal damage
explanation:
A. complications from her phosphate binder therapy
The most striking abnormality in the patient described in the vignette is the hypercalcemia and
increase in serum creatinine level from 1.8 to 2.8 mg/dL (159 to 248 μmol/L). The suppressed
parathyroid hormone with normal alkaline phosphatase and normal vitamin D levels render
autonomous hyperparathyroidism, paraneoplastic hypersecretion of parathyroid hormone–related
peptide, or granulomatous diseases unlikely as the cause of the hypercalcemia. It turned out that the
patient was taking calcium carbonate between meals. Calcium-containing phosphorus binders are
known to act as calcium supplements when they are not taken together with meals and may lead to
hypercalcemia. Combined with initiating calcitriol therapy, which enhances gastrointestinal absorption
of calcium, this aggravated her hypercalcemia.
Hypercalcemia is a common complication of calcium-containing phosphate binders, especially in
combination with vitamin D supplements. In addition, her vitamin D and parathyroid hormone levels
are in the reference range and will not lead to hypercalcemia. Nonadherence with her diet and
medications would likely lead to hypocalcemia and hyperphosphatemia. Although undiagnosed
pyelonephritis leading to further renal damage is unlikely, it could be a contributing factor and could
be asymptomatic but would not cause hypercalcemia.
Hypercalcemia causes multisystem disturbance and symptoms, which include the following.
Renal
The most important renal manifestations are polyuria, resulting from decreased concentrating ability
in the distal tubule, nephrolithiasis, and acute kidney injury. Long-standing hypercalcemia and
hypercalciuria may lead to calcification, degeneration, and necrosis of the tubular cells and eventual
tubular atrophy and interstitial fibrosis and calcification (nephrocalcinosis).
Gastrointestinal
Gastrointestinal symptoms, such as constipation, anorexia, and nausea, occur
commonly. Constipation may be related to decreased smooth muscle tone and/or abnormal
autonomic function. Pancreatitis and peptic ulcer disease occur less frequently than other
gastrointestinal symptoms. Proposed mechanisms for the development of pancreatitis include
deposition of calcium in the pancreatic duct and calcium activation of trypsinogen within the
pancreatic parenchyma.
Cardiovascular
Hypertension and cardiomyopathy can be complications of acute hypercalcemia. High serum calcium
can directly shorten the myocardial action potential, which is reflected in a shortened QT interval.
Although there does not appear to be any clinically important effect of moderate hypercalcemia on
cardiac conduction or the prevalence of supraventricular or ventricular arrhythmias in patients with
primary hyperparathyroidism, arrhythmia has been described in patients with severe hypercalcemia.
In addition, ST-segment elevation mimicking myocardial infarction has been reported in such patients.
Long-standing hypercalcemia, as occurs in primary hyperparathyroidism, can lead to other cardiac
abnormalities, including deposition of calcium in heart valves, coronary arteries and myocardial fibers,
hypertension, and cardiomyopathy.
Muscular

Profound muscle weakness was prominent in the original description of patients with primary
hyperparathyroidism. In one prospective study, for example, 9 patients were tested for neuromuscular
performance before and 4 weeks after parathyroid surgery. All had an increase in muscle strength
and improvement in fine motor movement, whereas there was no change in patients who did not
undergo surgery. Weakness can be an important feature of other causes of hypercalcemia, such as
malignant tumors, but this can be a manifestation of the underlying illness rather than from
hypercalcemia alone.
Neuropsychiatric
A number of mild neuropsychiatric disturbances have been associated with hypercalcemia, mostly in
patients with primary hyperparathyroidism with hypercalcemia. The most common symptoms have
been anxiety, depression, and cognitive dysfunction. Improvement in some or all of these symptoms
has been described after correction of the hypercalcemia.
PREP Pearls
 The most important renal manifestations of acute hypercalcemia are polyuria, resulting from decreased
concentrating ability in the distal tubule, nephrolithiasis, hypertension, and acute and acute on chronic renal
insufficiency.
 Long-standing hypercalcemia and hypercalciuria may lead to calcification, degeneration, and necrosis of the
tubular cells and eventual tubular atrophy and interstitial fibrosis and calcification (nephrocalcinosis).
American Board of Pediatrics Content Specification(s)
 Know the clinical manifestations of hypercalcemia
Suggested Readings
 Schiller LR, Santa Ana CA, Sheikh MS, Emmett M, Fordtran JS. Time of administration of calcium acetate on
phosphorus binding. N Engl J Med. 1989;320(7):1110-1113.
doi: http://dx.doi.org/10.1056/NEJM198904273201703
 Wesseling-Perry K, Salusky IB. Chronic kidney disease: mineral and bone disorder in children. Semin
Nephrol.2013;9(2):169-179. doi: http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.semnephrol.2012.12.017

stem:
Two of your patients with end-stage kidney disease (ESKD) undergo workup and are listed as active
status at the same time for deceased donor kidney transplant with the national Organ Procurement
and Transplant Network. Both children are 7 years old and have been receiving peritoneal dialysis for
1 year.
The first child is a girl who weighs 21 kg and has ESKD due to nephronophthisis, blood group A, and
a 5% panel reactive antibody level. She receives an organ offer and undergoes kidney transplant
within the first week of listing. The second child is a boy who weighs 18 kg and has ESKD due to
posterior urethral valves, an appendicovesicostomy, blood group B, and a 0% panel reactive antibody
level. However, he has not received any offers at 6 months after listing.
Of the following, the MOST likely reason for a longer waiting time for the second patient is
options: appendicovesicostomy
blood group B
girls get preference over boys
weight of less than 20 kg
explanation:
B. blood group B
For the male patient described in the vignette, the most likely reason for a longer waiting time for him
is his blood group B status. The male child weighs 18 kg so should easily accept any size kidney,
which is no different than for the 21-kg girl. Being a boy or having an appendicovesicostomy does not
affect the chance of a donor kidney offer. Finally, the deceased donor listing has an inherent
unpredictability, which can affect the timing of an offer.
The National Organ Transplant Act in 1984 established the creation of the Organ Procurement
Transplant Network (OPTN) in 1988 in the United States. The OPTN, set up by a private agency
under federal contract, then developed the following systems:
1. A national listing of deceased donor solid organs available for transplant (not just kidneys)
2. A national listing of people with end-stage organ failure, awaiting a deceased donor organ
transplant, known as candidate recipients
3. A national tissue typing and histocompatibility system to match the donor kidneys with the
candidate recipients
4. A national allocation system for each solid organ because the number of candidate recipients
exceeded the number of available deceased donor organs
5. A registry to track results of all solid organ transplants performed in the United States
For people with end-stage kidney disease, the options for renal replacement therapy include long-
term home or in-center dialysis or a living donor or deceased donor kidney transplant. Note that
OPTN does not facilitate living donor transplants, although it tracks the results of living donor
transplants. Once a transplant evaluation is complete, a candidate recipient can be listed with OPTN
for a deceased donor kidney. The listing can be under active or inactive (temporary or extended, as in
case of recent infection or immunization) status.
Under active status, a candidate recipient may receive an offer at anytime. This offer is made based
on (1) compatibility of donor and candidate blood groups; (2) a virtual tissue typing comparing the
HLA antigen profiles of each, which can also suggest (3) a likely negative crossmatch; and (4) the
priority score. Priority is assigned based on a number of factors, including antibody sensitization,
multiorgan need, and zero antigen mismatch. Children currently receive preference for the best-
quality kidneys, graded by a Kidney Donor Profile Index score.
Once the candidate has been called in for a potential transplant, donor cells are then mixed with
recipient serum in a laboratory crossmatch. The donor organ is usually being retrieved at this time.
A positive crossmatch result or damaged retrieved organ may lead to a cancellation of the transplant,
with the patient being put back on the waiting list.
At the time of this writing, the deceased donor waitlist far exceeds the actual organ supply
(https://optn.transplant.hrsa.gov). For adults, the average waiting time on the list is 3 to 4 years
(and can be longer in certain geographic areas). For children younger than 18 years at the time of
listing, the goal is to have the child receive a kidney transplant within 6 months of listing. Blood group
B is proportionately overrepresented on the deceased donor wait list compared with blood group A.
Thus, blood group B candidates have a longer average wait for a kidney transplant. In contrast, the
sex of the donor/candidate recipient or the primary kidney disease do not count in any way toward the
potential to receive an offer. Similarly, the need or not for a urologist at transplant surgery would not

count in terms of when a donor kidney offer might come. Note that the presence of an
appendicovesicostomy should not be construed as either a contraindication for receiving a donor
kidney offer or a need for a urologist being present at the time of the transplant surgery.
In the distant past, very small kidney candidate recipients (body weight <15 kg) would receive size-
matched kidneys from very young donors (also with body weight <15 kg), similar to the current
practice for heart, lung, and liver. However, this practice was discontinued in kidney transplants
because of the excessively high thrombosis rates in such pairings. The current practice in kidney is to
not size match because the kidney can be placed elsewhere in the abdomen and enough free space
exists in the abdomen to fit an adult kidney into a child longer than 65 cm or weighing more than 7.5
kg. A very young donor kidney (body weight <15 kg) would then be offered en bloc to an adult
candidate.
PREP Pearls
 The deceased donor list is a national system to list candidates awaiting a kidney transplant.
 The deceased donor list also matches the candidate with the donor organ.
American Board of Pediatrics Content Specification(s)
 Understand the concept of the deceased donor renal transplant waiting list
Suggested Readings
 Organ Procurement and Transplantation Network. Increasing Equity in Liver
Transplants. https://optn.transplant.hrsa.gov/. Accessed October 5, 2016

A neonatology colleague has approached you about data from a subset of patients from their
intensive care unit (ICU) in the past 5 years that they want to analyze. This data set includes prenatal
information, hospitalization, and clinic follow-up data for 80 patients. They have noted a large number
of patients being diagnosed with hypertension and wish to assess what factors may be associated
with its development. A resourceful neonatology fellow has been able to quickly sort through the data
and identified 20 of the patients who were diagnosed with hypertension at some point in time. You
asked her to analyze antenatal steroid exposure as a potential contributor to the development of
hypertension, and she has produced the following data table.
Hypertension Present Hypertension Not Present Total
Antenatal steroid 18 32 50
exposure present
Antenatal steroid 2 28 30
exposure absent
Total 20 60 80
Given this data set, the fellow asks you whether prenatal steroids are a risk factor for hypertension in
patients in the neonatal ICU.
Of the following, the MOST accurate response about that chance is that it is
options: 1.1 times higher
5.4 times higher
7.8 times higher
9.0 times higher
explanation:
C. 7.8 times higher
In the vignette, you are asked to estimate the chance of an exposure in patients with a disorder from
a subset of data given, in effect conducting a case-control analysis. The appropriate statistical
analysis would be the calculation of the odds ratio (OR) or the odds of exposure in cases compared
with the odds of exposure in controls. From the given vignette data, the odds of exposure in cases is
9.0 (18/2). The odds of exposure in controls is 1.14 (32/28). The ratio of these 2 odds values
(9.0/1.14 or ad/bc) is 7.8 or the OR and gives you the appropriate measure of association between
the exposure and the disorder of interest in case-control studies. If this data set were complete with
all the patients seen, then one may conduct a cohort or cross-sectional study and calculate the
degree of association using the relative risk (RR). That calculation would have yielded the value of
5.4 but is not the correct calculation to undertake for this type of study.
In the vignette, you are asked to assess the risk of a certain exposure (antenatal steroids) to the
occurrence of a disease (neonatal hypertension) as a means of estimating association between that
exposure and the disease in question. This can be measured in different ways, depending on the type
of study being conducted. In the described scenario, you are conducting a case-control study
because you have preliminarily identified those with the disease (hypertension) and are comparing
them with those without the disease to determine whether there are any factors (antenatal steroid
exposure) that may be associated with increased risk. This type of study contrasts with cohort
studies, in which the exposure is what is first identified and the development of a condition or disease
is then assessed, often over a protracted period. This study also contrasts with cross-sectional
studies, in which both the exposure and condition are assessed for at the same point in time.
Typically, the differences in these types of studies are clear based on the way they are conducted,
with case-control studies being conducted retrospectively often with few cases identified, cohort
studies often having the cohort identified first and followed up prospectively, and cross-sectional
studies being analyzed at one point in time. Although these differences seem subtle in context to the
data set that is given in this scenario, there is one great difference among these types of studies: the
known incidence of disease in the population being studied and, subsequently, in the type of
statistical analysis that can be performed. In a case-control study, the true incidence of the disease in
the population may be unknown. For example, this neonatal intensive care unit (NICU) may average
200 admissions a year, yet the given data set for 5 years contains information on only 80 patients.
Therefore, the true incidence of hypertension in this entire population is not known because the data
are not complete. However, this limitation does not restrict the utility of case-control study data. To
account for the unknown true incidence of disease in a case-control study, one must use an OR to
measure the association between exposure and outcome.
To clarify the concept of odds and OR, it may be easier to visualize things through the 2 × 2 table that
is often used in biostatistics (shown below)
Condition or Disease Present Condition or Disease Absent
Exposure present a b a + b
Exposure absent c d c + d
a + c b + d

where a represents those patients with both the disease and the exposure, b represents those
without disease but with the exposure, c represents those with the disease but without the exposure,
and d represents those without disease or exposure. Subsequently, a + c represents all who have
the disease or all the cases, whereas b + d would represent all those without the disease or the
controls; a + b represents all those exposed, whereas c + d represents all those not exposed.
The concept of odds is really a proportion of probabilities and is often easiest thought of in relation to
gambling or gaming. Let’s say that a certain amateur sports team is heavily favored to win a match,
with their probability of winning being 95%. The probability of them NOT winning would then be only
5%. The odds of them winning would be the proportion of these 2 probabilities:
Odds (Winning) = Probability of Winning/Probability of Not Winning = 95%/5% = 19 to 1
The difficulty in understanding odds is that the numerator (top number of the fraction) and the
denominator (bottom number) should reciprocate each other so that their sum is 100%, or 1 if using
decimals. This will help ensure that you are using the correct probabilities to calculate the odds of
what you are measuring.
For our given example, one may first ask what are the odds of being exposed (to antenatal steroids)
in individuals who have the disease or cases (NICU patients who develop hypertension). This would
be the probability of those developing hypertension with the exposure divided by the probability of
those with hypertension NOT having the exposure because we are looking at only those individuals
who developed hypertension. Mathematically, this would be expressed as follows:
In this particular vignette, the odds of receiving antenatal steroids if developing hypertension would be
18/20 divided by 2/20, simplified to 18/2 (a/c) or 9.0. This number is rather high but does not
represent the true risk of the exposure because most patients in this data set received the exposure
(50 of 80) possibly because they had other risk factors, such as prematurity or low birth weight, which
may also put them at risk for developing hypertension. This simply represents the odds of being
exposed only in those patients who have the disease.
To evaluate the full association of the exposure and the disease of interest, you must compare the
odds of exposure in cases, or those with the disease, with the odds of exposure in controls, or those
without the disease. This is the question being asked by the fellow, and it is answered by the OR,
also called the relative odds. The OR would be the ratio of the odds (disease given exposure) over
the odds (no disease given exposure). Mathematically, this would be expressed as
follows:
Simply applying the numbers given in this vignette, ad/bc would be 18 × 28/2 × 32 or 504/64, which is
just below 8, technically 7.8.
The generated values of an OR will always be a positive value but may be less than 1, close to 1, or
significantly higher than 1. An OR less than 1 means that the odds of exposure in cases are lower

than controls and the exposure may be protective of developing disease. An OR near 1 means that
the odds of exposure are nearly the same between cases and controls and, likely, the exposure is not
associated with the disease. An OR greater than 1 would mean that the exposure is greater among
cases and the exposure may be a risk factor for the disease.
In the vignette, the odds of exposure to antenatal steroids in those without hypertension would be
32/60 divided by 28/60, simplified to 32/28 (b/d) or approximately 1.14. This is greater than 1, so one
may jump to the conclusion that the exposure to steroids would technically also increase your
likelihood of NOT having hypertension. This is not the case because we are looking merely at the
odds, not the OR, of exposure in controls. The odds of exposure are high among controls and the
cases in this scenario because there is a very high percentage of all patients in the data set having
the exposure. However, regardless of the actual incidence of exposure, the OR may be used.
The OR may be used in other types of studies, although they are the only statistic used for case-
control studies, as well as being used in logistic regression. An OR may be calculated for cohort and
cross-sectional studies as well. In the vignette, if the data being collected were that of a total cohort
study, not a case-control study, then one would calculate the RR to answer the question of what
additional risk of developing hypertension does the receipt of antenatal steroids provide to infants in
the NICU. Using the same data from the 2 × 2 table would give us the following:
In this case, the RR of 5.4 does not equal the calculated an OR of 7.8 because the disease incidence
is not that rare.
Lastly, ORs are also used in logistic regression. The regression coefficient, often symbolized as b1 in
the regression formula, is the estimated increase in odds of developing the disease (although it is
raised exponentially or eb1) associated with a 1-unit increase in the exposure. For example, if you
were looking at the risk of hypertension developing based on grams of sodium in your diet and the
logistic regression yielded a regression coefficient value of 0.68, then someone consuming 4 g of
sodium would have an e0.68 (which calculates to 1.97) or almost twice the risk of developing
hypertension.
PREP Pearls
 The odds ratio, which is calculated from a 2 × 2 table as (a × d)/(b × c), is the appropriate statistic to use in
case-control studies.
 In cohort studies, the relative risk often may be approximated by the odds ratio when there is a very low
incidence of disease.
American Board of Pediatrics Content Specification(s)
 Calculate and interpret an odds ratio
Suggested Readings
 Gordis L. Estimating risk: is there an association? In: Epidemiology. 3rd ed. Philadelphia, PA: Elsevier-
Saunders; 2004:177-189.

 National Environmental Health Association. Calculating Measures of
Association. http://www.neha.org/sites/default/files/pd/edu-train/Calculating-Measures-
Association.pdf Accessed August 8, 2016
 Szumilas M. Explaining odds ratios. J Can Acad Child Adolesc Psychiatry. 2010;19(3): 227-229.

You are consulting on a 17-year-old girl with an elevated creatinine level. She has had chronic
problems with nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and constipation and has been prescribed a number of
dietary regimens for irritable bowel syndrome. She has had chronic burning of the hands and feet.
Her father had diabetes and chronic kidney disease. He had a history of a stroke at 30 years of age
and died at 45 years of age. Her paternal uncle was recently diagnosed with Fabry disease. On
examination her blood pressure and vital signs are normal. She has some nonblanching dark red
spots on her lower abdomen and one on her left palm. The remainder of her examination findings are
unremarkable. Her creatinine concentration gives her an estimated glomerular filtration rate of 78
mL/min/1.73 m². Her mother is concerned that she may have Fabry disease.
Of the following, the MOST accurate statement about Fabry disease is
options: Fabry disease is X-linked and does not occur in females
normal leukocyte α-galactosidase A enzyme activity would exclude the diagnosis of Fabry disease
therapy with enzyme replacement therapy is complicated by multiple reactions and is often not tolerated
therapy with enzyme replacement therapy may reduce pain episodes but has not been found to improve mortality in randomized studies
explanation:
D. therapy with enzyme replacement therapy may reduce pain episodes but has not been found to
improve mortality in randomized studies
Fabry disease is an X-linked lysosomal storage disorder that leads to accumulation of
globotriaosylceramide (GL3) and related glycolipids in multiple organs. It is caused by deficiency of α-
galactosidase A (GAL) attributable to mutations in the GLA gene. Reduced GAL activity is diagnostic
in males, but confirmatory genotyping is recommended. Because of skewing of X inactivation in
females, they may also develop Fabry disease. The median age of symptoms is 6 years in males and
9 years in affected females. The earliest reported signs and symptoms are listed in the Table.
Table Pediatric signs and symptoms of Fabry Disease
Some affected females may have nondiagnostic levels of blood GAL activity and require genotyping
for definitive diagnosis. Genotyping is important for prediction of disease severity and to help guide
decisions on when to consider enzyme replacement therapy. It is also the preferred modality for
screening family members.
The patient described in the vignette has signs (angiokeratomas and chronic kidney disease) and
symptoms (acroparesthesias and gastrointestinal issues) of Fabry disease with a positive family
history for Fabry disease. After she is confirmed by genotyping to have Fabry disease, the current
recommendations are that symptomatic females be considered for enzyme replacement therapy. In
women with Fabry disease, the rates of complications may be similar to men, especially for cardiac
disease. Cerebrovascular events, such as stroke, may even be more common.
Male patients may develop microalbuminuria or proteinuria as early as 7 years of age, and more than
half will have it by their middle 30s. End-stage kidney disease in males typically develops by 50 years
of age.
Enzyme therapy has been available for more than a dozen years. It consists of intravenous infusion
of galactosidase beta or galactosidase alfa (not available in the United States) enzyme. In

randomized trials of galactosidase beta or galactosidase alfa vs controls, there have been no
significant differences in the rate of death. Statistical improvement in pain scores has been
demonstrated vs placebo. In children, enzyme replacement therapy has been reported to improve
school performance, increase energy levels, and decrease pain. In addition to these quality-of-life
measures, clearance of GL3 from podocytes has been demonstrated with enzyme therapy. Stopping
therapy leads to renewed accumulation of GL3.
Overall, in trials between the 2 forms of enzyme therapy, there has been no difference in adverse
events. The enzyme infusions are generally well tolerated. There have been statistically significant
increases in rigors and fever with galactosidase beta compared with placebo. However,
premedication is not usually used for galactosidase alfa, whereas it is used for galactosidase beta
(antipyretic and/or antihistamine). The enzymes may be given by injection every 1 to 2 weeks;
however, the optimal regimen for dose and timing have not been defined.
In children, the complications of therapies may include the complications of weekly or every-other-
week infusions (venous access, school and social interruptions, and medicalization of the child). In
addition, there are some infusion-related reactions as mentioned above. Development of IgG
antibodies has been described against either enzyme, and 1 case of symptomatic IgE antibody
directed against galactosidase beta has been described in a highly atopic patient.
Other clinical evaluations would include electrocardiography, echocardiography, and formal
glomerular filtration rate assessment if available. Albuminuria may precede proteinuria, which should
also be checked at 6- to 12-month intervals. Other tools may include depression screening and pain
inventory questionnaires. Additional heart symptoms (irregular rhythm) may prompt Holter monitoring.
Additional central nervous system symptoms (suggestive of transient ischemic attacks) may prompt
magnetic resonance imaging. In this patient, her gastrointestinal symptoms would warrant evaluation
for non–Fabry disease–related causes of significant abdominal pain. In general, enzyme therapy
improves symptoms and slows disease progression in many systems but, as mentioned above, has
not yet had a significant effect on death rate.
PREP Pearls
 Therapy with enzyme replacement therapy may reduce pain episodes but has not been found to improve
mortality in randomized studies.
 Fabry disease is X-linked but also occurs in females.
American Board of Pediatrics Content Specification(s)
 Know the therapeutic options and complications of treatment for Fabry disease
Suggested Readings
 El Dib R, Gomaa H, Carvalho RP, et al. Enzyme replacement therapy for Anderson-Fabry disease. Cochrane
Database Syst Rev. 2016;7:CD006663. doi: http://dx.doi.org/10.1002/14651858.CD006663.pub4
 Ellaway C. Paediatric Fabry disease. Transl Pediatr. 2016;5(1):37-42. doi: http://dx.doi.org/10.3978/j.issn.2224-
4336.2015.12.02
 Schiffmann R, Fuller M, Clarke LA, Aerts JM. Is it Fabry disease? [published online May 19, 2016]. Genet Med.
doi: http://dx.doi.org/10.1038/gim.2016.55

You are seeing a 4-year-old boy for the first time regarding a family history of urolithiasis. The family
has been living overseas but is now establishing care at your center. There is a strong family history
of oxalate kidney stones, including the patient’s father and older sibling, but the 4-year-old has not
been diagnosed with urolithiasis to date. You discuss a general approach to prevention of urolithiasis
and interventions to diagnose and treat in the event of developing stones. You discuss the use of
computed tomography in making the diagnosis of urolithiasis, at which point the father states that he
and the older sibling had always had intravenous pyelography performed when they experienced any
colicky pain. He inquires about the benefits of intravenous pyelography, compared with computed
tomography, in the event that the 4-year-old starts to experience colicky pain.
In this given situation, the GREATEST advantage of intravenous pyelography over computed
tomography is
options: better detection of stones throughout the urinary tract
better enhancement of the renal parenchyma
less radiation exposure
use in patients with decreased renal function
explanation:
C. less radiation exposure
For the child described in the vignette, who may potentially require serial imaging because of the risk
of recurrent symptomatic nephrolithiasis, the advantages of using intravenous pyelography (IVP) is
that it delivers less overall radiation exposure compared with computed tomography (CT). It may also
provide better imaging of the upper urinary tract to assess intraluminal changes and degree of urinary
tract distention and tortuosity. However, IVP does NOT detect stones in the urinary tract better than
CT and, in fact, is worse in detecting stones in the lower ureters and ureterovesical junction. IVP also
does NOT provide superior imaging of the parenchyma because it very easily misses small (<3 cm)
masses and cannot make any distinguishment of areas without contrast uptake. Lastly, IVP use is
limited to patients who are able to receive intravenous contrast media, so it should NOT be performed
in individuals with significantly reduced renal function.
IVP, also more appropriately termed intravenous urography or excretory urography, was the primary
method of imaging the urinary tract for several decades before the advent of cross-sectional
imaging. Its use has largely been supplanted by ultrasonography, CT, and magnetic resonance
imaging (MRI) of the urinary tract in the United States, but IVP is still used in many other areas of the
world because of its relatively low cost and convenience. However, despite its diminished use, there
are still some indications for the use of IVP in place of these other imaging modalities (Table ).
Because IVP is used so infrequently in the United States, most physicians (both radiologists and
nephrologists) who were trained in the last 20 years are likely unfamiliar with proper test performance
and result interpretation so do not understand its utility, limitations, and contraindications. Basically,
an IVP is a sequence of X-rays of the abdomen immediately before and after the administration of
contrast media that is taken up and excreted by the kidneys, which allow for imaging of the kidneys,
ureters, and bladder. A preliminary image of the abdomen is performed before administration of any
contrast to check positioning and technique while also assessing for the presence of radiopaque
items, such as urinary calculi. Further images are then taken 1 to 3, 5, 10, and 15 minutes after the
administration of intravenous contrast. The first (1 to 3 minutes) postcontrast image is generally
centered on the expected location of the kidneys and provides an overall view of the kidney size,
shape, and functioning tissue, as the renal parenchyma takes up contrast. At 5 minutes after contrast
administration, contrast should then start to collect in the upper urinary tracts, allowing for an
evaluation of the renal calyces, pelvises, and upper ureters. This allows for an outline of the upper
urinary tract lumens, including any evidence of urinary tract dilation or absence of contrast within the
lumen from an obstruction. If there are no contraindications to abdominal compression, this is often
done between 5 and 10 minutes after contrast administration because this allows for optimal
distention and opacification of the ureters to provide greatest detail with the 10-minute postcontrast
images. Lastly, images performed 15 minutes after contrast administration should provide detailed
outline of the lower urinary tract and bladder. Therefore, IVP provides imaging of the entire upper
urinary tract to the bladder, with additional images taken from different angles (oblique, lateral, etc) or

different points in time, thus providing complete imaging of the intraluminal urinary tract. In addition,
IVP can provide information regarding urine transit over time, such as delayed excretion from renal
injury or obstruction that is not captured in the single moment in time of cross-sectional imaging.
The American College of Radiology cites the different indications of IVP, specifically noting its use in
the evaluation of suspected or known ureteral obstruction or the follow-up of patients with recurrent
renal or ureteral calculi. The former indication is because IVP can provide outstanding delineation of
not only the level at which there is obstruction but also the contour and degree of distention of the
urinary tract above the obstruction, which may be needed information for the intervening
surgeon. IVP, however, does not necessarily provide information on the cause of obstruction,
especially if it is from something extrinsically compressing the urinary tract rather than an intraluminal
blockage. In addition, because IVP relies on radiography for the detection of urolithiasis,
radiographically lucent stones may not be easily detected on IVP. Although the findings of
obstruction, if present, would be seen, the cause of obstruction may not be as apparent. A
comparison of noncontrast CT and IVP revealed that noncontrast CT had a higher detection rate of
any urinary tract stones (73% vs 51%) but especially greater detection when stones were present in
the distal ureter and ureterovesical junction. Therefore, IVP does NOT provide better detection of
stones throughout the urinary tract when compared with noncontrast CT.
The cited indication of IVP in the follow-up of patients with recurrent calculi is solely because of the
reduced patient radiation exposure when compared with CT. Noncontrast CT has a radiation dosage
(4.5 mSv) 3 times greater than standard IVP. Therefore, in patients likely to require multiple radiologic
procedures, such as those at high risk of recurrent renal calculi like the family members with oxalate
stone risk in the vignette, the use of IVP is preferred to reduce their lifetime exposure to radiation.
Another cited indication for IVP use includes situations in which cross-sectional imaging was thought
to place the patient at risk, such as intraoperative assessments in patients who are clinically unstable
for CT or MRI.
Other potential indications for IVP are dependent on the given reason for imaging. Because IVP can
provide greater information about the urinary collecting system, it may provide superior imaging of the
calyces and renal pelvis. Thus, it would be the preferred study if evaluating for sloughed renal
papillae, medullary sponge kidney, or transitional cell carcinoma. However, cross-sectional imaging,
specifically CT, outperforms IVP when assessing for abnormalities of the renal parenchyma. IVP
assesses only where the kidneys take up the contrast material, so it will show areas of intact
parenchyma. If an area of injured (or absent) parenchyma is small, it may not be detected easily by
IVP if the surrounding tissue is taking up contrast material. In fact, small renal masses (<3 cm in
diameter) can easily be missed on IVP, although they would be easily detected by other cross-
sectional imaging. In addition, IVP cannot tell you anything about the “abnormal” tissue in the kidney
that does not take up the contrast, for example, whether it is solid like a mass or fluid filled like a cyst,
only that it is an area devoid of working parenchyma, whereas cross-sectional imaging is able to give
more useful information about areas of abnormal findings.
IVP is only useful for imaging the urinary tract, so it has very little utility for detecting abnormalities
outside the urinary collecting system, whereas CT or MRI can detect abnormalities outside the urinary
collecting system. Therefore, IVP would not be recommended as first-choice imaging to evaluate less
specific symptoms, such as abdominal or back pain, where cross-sectional imaging would.
There are other limitations to using IVP besides its confined use to imaging of the urinary tract, which
may also restrict its utility. Because its images are contingent on the use of iodinated contrast media,
IVP may not be used in conditions in which the use of such media is contraindicated. This would
include restriction in individuals with known allergy to contrast medium or who have a strong history of
atopy or severe asthma because patients with these conditions have a higher likelihood of developing

severe allergic reactions to contrast. Patients with severe heart failure (including significant aortic
stenosis or pulmonary hypertension) should also avoid intravenous contrast media exposure because
the hyperosmolar fluid volume may not be tolerated. Patients with moderately decreased renal
function (glomerular filtration rate [GFR], 30-59 mL/min) and taking metformin should discontinue use
of their metformin use for more than 24 hours before receiving intravenous contrast because this
medication often can interact with the contrast to impair renal function. Similarly, patients with
severely decreased renal function (GFR, <30 mL/min) should not receive contrast media because of
the risk of further impairment from contrast nephropathy. In patients with these conditions, cross-
sectional imaging, such as noncontrast CT or MRI, may be preferred because images may still be
obtained without the use of contrast. In addition, there is a risk of extravasation of intravenous
contrast, similar to when being used for CT, and local skin breakdown.
Outside contraindications to receiving contrast media, the only other complications associated with
IVP use are related to performing abdominal compression during the study. Compression is intended
to distend the ureters by compressing them against the sacrum as they traverse across the ala.
Compression is not recommended in patients with evidence of urinary tract obstruction, recent
abdominal surgery, known urinary tract trauma, abdominal masses (such as aortic aneurysm), or
urinary diversions because the increased intra-abdominal pressure may cause further harm. In fact,
severe flank pain after applying compression may indicate rupture of a renal fornix. Lastly, pregnancy
is also considered a contraindication to having IVP performed because of both the risk of
compression and the exposure to radiation, even though at lower doses compared with CT.
PREP Pearls
 Intravenous pyelography, when properly performed, can provide a great deal of information about the kidneys,
ureter, and bladder. It can provide detailed imaging of the renal calyces, pelvis, and ureters and may be the
preferred imaging for papillary necrosis or medullary sponge kidney.
 Intravenous pyelography does not provide superior imaging of the renal parenchyma, compared with cross-
sectional imaging, and does not provide any imaging outside the renal collecting system, so its use should be
tailored toward very specific clinical questions.
American Board of Pediatrics Content Specification(s)
 Know the indications for and limitations and complications of intravenous pyelography
Suggested Readings
 American College of Radiology Practice Parameter for the Performance of Excretory
Urography. http://www.acr.org/~/media/795e1f28877844518b722e564a9a3de9.pdf. Accessed October 5, 2016
 Dyer RB, Chen MYM, Zagoria RJ. Intravenous urography technique and interpretation. Radiographics.
2001;21(4):799-824. doi: http://dx.doi.org/10.1148/radiographics.21.4.g01jl26799
 Whitfield AHN, Whitfield HN. Is there a role for the intravenous urogram in the 21st century? Ann R Coll Surg
Engl. 2006;88(1):62-65. doi: http://dx.doi.org/10.1308/003588406X83168

A 3-year-old boy with hemolytic uremic syndrome is referred to your hospital. At the outside hospital,
he was determined to be dehydrated and given 2 times maintenance intravenous fluids containing
potassium. When he is seen in your hospital, he is oliguric and edematous. Laboratory test results
are as follows: sodium, 128 mEq/L (128 mmol/L); potassium, 7.4 mEq/L (7.4 mmol/L); chloride, 90
mEq/L (90 mmol/L); bicarbonate, 13 mEq/L (13 mmol/L); urea nitrogen, 98 mg/dL (35.0 mmol/L);
creatinine, 4.8 mg/dL (424 μmol/L); calcium, 7.8 mg/dL (1.95 mmol/L); and phosphorus, 8.2 mg/dL
(2.65 mmol/L).
Of the following, the MOST likely clinical manifestation of the hyperkalemia is
options: hyperdynamic reflexes
muscle weakness
restlessness
tetany
explanation:
B. muscle weakness
Hyperkalemia is usually defined as a serum or plasma potassium level greater than 5.5 mEq/L (5.5
mmol/L). Although children are less likely to develop hyperkalemia than adults, pediatric
hyperkalemia is not an uncommon occurrence, and severe hyperkalemia (potassium level >7.0
mEq/L [>7.0 mmol/L]) is a serious medical problem that needs immediate attention.
Not all children with hyperkalemia will manifest electrocardiographic (ECG) changes, and the
absence of ECG change does not preclude the need for potential therapy for significant elevations in
potassium concentration. Hyperdynamic reflexes, restlessness, and tetany are not associated with
hyperkalemia.
The symptoms of hyperkalemia are variable. Most children are asymptomatic if they have mild (<6
mEq/L [<6 mmol/L]) or moderate elevations of potassium concentrations (6.0-7.0 mEq/L [6.0-7.0
mmol/L]). In these patients, hyperkalemia is typically detected when plasma or serum electrolytes are
obtained for monitoring or because electrolyte abnormalities are suspected. This typically occurs in
children with signs or symptoms of renal disease, such as hypertension; urinary abnormalities,
including hematuria and proteinuria, edema, and oliguria/anuria; significantly decreased effective
arterial blood flow, including shock, severe gastroenteritis, or heart failure; and trauma.
Children with severe hyperkalemia (potassium level >7 mEq/L [>7 mmol/L]) may have several clinical
manifestations. Muscle weakness or paralysis is usually ascending, beginning in the legs and
progressing to the trunk and arms, which can progress to flaccid paralysis. These findings may mimic
those seen in patients with Guillain-Barré syndrome. Children with significant hyperkalemia may have
symptoms of cardiac conduction abnormalities, including palpitations, syncope, or asystole,
depending on the severity of cardiac conduction disturbances.
Significant hyperkalemia is associated with potentially life-threatening disturbances in cardiac
conduction. ECG changes reflect the effect of increasing levels of serum and plasma potassium on
the electrical activity of the heart, including aberrant atrial (P wave) and ventricular (QRS complex)
depolarization and abnormal repolarization (T wave). These findings are based not only on the level
of extracellular potassium but also on how quickly the change in potassium level has occurred over
time. ECG changes that generally occur at a concentration greater than 7 mEq/L (>7 mmol/L) in
children with chronic hyperkalemia may be seen at lower levels in children with an acute rapid
increase in potassium concentration, resulting in a swift decrease in the transmembrane potassium
gradient. This may be seen in patients with tumor lysis or significant crush injury. In infants, ECG
changes are usually seen at greater levels of potassium because the reference range is higher in this
group of patients.
The following is the general range of serum and plasma potassium levels and the corresponding ECG
changes.
 5.5 to 6.5 mEq/L (5.5-6.5 mmol/L) and tall peaked T waves with a narrow base and shortening of the
QT interval as shown in waveform 1 below
 6.5 to 8.0 mEq/L (6.5-8.0 mmol/L) and peaked T waves, prolonged PR interval, decreased or
disappearing P wave, widening QRS complex, and amplified R wave as shown in waveform 2 below
 Greater than 8.0 mEq/L (>8.0 mmol/L) and absent P wave, bundle branch block, progressive widening
of QRS complex that eventually merges with the T wave to form a sinusoidal pattern followed by
ventricular fibrillation or asystole

PREP Pearls
 Physical finding of hyperkalemia are absent to mild if the potassium level is mildly elevated.
 Physical finding of hyperkalemia include ascending muscle weakness and paralysis.
 Cardiac arrhythmias can occur with hyperkalemia.
American Board of Pediatrics Content Specification(s)
 Know the clinical manifestations of hyperkalemia
Suggested Readings
 Kim M, Somers MJG. Fluid and electrolyte physiology and therapy. In: McMillan JA, DeAngelis CD, Feigin RD,
eds. Oski’s Pediatrics. 4th ed. Baltimore, MD: Lippincott Williams & Wilkins; Baltimore; 2006:54.
 Satin LM, Potassium. In: Avner ED, Harmon WE, Nauidet P, eds. Pediatric Nephrology. Baltimore, MD:
Williams & Wilkins; 2009:185-198.

You are consulting on a 2½-week-old female infant. She was admitted at 1 week of age for
dehydration and vomiting. Birth weight was 3.1 kg, and admission weight was 2.6 kg. The pregnancy
was uncomplicated. Her serum electrolytes revealed a potassium level of 7.8 mEq/L (7.8 mmol/L) in a
nonhemolyzed sample. Her serum sodium level is 126 mEq/L (126 mmol/L), bicarbonate level is 18
mEq/L (18 mmol/L), chloride level is 96 mEq/L (96 mmol/L), urea nitrogen level is 10 mg/dL (3.6
mmol/L), and creatinine level is 0.5 mg/dL (44 μmol/L). Results of renal ultrasonography are normal.
Physical examination findings and blood pressure are normal. She has been receiving intravenous
fluids (5% dextrose in half normal saline) and nasogastric feedings (total fluid, 175 mL/kg per day).
Hyperkalemia has persisted with a potassium range of 6.5 to 7.5 mEq/L (6.5-7.5 mmol/L) despite
volume and sodium administration. The aldosterone level from admission is 2,456 ng/dL (68,129
pmol/L) (reference ranges: adult standing, 4-31 ng/dL [111-860 pmol/L]; recumbent, 1-16 ng/dL [28-
444 pmol/L]).
Of the following, the BEST strategy for long-term management of this infant is
options: high-dose fludrocortisone and sodium bicarbonate
patiromer and sodium chloride supplementation
sodium polystyrene sulfonate and potassium citrate
sodium polystyrene sulfonate and sodium chloride supplementation
explanation:
D. sodium polystyrene sulfonate and sodium chloride supplementation
The patient described in the vignette is a newborn with persistently elevated potassium and extremely
high aldosterone levels that did not respond to volume expansion with saline. An elevated potassium
level at this age could be caused by congenital adrenal hyperplasia or an isolated deficiency in
aldosterone synthesis, but the high aldosterone level eliminates these possibilities. One of the
remaining possibilities is a form of pseudohypoaldosteronism (PHA).
There are 3 main types of PHA (Table ).
This patient has type I PHA. All patients with PHA have hyperkalemia, metabolic acidosis, and an
elevated blood aldosterone level. In PHA type I and type III, the patients lose sodium.
In this patient, the lack of ultrasonography findings makes a type III or secondary PHA unlikely. The
lack of hypertension and extremely elevated aldosterone level makes Gordon syndrome (PHA type II)
also unlikely.
In this patient, PHA type I could be the systemic form or a renal limited form. In the systemic form,
there can be complications of cholelithiasis, rashes, and lung disease related to reduced sodium-
dependent liquid absorption. These patients lose salt through their skin and may be diagnosed as
having PHA type I by a sweat test. The salt wasting can be quite severe and in some cases may
require up to 50 mEq/kg daily of sodium supplementation. The systemic form is caused
by SCNN1A, SCNN1B, or SCNN1G mutations in the epithelial sodium channel in an autosomal
recessive fashion. These patients require lifelong salt supplementation and may require symptomatic
therapy for respiratory tract illnesses and skin disease.
Renal limited forms cause milder sodium wasting and may require up to 20 mEq/kg per day of salt
supplementation. This is an autosomal dominant disease in the NR3C2 gene (mineralocorticoid
receptor). Fortunately, these patients improve with age and usually can be weaned off supplemental
sodium at approximately 2 years of age.
In addition to sodium supplementation, both the renal and systemic forms may require potassium-
binding resin and dietary modifications to reduce potassium dietary load. Sodium may be provided
predominantly as sodium chloride, but sodium bicarbonate may also be needed to correct the

acidosis. These patients often require tube feeding to facilitate administration of specialized feeds at
high volume.
Once the diagnosis is made with a high aldosterone level there is no role for mineralocorticoid
administration. Although the patient is acidotic, he also has hyperkalemia, and potassium citrate
would be contraindicated.
The traditional potassium-binding resin in use is sodium polystyrene sulfonate, which is approved by
the US Food and Drug Administration for hyperkalemia, but dosing in neonates has been associated
with necrotizing enterocolitis. Oral administration is contraindicated in neonates, especially those with
reduced gut motility (postoperatively or drug induced). Some centers may also use sodium
polystyrene sulfonate pretreatment of formula for ex vivo binding of potassium (with subsequent
decanting of treated formula from resin).
More recently, patiromer has been approved for hyperkalemia in adults. It is a cation exchange
polymer that contains a calcium-sorbitol anion. It may cause complications by binding some drugs
and has gastrointestinal issues similar to sodium polystyrene sulfonate. It would not be an appropriate
choice because there is no published pediatric experience. In addition, it is sodium free, and patients
with PHA type I taking patiromer would need more sodium supplementation than those taking sodium
polystyrene sulfonate.
Approximately half of the patients with rare antenatal Bartter syndrome have transient hyperkalemia
in the newborn period and also hyperaldosteronism. This condition usually follows a pregnancy
complicated by polyhydramnios, and the hyperkalemia usually begins to resolve after a week of age.
In addition, there is usually hypercalciuria and early nephrocalcinosis.
PREP Pearls
 The aldosterone level is the key to segregating the causes of hyperkalemia in the newborn.
 A sweat test can be used to differentiate systemic pseudohypoaldosteronism from renal limited
pseudohypoaldosteronism.
American Board of Pediatrics Content Specification(s)
 Know the treatment and the complications of treatment for pseudohypoaldosteronism type 1
Suggested Readings

distribution, and associated inherited diseases. Gene. 2016;579(2):95-132.

A 2-year-old girl is seen in her primary care physician’s office for her yearly checkup. The physician
notices that the patient’s height continues to be at the 50th percentile for her age, but her weight has
decreased from the 50th to the 5th percentile since her previous visit 6 months ago. Her family denies
any history that could explain the weight loss. Her vital signs and physical examination findings are
normal. Blood chemistry reveals the following: sodium, 140 mEq/L (140 mmol/L); potassium, 3.5
mEq/L (3.5 mmol/L); chloride, 115 mEq/L (115 mmol/L); bicarbonate, 15 mEq/L (15 mmol/L); urea
nitrogen, 9 mg/dL (3.2 mmol/L); creatinine, 0.3 mg/dL (27 μmol/L); glucose, 100 mg/dL (5.6 mmol/L);
and calcium, 9.5 mg/dL (2.38 mmol/L).
Of the following, which is the MOST likely diagnosis in this patient?
options: inborn error of metabolism
ingestion of ethylene glycol
renal tubular acidosis
salicylate poisoning
explanation:
C. renal tubular acidosis
For the patient described in the vignette, the most likely diagnosis is renal tubular acidosis (RTA)
because the patient has hyperchloremic non–anion gap (AG) acidosis. Ingestion of ethylene glycol,
lactic acidosis from an inborn error of metabolism, and salicylate poisoning are not the likely
diagnoses because each of these is associated with elevated AG metabolic acidosis. In addition,
each of these usually present with significant symptoms and not as growth failure noted during a well-
child visit.
Infants and children with metabolic acidosis can present with varying degrees of severity. Once
metabolic acidosis is diagnosed, the next step is to determine whether it is AG metabolic acidosis or
non-AG metabolic acidosis. The AG is calculated as the difference between the major cation sodium
(Na+) and the major measured anions (chlorine [Cl−] and bicarbonate [HCO −]):
3
AG = (Na+) − (Cl− + HCO −)
3
The normal mean (SD) AG is 12 (4). An elevated AG is generally due to an increase in unmeasured
anions, such as lactate, β-hydroxybutyrate, or metabolic products of some ingested poisons
(methanol, ethylene glycol) in the blood (further discussed below).
A low AG can be produced by a reduction in unmeasured anions, such as hypoalbuminemia, or an
increase in nonsodium cations, such as hyperkalemia, hypercalcemia, and/or hypermagnesemia.
Normal AG acidosis is caused by various forms of RTA or extrarenal losses of sodium bicarbonate,
such as gastrointestinal losses.
Occasionally, children will present with mixed metabolic acidosis (further discussed below).
Causes of High AG Metabolic Acidosis
High AG metabolic acidosis results from an increase in unmeasured anions, resulting in hydrogen ion
accumulation in the blood. In children, an AG above 14 to 16 mEq/L (14-16 mmol/L) is considered
elevated. The important causes of high AG metabolic acidosis in children are listed in Figure 1.

The most common cause of ketoacidosis in children is diabetic ketoacidosis, which results from
accumulation of acetoacetic acid and β-hydroxybutyric acid. Other causes include starvation or
ethanol abuse in adults.
Lactic acidosis may result from hypoperfusion due to sepsis, cardiac failure, or severe hypovolemia,
as well as other causes. Lactic acidosis may occur in neonates with perinatal hypoxemia and
ischemia. Lactic acidosis can occur is some inborn errors of metabolism, particularly mitochondrial
disorders.
Uremia is associated with retention of both hydrogen ions and unmeasured anions, such as sulfate,
phosphate, and urate, which result in increased AG acidosis.
Ingestion of toxic materials, such as ethylene glycol, methanol, or salicylate poisoning, is a cause of
high AG acidosis. These substances are converted to metabolic anions that increase the AG;
methanol is converted to formate acid, ethylene glycol is converted to glycolate and oxalic acids, and
salicylate is converted to ketones and lactic acid.
Increased AG acidosis can be caused by overproduction of organic acids due to inborn errors of
metabolism of amino acids, carbohydrates, or fatty acids. As described above, lactic acidosis can
also result from some inborn errors of metabolism.
Causes of Normal AG Metabolic Acidosis

Metabolic acidosis with a normal AG is caused by a loss of HCO − or impaired renal excretion of H+ in
3
the absence of renal failure. In patients with HCO − loss, the kidneys increase Cl− retention in a direct
3
milliequivalent for milliequivalent exchange to compensate for HCO − loss to maintain
3
electroneutrality. Consequently, hyperchloremia is a hallmark finding of normal AG metabolic
acidosis, which is also referred to as hyperchloremic normal AG metabolic acidosis.
Pediatric causes of normal hyperchloremic AG metabolic acidosis include gastrointestinal losses, with
diarrhea being the most common cause. Other less common pediatric causes of gastrointestinal
HCO − loss include enteric fistulae, enterostomies, and chronic laxative loss.
3
RTA in also a common cause of a normal anion gap acidosis. There are 3 major types of RTA. RTA
type I, also call distal RTA, is caused by a defect in net acid excretion. RTA type II, also called
proximal RTA, is caused by a lower renal threshold for bicarbonate reabsorption. RTA type IV, also
called hyperkalemic RTA, is caused by selective aldosterone deficiency or resistance (Figure 2).
Mixed Causes of Metabolic Acidosis
Mixed disorders occur when there are simultaneous causes of normal and high AG metabolic
acidosis in the same patient. These disorders are often difficult to diagnose and differentiate from
high AG metabolic acidosis because both have an elevated AG. The most common pediatric example
of a mixed disorder is severe diarrhea (normal AG with a low HCO −) accompanied by lactic acidosis
3
(high AG) due to hypoperfusion, resulting from hypovolemia caused by severe gastrointestinal fluid
loss.

PREP Pearls
 Metabolic acidosis has many causes, and once the anion gap is determined, the cause can be further
investigated.
 Non–anion gap metabolic acidosis is usually caused by extrarenal losses of bicarbonate or renal tubular
acidosis.
 Anion gap acidosis is usually caused by lactic acidosis due to multiple causes, including uremia; diabetic
ketoacidosis; ingestion of ethylene glycol, methanol, or salicylate; or inborn errors of metabolism.
American Board of Pediatrics Content Specification(s)
 Know the causes of a metabolic acidosis
Suggested Readings
 Emmett M, Narins RG. Clinical use of the anion gap. Medicine (Baltimore). 1977;56:38-54.
 Gabow PA, Kaehny WD, Fennessey PV, et al. Diagnostic importance of an increased serum anion gap. N Engl
J Med.1980;303:854-858. doi: http://dx.doi.org/10.1056/NEJM198010093031505
 Kraut JA, Madias NE. Metabolic acidosis: pathophysiology, diagnosis and management. Nat Rev
Nephrol.2010;6:274-285. doi: http://dx.doi.org/10.1038/nrneph.2010.33

A 5-year-old, North American, white boy presents with nephrotic syndrome. He has proteinuria (4+) in
his urine without blood. On physical examination, he has periorbital and ankle edema and a blood
pressure of 90/60 mm Hg. Family history is negative for kidney disease, and the parents are not
related. His parents want to know about the role of genetic testing in this patient.
Of the following, which is the MOST appropriate strategy for genetic testing in this patient?
options: test for podocin mutation
no genetic testing at this time
order a 40-gene panel for nephrotic syndrome
order whole-exome sequencing
explanation:
B. no genetic testing at this time
The patient described in the vignette has new-onset nephrotic syndrome without a family history,
hematuria, or hypertension. At 5 years of age, he has an 85% to 90% chance of having steroid-
sensitive nephrotic syndrome and should commence empiric steroid therapy to induce remission and
prevent complications of untreated nephrotic syndrome.
If he proves to be steroid resistant, his chance of having a monogenic cause of nephrotic syndrome
would be predicted to be between 5% and 30%. The former estimate represents a patient of this age
with nonfamilial nephrotic syndrome and typical nonconsanguineous North American mixed white
ancestry. The latter estimate would represent younger patients (especially those with congenital
nephrotic syndrome) or those with family history and/or consanguineous parents.
The known genetic causes of steroid-resistant nephrotic syndrome at this time are listed in Table 1.

Some of these mutations have only been described in 1 or 2 families. Different mutations are more
common at different ages (Table 2).

Aside from the WT1 gene, mutations in genes causing autosomal dominant nephrotic syndrome
become more common in young adulthood. The most common genetic cause of nephrotic syndrome
in young adults is INF; less commonly it is caused by TRPC6 and LMX1B mutations.
Importantly, some forms of hereditary focal segmental glomerulosclerosis are associated with
extrarenal manifestations (Table 3).

Whole-exome sequencing provides information on the more than 20,000 genes in the human
genome. This large amount information must be analyzed to identify potentially causal mutations in
genes known to cause nephrotic syndrome. In addition, it generates a lot of information about genes
not known to cause nephrotic syndrome. A gene panel is platform to perform sequencing on a limited
number of genes, usually up to 30. In either case, the technology has progressed so that analysis of
the data is the challenge. The optimal filtering strategy to identify pathologic variants has not yet been
identified. In addition, the background prevalence of variants in the population needs to be accounted
for in the filter. For example, a typical filter actually detected higher rate of variants in healthy subjects
in a reference population when compared with a cohort of patients with nephrotic syndrome.

In addition to the above-mentioned genes, there are risk alleles in the APOL1 gene. These risk alleles
(G1 and G2) in the last exon of the APOL1 gene are found in patients of West African descent. They
are thought to confer resistance to Trypanosoma brucei infection. If 2 risk alleles are inherited, they
confer a 10- to 20-fold increased risk of focal segmental glomerulosclerosis. The mechanism of this is
unclear. The presence of these risk alleles in the African American community is thought to confer
much of the excess risk of end-stage kidney disease in this community. Up to 70% of African
American children with focal segmental glomerulosclerosis have a high-risk APOL1 genotype in some
studies.
PREP Pearls
 Monogenic causes of nephrotic syndrome are relatively rare in steroid-resistant nephrotic syndrome in school-
age children without consanguineous parents or a family history.

 Know the genetic basis of the hereditary forms of focal segmental glomerulosclerosis

nephrotic syndrome diagnosis in a case cohort. J Am Soc Nephrol. 2016;27(7):1970-1983.

You are consulting on a 6-month-old infant with poor growth and elevated serum creatinine levels.
Renal ultrasonography revealed bilaterally small kidneys for age. The infant was recently diagnosed
with deafness. Comparative genomic hybridization detected a microdeletion in chromosome 14,
which contains the SIX1 gene. You diagnose the patient with branchio-oto-renal syndrome.
Which of the following metanephric compartments is the MOST likely affected by the absence
of SIX1 function?
options: cap mesenchyme
microvasculature
stroma
ureteric bud
explanation:
A. cap mesenchyme
The infant described in the vignette has bilateral renal hypoplasia associated with deafness and
chromosomal microdeletion that encompasses the SIX1 gene, a homeobox transcription factor that is
required for the DNA-binding activity of the EYA1 protein. EYA1 loss-of-function causes branchio-oto-
renal syndrome.
The metanephric kidney develops from reciprocal and iterative interactions between 2 cell lineages in
the posterior intermediate mesoderm called the ureteric bud (UB) and metanephric mesenchyme
(MM). Nephrogenesis begins when each UB branch tip induces the surrounding MM to condense and
form a crescent-shaped compartment called the cap mesenchyme (CM). The CM, made up of 4 to 5
layers of mesenchymal cells, the surrounding stroma (primitive interstitial cells), and the UB tip
compartments make up the so-called nephrogenic niche (Figure 1 ).

Figure 1: Compartments of the nephrogenic niche

The CM itself is divided into subcompartments, each identified by specific and shared molecular
markers. The subcompartment lying directly on top of the UB tip and beneath the stroma houses the
self-renewing nephron progenitor cells (NPCs), a group of undifferentiated stem-like cells
expressing Cited1, Eya1, and Six2 in mice and SIX1 and EYA1 in humans. Lineage tracing in mice
has revealed that Cited1+/Six2+NPCs give rise to all segments of the epithelial nephron from the
glomerulus to the connecting tubule. Cited1+/Six2+NPCs are resistant to inducing factors, which allows
them to undergo about 4 cell divisions throughout their lifetime under the influence of growth factors,
such as fibroblast growth factors 9 and 20. Transition from the Cited1+/Six2+to Cited1−/Six2+state
renders the NPCs sensitive to inductive signals and is presumably mediated by activation of bone
morphogenetic protein 7–SMAD signaling. For currently unknown but intensively investigated
reasons, NPCs are short-lived, and all NPCs differentiate en mass at the end of gestation (34 weeks
in humans and postnatal day 2-4 in mice), leading to their depletion and cessation of nephrogenesis.
The patient in the vignette has a loss-of function mutation in SIX1, which is expressed specifically in
the CM. Consequently, loss of SIX1/EYA1 function results in depletion of NPCs, premature cessation
of nephrogenesis, and reduced nephron endowment (ie, renal hypoplasia)
The stromal compartment, lying underneath the renal capsule rostral to the CM and surrounding the
nascent nephrons, is called the cortical stroma and expresses the transcription factor Foxd1. Fate
mapping in mice has revealed that Foxd1-lineage cells give rise to interstitial fibroblasts, pericytes,
arteriolar vascular smooth muscle cells, juxtaglomerular renin-expressing cells, and mesangial cells.
The cortical stroma in contact with the CM appears to restrain NPC renewal and promote their
differentiation into nascent nephrons via direct contact and by releasing soluble factors. The
medullary stroma expresses low levels of Foxd1 but high levels of another transcription factor called
Meis1. The fate of the medullary stroma is not well understood but likely gives rise to pericytes
surrounding the peritubular capillaries in response to inductive signals from the adjacent ureteric bud
epithelium.
Finally, the UB tip compartment is composed of progenitor cells that express the c-Ret proto-
oncogene. Lineage tracing revealed that UB tip cells are the progenitors of all cell types of the
collecting duct.
PREP Pearls
 The developing kidney is a complex organ composed of multiple interconnecting compartments.
 The nephrogenic niche is composed of 3 major compartments: the cap mesenchyme, cortical stroma, and
ureteric bud tip.
 Lineage analysis has revealed that the cap mesenchyme gives rise to the epithelial nephron, the ureteric bud
tip to the collecting ducts, and the stroma to the interstitium, pericytes, vascular smooth muscle, renin cells,
and mesangium.
American Board of Pediatrics Content Specification(s)
 Understand the compartmental development of the kidney
Suggested Readings
 Carroll TJ, Das A. Defining the signals that constitute the nephron progenitor niche. J Am Soc Nephrol.
2013;24(6):873-876. doi: http://dx.doi.org/10.1681/ASN.2012090931
 Thiagarajan RD, Georgas KM, Rumballe BA, et al. Identification of anchor genes during kidney development
defines ontological relationships, molecular subcompartments and regulatory pathways. PLoS
One.2011;6(2):e17286. doi: http://dx.doi.org/10.1371/journal.pone.0017286

 Yu J, Valerius MT, Duah M, et al. Identification of molecular compartments and genetic circuitry in the
developing mammalian kidney. Development. 2012;139(10):1863-1873.
doi: http://dx.doi.org/10.1242/dev.074005
