A 9-year-old girl is being seen for the first time for proteinuria that was confirmed by the pediatrician
on a first morning void specimen. The mother states that she has always been concerned about her
daughter’s weight gain. The family history is negative for known kidney diseases. Her father has a
history of multiple joint dislocations as a child and was excluded from competitive sports. Similarly,
the daughter has also been kept from participating in sports because she is “just like her father.”
On examination, the child is lean, with a height in the 50th percentile for age but weight only in the
20th percentile. Blood pressure is normal. She has limited extension of her knees, elbows, and some
fingers. Her mother also points out that her dorsal fingers are smooth and her fingernails have small
triangles at their base “just like her father.” Her urinalysis in clinic reveals isolated proteinuria (2+) and
an elevated spot urine protein-creatinine ratio of 0.5. Her serum creatinine and albumin levels are
normal.
Of the following, which is TRUE of the renal disease in this patient?
options: immunosuppression will help preserve renal function
proteinuria will persist but the renal function will be preserved because she is only a carrier of this genetic condition
proteinuria will progress over time with deterioration of renal function
risk factors for deterioration in renal function are not well known, and defining prognosis is difficult
explanation:
D. risk factors for deterioration in renal function are not well known, and defining prognosis is difficult
The child described in the vignette and her father have nail-patella syndrome (NPS), which is
an autosomal dominant condition. Therefore, the daughter is not a mere carrier of the condition but
clearly has the disorder. In addition, the nephropathy is not responsive to immunosuppressive
medications. The risk factors for progression of nephropathy are unknown. Only a few patients with
nephropathy progress to end-stage kidney disease. As frustrating as it may be for the family and the
physician, our current understanding of NPS nephropathy does not allow for us to make valid
predictions of who may or may not progress with their kidney disease. Therefore, risk factors for
deterioration in renal function are not well known, and defining prognosis is difficult. Recent findings
that certain mutations of LMX1B may be at higher risk of more severe nephropathy may allow for
better prognostication based on genetic risk, but without knowing the actual pathogenetic mechanism
of the kidney disease, it is extremely difficult to study the factors that may influence disease
severity.
The distinctive physical features described in this vignette include abnormalities of the nails, skeleton,
and joints with a hereditary pattern that fits the description of NPS. This disorder has also been called
Fong disease, Turner-Keiser syndrome, and Osterreicher-Turner syndrome but is probably best
referred to as hereditary osteo-onychodysplasia because it describes the classic physical findings
and intimates to the genetic heritability of this disorder. The pattern of autosomal dominant heritability
of NPS was first described in the Lancet in the Victorian era, back in 1897, and it was one of the first
disorders in which a linkage relationship was established with the ABO blood group in the 1950s. This
aided identification of the related gene, LMX1B, on the long arm of chromosome 9 (q34) with this
disorder. However, there remain large gaps in our understanding of determinants of this disease in
humans.
The LMX1B geneencodes a transcription factor that had been previously associated with dorsoventral
limb patterning in other species, such as the chicken and mouse, so its human ortholog reflects
dysplasia of structures derived from the dorsal mesenchyme. The classic tetrad of findings associated
with NPS is abnormalities of the nails, patella, and elbows along with iliac horns. Nail changes have
been reported in 98% of patients with NPS but may vary greatly in degree of subtlety of changes.
Triangular lunules of the nails, as described in this vignette, were seen in 88% of patients with NPS in
the largest phenotype study to date. More overt findings, such as nail hypoplasia or dysplasia, may
also occur, but involvement of the distal interphalangeal joint with skin changes or reduced range of
motion may be more prevalent. Recurrent subluxation of the patella or the radial head at the elbow
may also be seen because of hypoplasia of these bones. Iliac horns, which project posteriorly and
laterally from the central part of the iliac bones, are pathognomonic of NPS, although reported as
present in 68% of individuals in the large phenotype study. The Table contains a list of major
extrarenal features seen in NPS.

Antecubital pterygia

Iliac horns (68%) Painless projections from the central part of the iliac bones,
sometimes palpable
Other findings Feet: Pes planus (64%), Talipes (19%)
Back: Back pain (55%), lordosis (47%), scoliosis (23%)
Chest: Pectus excavatum (36%)
Gastrointestinal: Irritable bowel syndrome (13%), significant
constipation (18%)
Eye: Open angle glaucoma (10%) and ocular hypertension
(7%), but higher if older than 40 years, cloverleaf-shaped
Hyperpigmentation around the iris or Lester sign (54%)
Nervous system: peripheral neuropathic symptoms (up to
28%), epilepsy (6%)
Although not part of the defining tetrad for the disorder, the association of renal disease with NPS has
been documented for nearly 70 years. The most common finding of nephropathy in NPS is
proteinuria, with some patients, but not all, also having hematuria. On kidney biopsy, patients with
NPS nephropathy are likely to have normal-appearing glomeruli on light microscopy, although some
degree of glomerular sclerosis may also be seen. However, electron microscopy should reveal
irregular glomerular basement membrane (GBM) thickening with bundles of type III collagen fibers
deposited in the lamina densa, giving a moth-eaten (lucent) appearance to the GBM. There may also
be subsequent podocyte foot process effacement. Immunofluorescence results are typically negative,
or there may be nonspecific staining for IgM or C3.
With the irregularities to the GBM, NPS was once thought related to Alport syndrome; however, the
glomeruli in patients with NPS stain normally for α - and α - chains of type IV collagen. NPS should
3 4
also be distinguished from collagen type III glomerulopathy, another hereditary disorder (although
autosomal recessive) without extrarenal features, that notably has type III collagen deposition in the
subendothelial space in addition to the GBM, whereas NPS does not.
Although LMX1B gene mutations have been identified with NPS for more than 20 years, the exact
mechanism for how these mutations cause nephropathy in humans has still not been
elucidated. LMX1B has an important role in kidney development and maintenance of podocytes,
being expressed in podocytes prenatally as early as the S-shaped body stage into postnatal
life. LMX1B-null mice have reduced glomerular expression of α - and α - chains of type IV collagen,
3 4
somewhat similar to what may be expected in Alport syndrome. However, this has not been seen in
humans with NPS, making it difficult to know whether it is regulation of type IV collagen or other

abnormal gene transcription that causes the renal disease. Inducible deletion of LMX1B in fully
differentiated murine podocytes causes dysregulation of the actin cytoskeleton and proteinuria, so it
has been speculated that changes to the proteins composing the slit diaphragm are also likely
affected. Recently, a specified mutation of LMX1B (R246) was associated with altered expression of
CD2AP and podocin (NPHS2) within the podocytes of some individuals with NPS, but this had not
been seen previously in patients with NPS, perhaps because these individuals had different
mutations than at R246. The differences found between the animal models of disease and those
individuals with NPS have been one of the obstacles to fully understanding this disorder. Adding to
the consternation surrounding this disease are recent reports of patients with LMX1B mutations and
kidney disease but no extrarenal manifestations.
The lack of uniformity of kidney disease in NPS has equally been confounding to understand this
disorder. The clinical findings of nephropathy are not seen in all patients with NPS. Estimates of the
incidence of proteinuria generally range from 20% to 60%. The largest phenotype study to date
reported an overall incidence of proteinuria as 37.5%, but this decreased to only 25% when they
excluded women with NPS who were only proteinuric while pregnant. The progression of proteinuria
and decline in renal function can also be inconstant. There is variability in the degree of nephropathy
reported within kindreds, with children having nephrotic-range proteinuria, whereas the affected
parent has very mild, if any, detectable proteinuria. Patients with NPS nephropathy have an
accelerated loss of filtration function as they age when compared with individuals with NPS but
without nephropathy. However, the progression to end-stage kidney disease has been reported to be
only 5% to 10% of those with NPS nephropathy, constituting only a few affected patients.
There have been no general identifiable clinical factors to predict which patients with NPS will
develop proteinuria or end-stage kidney disease to date. Studies have found that the NPS allele of
the affected parent, but not the specific mutation, can affect the severity of nail dysplasia in offspring,
but there have been no large-scale associations made in regard to the presence of nephropathy or
degree of proteinuria. A few recent studies of patients with a mutation of LMX1B at R246 have
indicated that these individuals seem to develop chronic kidney disease and fare more poorly than
other NPS mutations. It has been speculated that mutations within the homeodomain of LMX1B, like
R246, also seem to have higher rates of nephropathy.
The treatment of NPS nephropathy is based off the premise that the progression of chronic kidney
disease is slowed by minimizing the degree of proteinuria, as seen in other renal disorders. However,
no studies in NPS have found that antiproteinuric therapy, such as angiotensin-converting enzyme
inhibitors or angiotensin II receptor blockers, have proven benefit in this disorder. Hypertension is
uncommon in NPS nephropathy. Because this is a congenital disorder of the GBM, like Alport
syndrome, modulation of the immune system is unlikely to have any effect on the proteinuria.
PREP Pearls
 The nephropathy of nail-patella syndrome (NPS) typically presents with asymptomatic proteinuria. Therefore,
this disorder should be considered in patients with asymptomatic proteinuria who have additional skeletal or
nail abnormalities. However, the skeletal and nail abnormalities of NPS are not always overt and may require
some investigation.
 The recommended treatment of the nephropathy of NPS is with antiproteinuric agents that affect the renin-
angiotensin system, but this is based on therapeutic efficacy in other proteinuric disorders and has not yet
been studied for efficacy in this particular disorder.

American Board of Pediatrics Content Specification(s)
 Know the natural history and epidemiology of nail-patella syndrome

syndrome to isolated nephropathy [published online July 23, 2015]. Pediatr
Nephrol. doi: http://dx.doi.org/10.1007/ s00467-016-3462

A 3-year-old boy was referred to you for evaluation of polyuria and small kidneys on renal ultrasound
examination. He was born at term, and his birth weight was 2.9 kg. The results of review of maternal
records during pregnancy were remarkable for gestational diabetes and mild hypertension treated
with hydralazine. The mother received 2 courses of amoxicillin and 1 injection of ceftriaxone for
bronchitis during the second trimester of pregnancy. She smoked 5 cigarettes per day during
pregnancy but did not consume alcohol. She described her dietary habits as poor. In addition to the
known effects of maternal hyperglycemia on renal development, you consider environmental fetal
exposures.
Of the following, which prenatal exposure is MOST compatible with normal nephrogenesis?
options: aminopenicillins
ceftriaxone
hydralazine
vitamin A deficiency
explanation:
C. hydralazine
Gestational exposure of the maternal-fetal unit to certain environmental factors may be detrimental to
renal organogenesis. Some nutritional factors, such as maternal vitamin A level, have been
postulated to mediate the variations in nephron number found in the population. The child described
in the vignette was discovered to have small kidneys, a surrogate for low nephron endowment, during
evaluation of polyuria, a common clinical manifestation of renal hypoplasia.
Experimental studies in animals have illustrated the effects of maternal factors on the fetus, newborn,
and adult. These effects include nutritional deficiency, pharmacologic agents, and placental
insufficiency. The case in the vignette illustrates the coexistence of many environmental factors, such
as placental insufficiency (maternal diabetes and hypertension), poor nutrition, and exposure to
drugs. Because nephrogenesis ends by 34 to 36 weeks of gestation, nephron regeneration
postnatally is not possible. Accordingly, obtaining a detailed maternal history is crucial when
evaluating the child and adult with renal and cardiovascular disease.
Maternal perturbations tend to have critical windows during which the effect of the environmental
stressor is believed to be most damaging to fetal organogenesis. Epidemiologic studies of the Dutch
winter famine suggest that maternal undernutrition during the first trimester of pregnancy is
associated with increased incidence of adult obesity and cardiovascular disease. On the other hand,
maternal undernutrition during the second trimester is more associated with renal dysfunction in the
offspring, whereas maternal undernutrition late in gestation results in infants with low birth weight.
Several animal studies have found that even a mild degree of maternal vitamin A deficiency, causing
50% reduction in circulating vitamin A in the fetus, is sufficient to induce a 25% reduction in nephron
numbers. Interestingly, giving vitamin A to protein-deprived pregnant rats at midgestation prevented
the nephron deficit observed in the growth retarded pups. Vitamin A acts via stimulating c-Ret gene
expression in the ureteric bud tips, thus enhancing ureteric bud–branching morphogenesis. Vitamin A
also acts by maintaining the integrity of the renal vascular network in the developing kidney.
Impaired renal organogenesis occurs with increased frequency in the offspring of diabetic mothers in
humans and animals and in metanephric kidneys cultured in the presence of elevated d-glucose
concentrations in the medium. Hyperglycemia appears to negatively affect the survival of the
metanephric mesenchyme and to impair ureteric bud branching.
A defect in ureteric bud branching is the principal cause of aminoglycoside-induced oligonephronia.
β-Lactam antibiotics, which are commonly prescribed during pregnancy, have also been implicated in
causing nephron deficits. The aminopenicillins, ampicillin and amoxicillin, cause nephron deficit in
vitro and in vivo at a dosage normally used in clinical practice. Unlike aminoglycoside, the penicillins
affect renal development by enhancing apoptosis in the metanephric mesenchyme, suggesting that
the 2 nephric lineages (metanephric mesenchyme and ureteric bud) are differentially susceptible to
environmental insults. Interestingly, ceftriaxone, a third-generation cephalosporin, has a minor effect
on nephrogenesis compared with other β-lactams. Calcineurin inhibitors, such as cyclosporine, also
affect nephrogenesis in vitro. Inhibitors of the renin-angiotensin and prostaglandin systems are
contraindicated during pregnancy. Angiotensin II is required for fetal renal vasculogenesis, whereas
prostaglandins are required for the patency of ductus arteriosus and maintenance of fetal renal blood
flow. Unlike the drugs listed above, hydralazine, a direct vasodilator, used extensively to treat
gestational hypertension, has no reported effect on fetal organogenesis.
PREP Pearls
 Multiple environmental factors often coexist during pregnancy that may affect renal organogenesis.

 Environmental events tend to have critical windows of opportunity to exert the negative effects on
nephrogenesis.
 Nutritional factors, uteroplacental insufficiency, drugs, and maternal hyperglycemia are the most commonly
encountered adverse environmental events leading to congenital nephron deficit.
American Board of Pediatrics Content Specification(s)
 Understand the impact of the fetal environment on renal development
Suggested Readings
 Dorey ES, Pantaleon M, Weir KA, Moritz KM. Adverse prenatal environment and kidney development:
implications for programming of adult disease. Reproduction. 2014;147(6): R189-R198.
doi: http://dx.doi.org/10.1530/REP-13-0478
 Merlet-Benichou C. Influence of fetal environment on kidney development. Int J Dev Biol. 1999;43(5):453-456.

A 7-year-old girl presented initially at 1 year of age with a sudden onset of lethargy, pallor, and
edema. Her blood tests then showed:
Laboratory Test Result
White blood cell count 13,200/µL (13.2 × 109/L)
Hemoglobin 6.1 g/dL (61 g/L)
Platelet count 19 × 103/µL (19 × 109/L)
Blood urea nitrogen 74 mg/dL (26 mmol/L)
Creatinine 5.2 mg/dL (397 µmol/L)
Despite administering therapies available at the time, she progressed to end-stage renal disease and
has been on maintenance peritoneal dialysis. After years of waiting on the deceased donor list due to
high levels of panel reactive antibodies and frequent positive cross-matches with candidate donors,
she now has a potential living donor candidate. The child’s genetic testing shows a compound
heterozygous mutation in the CD46 (membrane cofactor protein) gene and the complement factor H
gene. Her parents want to know the risk of recurrent primary disease after a kidney transplant.
Of the following, the MOST accurate statement is that her risk of posttransplant recurrent disease
options: depends on if she develops acute rejection
is 30%
is nearly 100%
is negligible
explanation:
B. is 30%
The girl in this vignette has clinical and genetic features consistent with atypical hemolytic uremic
syndrome (aHUS; microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia, in a very young child,
without other triggers, presence of certain genetic mutations). After other diseases, such as
pneumococcal-hemolytic uremic syndrome or thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura, are ruled out,
the remaining forms of aHUS are characterized by abnormalities in the complement system, typically
the inhibitory regulators of complement. Lack of inhibition allows the complement system to remain
active, and it can become overactive in response to unknown triggers. Abnormalities in the
complement system can be caused by genetic mutations in complement factor 3 or complement
inhibitors or by development of antibodies to the regulators from mutations in related proteins. The
affected complement regulators include complement factor H (CFH), complement factor H–related 5,
complement factor I (CFI), complement factor B, membrane cofactor protein (MCP or CD46), and
thrombomodulin. In addition, diacylglycerol kinase epsilon is a non–complement-inhibiting factor that
associates with aHUS when mutated.
Patients with aHUS may have homozygous mutations in 1 of the complement or complement
regulator genes (30%-60% of patients), no identifiable mutations (20%-40% of patients), or
heterozygous compound mutations in 2 complement regulator genes (3%-6% of patients).
Each mutation can have variable penetrance. Combined mutations are more common in patients
with CFI or CD46 mutations (25% of patients), but less common in patients with gene mutations in
CFH, complement factor 3, or complement factor B (8%-10%). The presence of combined mutations
in CFH and CD46 increases the penetrance from 36% to 73% and increases the chance of end-stage
kidney disease by 3 years of onset from 19% to 50%. In contrast, combined mutations
in CFH or CFI with non-CD46 mutations do not modify the prognosis.
Posttransplant recurrence of aHUS was very common in the pre-C5 blockade era; recurrence
occurred in up to 60% of patients, and the subsequent graft survival was very poor (30% survival at 5
years if recurrence vs 68% if no recurrence). As seen in cases of focal segmental glomerulosclerosis,
if a prior failed allograft exhibited recurrence, then the risk of aHUS recurrence in a later allograft is
very high, approximately 80%. The risk varies with the gene affected. Risk of recurrence is highest
with CFH or complement factor B gene mutations (80%), lower with CFI mutations (50%), and lowest
with isolated CD46 mutations (< 10%), where the allograft expresses the nonmutated MCP protein,
which is cell bound and not circulating. However, when a CD46 mutation is associated with a
concomitant mutation in CFH or CFI (as is the case in this vignette), then the risk increases to
approximately 30%. Although acute rejection episodes may activate complement, they have not been
shown to affect the likelihood of aHUS recurrence.
Recurrence may be preventable with use of prophylactic C5 blockade using eculizumab in cases
where the recurrence risk is high. In lower risk cases, prophylaxis may be deferred; treatment should
be initiated if recurrence occurs, and the recovery is usually good if treatment is started early.
Other forms of thrombotic microangiopathy have low to negligible rates of recurrence. Complement
factor H antibody–associated hemolytic uremic syndrome has a low recurrence risk when the
antibody titer is less than 1,000 AU/mL, but can be substantial if the titer is elevated. Shiga toxin–
induced hemolytic uremic syndrome would not be expected to recur. No recurrence has been
reported so far in 3 patients with diacylglycerol kinase epsilon gene mutation who received a kidney
transplant. However, 1 patient who has a thrombomodulin gene mutation has experienced
posttransplant recurrence.

PREP Pearls
 The recurrence risk of atypical hemolytic uremic syndrome varies by the genetic mutation and the presence of
other mutations.
 The highest risk of recurrence is with CFH and CFB mutations.
 The number of genes that may be associated with atypical hemolytic uremic syndrome is increasing.
American Board of Pediatrics Content Specification(s)
 Know the risk of post-transplant recurrence in the different forms of the thrombotic microangiopathies
Suggested Readings
 Bresin E, Rurali E, Caprioli J, et al. Combined complement gene mutations in atypical hemolytic uremic
syndrome influence clinical phenotype. J Am Soc Nephrol. 2013;24(3):475-486.
doi: http://dx.doi.org/10.1681/ASN.2012090884
 Le Quintrec M, Zuber J, Moulin B, et al. Complement genes strongly predict recurrence and graft outcome in
adult renal transplant recipients with atypical hemolytic and uremic syndrome. Am J
Transplant. 2013;13(3):663-675. doi: http://dx.doi.org/10.1111/ajt.12077
 Loirat C, Fakhouri F, Ariceta G, et al. An international consensus approach to the management of atypical
hemolytic uremic syndrome in children. Pediatr Nephrol. 2016;31(1):15-39.
doi: http://dx.doi.org/10.1007/s00467-015-3076-8

A 2-week-old male neonate is seen by his primary care provider. He was born full term with a weight
of 3 kg and without complications. He has been voiding and stooling regularly and feeding
appropriately. His provider notes a prenatal history of a cystic mass in the location of his left kidney
with a normal-appearing right kidney. There is a family history of a maternal aunt with a congenital
solitary kidney. The neonate appears well on examination, weighs 3.1 kg, and has normal blood
pressure. He has a left-sided abdominal mass but no other abnormalities. Renal ultrasonography
reveals a normal right kidney measuring 5.5 cm without urinary tract dilation. The left renal fossa
contains a disorganized collection of cysts measuring 7.3 cm in the longest diameter.
Of the following, the MOST appropriate management of this patient is to perform
options: a DMSA (dimercaptosuccinic acid) scan
a left nephrectomy
serial renal ultrasonography
voiding cystourethrography
explanation:
C. serial renal ultrasonography
The newborn in this vignette has a left multicystic dysplastic kidney (MCDK). Serial renal
ultrasonography is essential for the management of MCDK disease to assess for involution of the
cystic kidney and confirm appropriate structure and compensatory growth of the contralateral kidney.
Simple unilateral MCDK with a normal contralateral kidney has an excellent prognosis for overall
kidney function. However, there is a significant incidence of contralateral renal abnormalities including
vesicoureteral reflux, urinary tract obstruction, and milder forms of renal hypodysplasia. If
abnormalities are present, the child may be at risk for recurrent febrile urinary tract infection,
hypertension, or progressive chronic kidney disease. Supportive monitoring for MCDK therefore
includes serial renal ultrasonography, urinalysis, and blood pressure measurement to screen for signs
of renal functional impairment or complications.
A MCDK is strictly defined as a nonreniform collection of cysts. There is no identifiable renal tissue,
and the kidney has no function. Dimercaptosuccinic acid (DMSA) scans can be considered in the
evaluation of MCDK but are not usually essential. A functional renal scan or diuretic functional renal
scan is most commonly performed when there is uncertainty whether the abnormal kidney represents
a MCDK, a dysplastic kidney with cysts (and therefore, some function), or a congenital ureteropelvic
junction obstruction. Functional scans are usually not needed, especially if the MCDK has already
begun involution prenatally or in the first year after birth, as occurs in the majority of cases.
Previously, there was concern that the MCDK could result in increased incidence of urinary tract
infection, hypertension, or malignant transformation to nephroblastoma or renal cell carcinoma.
Therefore, past management has included nephrectomy. More recent studies demonstrate that
nephrectomy is unnecessary. Provided there is a normal contralateral kidney and urinary tract, there
does not appear to be an increased risk for urinary tract infection or hypertension. Importantly, larger
registries have not illustrated an increased association with renal malignancy or malignant
transformation of the cysts. Nephrectomy is now rarely indicated and only for unique circumstances.
There is an increased risk of vesicoureteral reflux in patients with MCDK, as high as 30% to 40% in
some case series. Reflux may occur on either the ipsilateral or contralateral side. Larger registries
have demonstrated that most of these cases are lower grade reflux (grade 1 or 2) and that the
identification of the reflux has not altered clinical monitoring or management. Because of the
significant incidence of reflux, many providers obtain voiding cystourethrography. However, if the
contralateral kidney and the urinary tract appear otherwise normal, many providers only use voiding
cystourethrography if the patient develops a febrile urinary tract infection. Therefore, serial renal
ultrasonography should be the mainstay of management, whereas voiding cystourethrography may
be considered but is not absolutely needed for the neonate in this vignette.
PREP Pearls
 Multicystic dysplastic kidney disease that is simple and unilateral without contralateral renal or urinary tract
abnormalities has an excellent prognosis.
 The management of multicystic dysplastic kidney disease should include serial ultrasonography to assess for
compensatory growth and normal structure of the contralateral kidney and normal structure of the urinary tract.
 Functional renal scans and voiding cystourethrography may be considered in the evaluation of patients with
multicystic dysplastic kidney disease, but they are not always necessary.
 Nephrectomy is now rarely indicated and only for unique circumstances.

American Board of Pediatrics Content Specification(s)
 Know the management of multicystic renal dysplasia
Suggested Readings
 Hains DS, Bates CM, Ingraham S, Schwaderer AL. Management and etiology of the unilateral multicystic
dysplastic kidney: a review. Pediatr Nephrol. 2009;24(2):233-241. doi: http://dx.doi.org/10.1007/s00467-008-
0828-8
 Weinstein A, Goodman TR, Iragorri S. Simple multicystic dysplastic kidney disease: end points for subspecialty
follow-up. Pediatr Nephrol. 2008;23(1):111-116. doi: http://dx.doi.org/10.1007/s00467-007-0635-7

A 17-year-old adolescent girl is referred to your office for increased serum creatinine levels. She was
recently diagnosed with gout. She has a paternal grandmother aged 59 years who has end-stage
kidney disease, and her father sees a nephrologist because “his kidneys do not work well.” The
patient’s paternal grandmother and father both have gout. The patient is at the 50th percentile for
height and weight and has a blood pressure of 110/60 mm Hg. Her physical examination is normal.
Laboratory investigations reveal a normal complete blood cell count and the following results:
Laboratory Test Result
Serum
Electrolytes Normal
Creatinine 1.5 mg/dL (133 µmol/L)
Uric acid 7.7 mg/dL (458 µmol/L)
Urine
Specific gravity 1.005
Blood Negative
Protein Negative
Renal ultrasonography demonstrates 11-cm kidneys with increased echogenicity and loss of
corticomedullary differentiation.
Of the following, the MOST accurate statement regarding this patient’s kidney disease is that
options: fractional excretion of uric acid is likely to be low
a kidney biopsy would reveal uric acid crystals in the tubular lumen
a metabolic evaluation should be initiated to investigate the uric acid overproduction
ultrasonography of the father or paternal grandmother would reveal medullary cysts
explanation:
A. fractional excretion of uric acid is likely to be low
Medullary cystic disease, also known as autosomal dominant tubulointerstitial kidney disease
(ADTKD), is a rare progressive renal disease in children. Patients will usually have a strong family
history of chronic kidney disease that follows an autosomal dominant pattern, because de novo
mutations are rare. Mutations in genes encoding uromodulin (UMOD), renin (REN), hepatocyte
nuclear factor-1β (HNF1B), and mucin-1 (MUC1) have been implicated in ADTKD. The progressive
decline in kidney function usually occurs after the teenage years and is associated with
tubulointerstitial fibrosis. Cysts are only occasionally detected. Furthermore, the medulla may not be
the location of these cysts. Thus, the term “medullary cystic kidney disease” is misleading, and the
preferred nomenclature is ADTKD.
The clinical presentation of ADTKD is usually nonspecific. Classic clinical findings are presented
in Table 1.
Table 1. Usual Clinical Findings in Patients With ADTKD.
Autosomal dominant inheritance
Progressive loss of kidney function
Bland urinary sediment
Absent to mild albuminuria/proteinuria
Hypertension in early stages is uncommon
No history of drug exposure potentially causing tubulointerstitial nephritis
Normal or small-sized kidneys on ultrasonography
Nocturia or enuresis in children (owing to loss of renal concentration ability)
Abbreviation: ADTKD, autosomal dominant tubulointerstitial kidney disease.
Adapted and reprinted with permission from Eckardt KU, Alper SL, Antignac C, et al. Autosomal dominant
tubulointerstitial kidney disease: diagnosis, classification, and management—a KDIGO consensus report.
Kidney Int. 2015;88(4):676-683.
During teenage years, patients may have elevated creatinine levels. Their urine sediment is usually
bland with evidence of concentrating defect, microscopic hematuria is rare, and proteinuria may be
minimal or absent. A kidney biopsy, which is not necessary for diagnosis, will demonstrate interstitial
fibrosis, normal glomeruli with negative immunofluorescence results, and occasional tubular dilation
consistent with microcysts.
Laboratory abnormalities can be specific to the subtypes of ADTKD. Hyperuricemia often occurs in
ADTKD associated with UMOD and REN mutations. The UMOD mutation–associated ADTKD results
in underexcretion (not overproduction) of urate. The differential diagnosis for teenaged patients who
have gout and abnormal kidney function should include ADTKD.
A low renin state with low angiotensin levels occurs in ADTKD associated
with REN mutations. These patients will have normal blood pressure, mild hyperkalemia, and anemia
that is disproportionate to their renal dysfunction; this anemia is thought to be secondary to
decreased erythropoietin levels.
An overview of the different clinical presentations of ADTKD with each known mutation is outlined
in Table 2.

Table 2. Overview of Clinical Presentations of ADTKD with Each Known Mutation.
Adapted and reprinted with permission from Eckardt KU, Alper SL, Antignac C, et al. Autosomal dominant
tubulointerstitial kidney disease: diagnosis, classification, and management—a KDIGO consensus report.
Kidney Int. 2015;88(4):676-683.
Radiography is not usually helpful in the diagnosis of ADTKD in children. Cysts are not usually
present until late in the disease course and are not thought to impinge on normal parenchyma or lead
to progressive renal function decline.
Treatment of ADTKD is largely supportive. No specific therapy exists for any of the subtypes, so
managing risk factors that can accelerate renal decline, such as hypertension and diabetes, is critical.
If patients have hyperuricemia and hypertension, losartan should considered because it also
increases urinary urate excretion.
The patient in this vignette exhibits a classic presentation of UMOD mutation–associated ADTKD.
The mutation in UMOD leads to underexcretion of uric acid, which can be assessed by calculating the
fractional excretion of uric acid as follows:
(urine uric acid/serum uric acid) ÷ (urine creatinine/serum creatinine).
If this value is below 6%, underexcretion is present. Because the elevated serum uric acid levels are
secondary to underexcretion and not overproduction, uric acid crystals are not seen in renal tubules
or urine, and uric acid stones do not occur. Also, a metabolic evaluation is not needed with an
autosomal dominant pattern of kidney disease in the family history, renal insufficiency, and low
fractional excretion of uric acid. Finally, medullary cysts are not always present (< 50% of patients will
have detectable cysts), and therefore their absence does not rule out ADTKD.
PREP Pearls
 Autosomal dominant tubulointerstitial kidney disease associated with UMOD mutations results in
underexcretion of uric acid and hyperuricemia/gout.
 Autosomal dominant tubulointerstitial kidney disease associated with REN mutations results in a low renin
state and a subsequent angiotensin deficiency with low blood pressure, hyperkalemia, and anemia out of
proportion to the degree of renal insufficiency.
 Medullary cysts are not usually present in autosomal dominant tubulointerstitial kidney disease, formally known
as medullary cystic kidney disease.

American Board of Pediatrics Content Specification(s)
 Know the laboratory and uroradiologic evaluation of medullary cystic disease including prenatal diagnosis
Suggested Readings
 Bleyer AJ, Zivná M, Hulková H, et al. Clinical and molecular characterization of a family with a dominant renin
gene mutation and response to treatment with fludrocortisone. Clin Nephrol. 2010;74(6):411-422.
 Eckardt KU, Alper SL, Antignac C, et al. Autosomal dominant tubulointerstitial kidney disease: diagnosis,
classification, and management—a KDIGO consensus report. Kidney Int. 2015;88(4):676-683.
doi: http://dx.doi.org/10.1038/ki.2015.28
 Omran H, Ermisch-Omran B. Nephronophthisis and medullary cystic kidney disease. In: Geary D, Schaefer F,
eds. Comprehensive Pediatric Nephrology. Philadelphia, PA: Mosby-Elsevier; 2008:143-153.

A 3-year-old presents with a 12-hour history of frequent watery, nonbloody stool. He is seen in the
local emergency department, where he is noted to have mild to moderate dehydration with stable vital
signs. You decide that he is a candidate for a trial of oral rehydration therapy (ORT). The nurse caring
for the child with you wants to know more about the physiologic principles on which ORT is based.
You tell her that in the setting of acute diarrhea, ORT takes advantage of which ONE physiologic
mechanism in the gastrointestinal tract
options: sodium-coupled amino acid cotransporter
sodium-coupled chloride transport
sodium-coupled glucose cotransporter
sodium-coupled hydrogen ion exchanger
explanation:
C. sodium-coupled glucose cotransporter
The success of oral rehydration therapy (ORT) is based on the preserved cotransport of sodium and
glucose in patients with diarrhea secondary to gastroenteritis. Oral rehydration solutions that are
isotonic with equimolar concentrations of glucose and sodium are as effective as intravenous
hydration in treating hypovolemia in patients with diarrhea. The World Health Organization
recommended properties for oral rehydration solutions and formulations that are available can be
found at http://www.who.int/maternal_child_adolescent/documents/9241593180/en/. Amino acid,
chloride, and hydrogen ion, although operational in the gastrointestinal tract, are not used to facilitate
sodium and water reabsorption in the setting of diarrhea-associated volume depletion.
ORT was first used in 1945 but came into its own in the 1960s with the development of effective ORT
formulations. Since that time ORT has saved countless lives of children with diarrhea-associated
hypovolemia, especially in developing countries. In addition, ORT is as effective as intravenous
rehydration therapy in treating hypovolemia from diarrheal illness attributable to gastroenteritis. ORT
was also associated with a shorter length of hospitalization, lower costs, and fewer serious
complications.
ORT makes use of the physiologic basis for water absorption in the gastrointestinal tract. The 3
principal mechanisms that permit passive water absorption in the gastrointestinal tract are the
presence of sodium-hydrogen exchangers, establishment of an electrochemical gradient, and the
sodium-coupled transport with carrier organic solutes (eg, glucose and amino acids). Disruption of
any of these processes can result in diarrhea. However, in children with diarrhea attributable to
gastroenteritis, the sodium-coupled cotransport with glucose and other carrier organic solutes
remains intact.
Fluids with a molar ratio of glucose in excess of sodium, such as fruit juices, soda, or sports
beverages, increase diarrheal losses because the higher unabsorbed glucose load will increase the
osmolality in the lumen, resulting in decreased water absorption. Fluids high in sodium may increase
diarrheal losses and may result in hypernatremia.
Although glucose is used as the carrier organic solute for sodium-coupled transport, other alternatives
have been studied, including zinc, probiotics, glucose polymers, ʟ-isoleucine, glycine, alanine, and
glutamine. However, no data indicate that they are more effective than glucose. Common household
beverages and fluids are not recommended because they have a much higher carbohydrate and
osmolality content than commercial and standard oral rehydration solutions. However, a recent
Canadian clinical trial found that half-strength apple juice may be effective in treating mild-volume
depletion secondary to diarrhea.
PREP Pearls
 Oral rehydration therapy is a vital component of volume repletion in the acute care setting.
 Oral rehydration therapy makes use of glucose- and sodium-coupled cotransport in the gastrointestinal tract to
facilitate water reabsorption.
American Board of Pediatrics Content Specification(s)
 Know the physiologic principles on which oral rehydration therapy is based
Suggested Readings
 Hirschhorn N. Decrease in net stool output in cholera during intestinal perfusion with glucose-containing
solutions. N Engl J Med. 1968;279:176–181. doi: http://dx.doi.org/10.1056/NEJM196807252790402

 Ruxin JN. Magic bullet: the history of oral rehydration therapy. Med Hist. 1994;38:363–397.
 US Department of Health and Human Services. Oral Rehydration Therapy (ORT) in Children. Washington, DC:
US Dept of Health and Human Services; 1997..
 World Health Organization. The Treatment of Diarrhea: A Manual for Physicians and Other Senior Health
Workers. Geneva, Switzerland: World Health Organization, 2005.

stem:
A 13-year-old adolescent boy who has end-stage kidney disease of undetermined etiology has been
receiving hemodialysis for the past 9 months without any notable issues. His dialysis prescription
includes a high-flux filter with a 2-mEq/L potassium, 33-mEq/L bicarbonate, and 3-mEq/L calcium
bath for 3.5 hours 3 times a week. His single pool Kt/V has ranged from 1.5 to 1.8 over the last 6
months. His intradialytic medications include intravenous epogen and paricalcitol with each treatment
and intravenous iron every other month. His home medications include lisinopril, furosemide, calcium
acetate, ergocalciferol, and a dialysis-specific vitamin. His most recent monthly blood test results
were notable for:
Laboratory Test Result
Calcium 11.2 mg/dL (2.80 mmol/L)
Phosphorus 4.9 mg/dL (1.58 mmol/L)
Intact parathyroid hormone 33 pg/mL (33 ng/L)
Of the following, the MOST appropriate treatment for this patient’s hypercalcemia is to
options: add a calcimimetic agent
decrease the calcium bath to 2.5 mEq/L
decrease the treatment time to 3 hours
replace calcium acetate with calcium carbonate
explanation:
B. decrease the calcium bath to 2.5 mEq/L
In this vignette, the patient has developed hypercalcemia with a desired serum phosphorus level and
an overly suppressed parathyroid hormone (PTH) level while receiving several therapies that can
affect these values. Although choices A through C may all lower serum calcium levels (choice D
would raise levels if given an equivalent dose), only choice B (decrease the calcium bath to 2.5
mEq/L) would not adversely affect other aspects of the patient’s bone and mineral disease. The
addition of a calcimimetic (choice A) would be expected to lower the serum calcium level, but would
also further decrease an already suppressed intact PTH level and worsen any adynamic bone
disease. Decreasing the treatment time (choice C) would decrease the overall diffusion of calcium to
the patient, but would also decrease the diffusive clearance of phosphorus. Decreasing the calcium
bath (choice B) would lower the patient’s total exposure to (and absorption of) calcium without
impacting the PTH or phosphorus level.
Serum calcium levels are tightly regulated in most individuals by the deft integration of the kidneys,
bone, intestine, and parathyroid glands, such that normal serum phosphorus and PTH levels are also
maintained. However, in patients with decreased renal function, there can be insufficient active
vitamin D levels, low dietary calcium intake, or inadequate renal excretion of phosphate, leading to a
disruption of this delicate balance. Hypocalcemia, hyperphosphatemia, and hyperparathyroidism may
all develop and become increasingly more prevalent as the glomerular filtration rate lowers. The goals
of bone and mineral disease management in end-stage kidney disease are to maintain both serum
calcium and phosphorus levels in the normal range, while having permissibly elevated PTH levels to
allow for appropriate bone turnover and growth. Balancing these 3 goals can become challenging
because of the differing effects of agents that influence bone and mineral homeostasis.
Enteral calcium intake (both dietary and calcium-containing binders), dialysate calcium, and the use
of activated vitamin D analogs are the primary determinants of calcium balance in patients receiving
dialysis. Hypercalcemia had previously been an uncommon complication in dialysis. Most patients on
dialysis would have a negative calcium balance when dialysate calcium levels were set to the normal
physiologic level, around 2.5 mEq/L, as their dietary intake was not sufficient. Therefore, higher
dialysate calcium concentrations became an early standard, as they would allow for a positive
calcium balance to the patient and correction of hyperparathyroidism. With the advent of calcium-
containing phosphate binders in the 1980s, hypercalcemia became a more prevalent issue. Elevated
serum calcium levels, combined with elevated phosphate levels, increase the risk of precipitation of
calcium-phosphate salts within different tissues, most importantly within the medial layer of
vasculature, and the worsening of cardiovascular disease in the already at-risk dialysis population. In
the adult hemodialysis population, several studies, including the Dialysis Outcomes and Practice
Patterns Study (DOPPS), have shown hypercalcemia to be associated with an increased risk of
death. This association led to hypercalcemia (or the percentage of dialysis patients having an
elevated rolling average of serum calcium) being the first measure of bone and mineral disease
added to the list of dialysis measures in the Quality Improvement Program in 2014.
Guidelines on management of bone and mineral disease in patients with chronic kidney disease have
been developed by both the Kidney Disease Outcomes Quality Initiative (KDOQI) and Kidney
Disease: Improving Global Outcomes (KDIGO) working groups. Although these 2 guidelines are
similar, they have some slight differences in recommendations that reveal our limited knowledge in
some aspects of this disorder. It is recommended by KDOQI that “serum levels of total corrected
calcium should be maintained in the normal range…and preferably toward the lower end” (Am J
Kidney Dis. 2005;46 [4, suppl 1]:S1-121) in patients with stage 5 chronic kidney disease, whereas the
KDIGO recommendations only state maintaining serum calcium levels within the normal range for
patients with stages 3, 4, and 5 chronic kidney disease. Both guidelines recommend courses of action
in the event of hypercalcemia, with restrictions being placed on the dose of calcium-based phosphate

binders or the dose of vitamin D analog, if used. Additionally, KDOQI recommends using a lower (<
2.5 mEq/L) dialysate calcium level for 3 to 4 weeks if there is persistent hypercalcemia despite
making the aforementioned first-line changes. However, activated vitamin D analogs and calcium-
based phosphate binders also have direct effects on PTH and phosphorus levels, whereas dialysate
calcium concentration does not tend to directly affect these other values (although PTH levels will be
indirectly affected), so the potential for other unintended consequences must be accounted for when
making these adjustments.
This difference in the use of lower dialysate calcium concentrations likely stems from differences in
the general recommendations of the 2 groups in the appropriate calcium concentrations, both for
hemodialysis and peritoneal dialysis, to use at baseline. The dialysate calcium concentrations
recommended by the KDOQI guidelines are 2.5 mEq/L for patients who receive calcium-based
phosphate binders and 2.5 to 3 mEq/L for patients who do not receive this type of binder. The KDIGO
guidelines recommend dialysate calcium concentrations between 2.5 and 3 mEq/L, irrespective of the
type of binder being used. Higher dialysate calcium concentrations have been associated with less
intradialytic hypotension and less arrhythmias in adult hemodialysis patients, therefore these
dialysates may be indicated in hemodynamically unstable patients. Similarly, higher dialysate calcium
concentrations have also been associated with lower PTH levels in pediatric peritoneal dialysis
patients with significant hyperparathyroidism. However, the use of these higher calcium
concentrations is also associated with a greater long-term risk of hypercalcemia.
The dialysis prescription may also affect calcium balance with differences in both treatment time and
ultrafiltration volumes. Net removal of calcium by convection can exceed the amount gained by
diffusion, so alterations in ultrafiltration volumes in hemodialysis could theoretically lower serum
calcium levels, but the amount of ultrafiltration needed to achieve this decrease may cause other
significant side effects. Similarly, a reduction in dialysis time, both in peritoneal dialysis and
hemodialysis, would provide less diffusion of calcium to the patient and a less positive calcium
balance. However, it would also provide less diffusive clearance of phosphorus, possibly to a greater
degree. Therefore, a reduction in time on dialysis (choice C) would theoretically treat the
hypercalcemia described in the patient in this vignette, but would also reduce the clearance of
phosphate and possibly lead to hyperphosphatemia.
The selection of phosphate binders should be based on the serum phosphorus and calcium levels, as
well as the age and oral intake capabilities of the patient. In adolescent patients on dialysis on a
phosphorus-restricted diet, their dietary intake of calcium is often very low and calcium
supplementation is typically needed. The total daily intake of dietary calcium, which includes calcium-
based binders, should not exceed twice the daily recommended amount (Dietary Reference Intake)
for age or 2,500 mg total for adolescents and adults. Therefore, it is beneficial to know the calcium
content and enteral absorption of binder options to address the patient’s phosphate levels while not
providing excessive amounts of enteral calcium. In children with chronic kidney disease, calcium
acetate provides a greater degree of phosphate binding (with lower posttreatment phosphate levels)
than calcium carbonate. Similarly, acetate supplies less elemental calcium than carbonate, although
there have not been any significant differences in hypercalcemic episodes in children when these 2
forms of calcium are compared. The calcium-free binder, sevelamer, has been used safely in children
on dialysis for years and has been associated with less hypercalcemia when compared to calcium-
based binders in this pediatric population. This binder would be an optimal choice to replace the
calcium acetate, if offered, in the scenario described in the vignette. Replacing calcium acetate with
calcium carbonate (choice D) would not be optimal as it may place the patient at higher risk of
hypercalcemia if an equivalent dose was used, while providing less phosphate binding.
Calcimimetic agents increase the sensitivity of the calcium-sensing receptors on the parathyroid
gland, suppressing both serum calcium and PTH levels. Therefore, calcimimetics affect the serum

calcium level by affecting the amount of PTH released by the gland and are indicated for use in
primary or tertiary hyperparathyroidism. Updated KDIGO guidelines suggest calcimimetic use to lower
PTH levels, but also recommend its discontinuation in dialysis patients when the PTH level is less
than twice the normal limit. The use of calcimimetics in children on dialysis has been limited and not
well studied. The patient in this vignette has a PTH level in the lower normal range, therefore
suppressed. This would be consistent with adynamic bone disease in this population, a possible
effect from hypercalcemia, but after a prolonged period of decreased bone turnover, may also be a
contributing cause to the hypercalcemia. The addition of a calcimimetic agent (choice A), although
having the side effect of lowering serum calcium levels, would be contraindicated in this scenario
because it would lower the PTH level further and worsen the patient’s bone disease.
Lastly, hypercalcemia can occur in dialysis patients for other reasons besides excess exposure to
vitamin D analogs, enteral calcium, or dialysate calcium, although these etiologies are now
exceedingly rare in the pediatric population. Excess vitamin A exposure or the use of thiazide
diuretics causes hypercalcemia in adult patients and would best be treated with discontinuation of
these medications. Aluminum toxicity historically has been a cause of hypercalcemia, when
aluminum-containing phosphate binders were primarily used. Aluminum deposition in the bone would
cause decreased bone turnover and not allow for calcium to re-deposit into the bone, causing
elevated serum levels. Similarly, patients with significant immobilization and decreased bone turnover
may also become hypercalcemic. Malignancies have been associated with hypercalcemia in adult
dialysis patients, from lytic bone lesions, excessive active vitamin D formation, or the production of
PTH-related protein from the tumor cells. Lastly, granulomatous diseases, like sarcoidosis,
tuberculosis, or disseminated histoplasmosis, can also cause excessive active vitamin D levels and
hypercalcemia and may be considered if hypercalcemia persists despite minimizing exposure to
prescribed sources of calcium and vitamin D.
PREP Pearls
 Enteral calcium intake (primarily calcium-containing binders), dialysate calcium, and the use of activated
vitamin D analogs are the primary determinants of calcium balance in patients receiving dialysis.
 A dialysate calcium concentration of 2.5 mEq/L is generally recommended in both hemodialysis and peritoneal
dialysis when calcium-based phosphate binders, vitamin D sterols, or both are also being prescribed.
 Calcium acetate provides a greater degree of phosphate binding than calcium carbonate, but also supplies
less elemental calcium.
American Board of Pediatrics Content Specification(s)
 Know the management of hypercalcemia in patients treated with maintenance dialysis
Suggested Readings
 K/DOQI Clinical Practice Guidelines for Bone Metabolism and Disease in Children With Chronic Kidney
Disease. Am J Kidney Dis. 2005;46 (4, suppl 1):S1-121. doi: http://dx.doi.org/10.1053/j.ajkd.2005.07.025
 Kidney Disease: Improving Global Outcomes (KDIGO) CKD-MBD Work Group. KDIGO Clinical Practice
Guideline for the Diagnosis, Evaluation, Prevention, and Treatment of Chronic Kidney Disease-Mineral and
Bone Disorder (CKD-MBD). Kidney Int Suppl. 2009;76(suppl 113):S1-S130.
 Toussaint N, Cooney P, Kerr PG. Review of dialysate calcium concentration in hemodialysis. Hemodial
Int.2006;10(4): 326-337. doi: http://dx.doi.org/10.1111/j.1542-4758.2006.00125.x

You are seeing a 6-day-old premature infant born at 30 weeks of gestation. She has respiratory
distress syndrome and is receiving mechanical ventilation. Initially after birth, she appeared slightly
edematous but had normal blood pressure, peripheral perfusion, and physical examination findings.
During the past 4 days, FiO decreased from 0.7 to 0.4, urine output increased from 1.0 mL/kg/h on
2
days 1 and 2 after birth to 6.0 mL/kg/h on days 4 to 6, and the serum creatinine level decreased from
1.4 to 0.8 mg/dL (124 to 71 µmol/L). Her fluid intake was maintained at 80 mL/kg/d until day 5 when it
was increased to 120 mL/kg/d. Serum sodium concentration increased from 129 mEq/L (129 mmol/L)
on day 2 to 142 mEq/L (142 mmol/L) on day 6. She received routine antibiotic coverage with
ampicillin and cefotaxime, but is on no other medications. A pediatric resident asks you about the
effects of respiratory distress syndrome on neonatal renal function.
Of the following, the MOST likely cause of the spontaneous postnatal diuresis in this infant is
options: increased free water clearance
physiological decrease in renal responsiveness to antidiuretic hormone
a rise in glomerular filtration rate that exceeds proximal tubular reabsorption capacity
solute diuresis caused by enhanced delivery of sodium to the distal nephron
explanation:
A. increased free water clearance
The premature infant in this vignette has respiratory distress syndrome (RDS). During the first week
after birth, the infant underwent a spontaneous diuresis followed by improved oxygenation and a rise
in serum sodium concentration consistent with water diuresis.
There is a consensus among studies of renal function in premature infants with RDS that renal
plasma flow (measured by para-aminohippuric acid clearance) and glomerular filtration rate
(measured by inulin or creatinine clearance) are both depressed in the early phase of RDS. During
this period (days 1-3 after birth), the infant appears slightly edematous, sodium concentrations are
slightly low, urine output is less than 1 mL/kg/h, and O requirements are relatively high. In the
2
absence of confounding factors such as intraventricular hemorrhage, hemodynamically significant
patent ductus arteriosus, or sepsis, the premature infant undergoes a spontaneous diuresis (usually
tripling of the urine flow rate) on days 3 to 5 after birth, followed by weight loss, normalization of
serum sodium, and a marked in improvement in O requirement and ventilatory support. During this
2
diuretic phase, plasma vasopressin levels remain unchanged (choice B), and renal plasma flow and
glomerular filtration rate increase significantly. Initial studies suggested that the improved renal
hemodynamics mediate the spontaneous diuresis in neonatal RDS. However, later studies that
examined the temporal correlation between urine flow rate and renal hemodynamics found that the
increase in glomerular filtration rate persisted even after the resolution of the diuretic phase (choice
C). Also, careful analysis of urinary osmotic and water clearances conducted before, during, and
after the spontaneous diuresis phase concluded that the spontaneous diuresis is caused by
increased free water clearance (adjusted for glomerular filtration rate). Presumably, the free water
diuresis represents the renal response to the endogenous water load resulting from the
intracellular/extracellular fluid shift after birth (choice A). Osmolar clearance remains unchanged
during the diuretic phase of RDS (choice D).
PREP Pearls
 Neonatal respiratory distress syndrome is accompanied by altered renal hemodynamics including low renal
plasma flow and glomerular filtration rate, independent of changes in systemic hemodynamics.
 All infants, regardless of age, undergo spontaneous postnatal diuresis.
 Although it coincides temporally with increased glomerular filtration, the spontaneous diuresis of neonatal
respiratory distress syndrome is caused by enhanced tubular free water clearance in an attempt to excrete the
endogenous water load.
American Board of Pediatrics Content Specification(s)
 Understand the effects of neonatal respiratory distress syndrome on renal function
Suggested Readings
 Costarino AT, Baumgart S, Norman ME, Polin RA. Renal adaptation to extrauterine life in patients with
respiratory distress syndrome. Am J Dis Child. 1985;139(10):1060-1063.
 Guignard J-P, Torrado A, Mazouni SM, Gautier E. Renal function in respiratory distress syndrome. J
Pediatr. 1976;88(5):845-850.

A 3-month-old, preterm, male infant born at 36 weeks presents for evaluation of small kidneys
incidentally noted on abdominal ultrasonography performed when the infant presented with emesis to
the emergency department. His prenatal course was complicated by intrauterine growth restriction.
There is no family history of renal disease. Physical examination findings are normal, with a blood
pressure of 80/50 mm Hg. Renal ultrasonography reveals a left kidney of 3.6 cm and right kidney of
3.5 cm (<2 SDs below the mean).
Of the following, the MOST likely cause of small kidneys in this infant is
options: intrauterine growth restriction
maternal vitamin A deficiency
PAX2 mutation
prematurity
explanation:
A. intrauterine growth restriction
The infant described in the vignette has bilateral renal hypoplasia. Renal hypoplasia is defined as
small kidneys (2 SDs below the mean for age) with normal morphologic findings and reduced
nephron numbers. Ureteric bud branching is a critical factor determining nephron number. Multiple
signaling pathways regulate ureteric bud branching (Figure and Table 1).

Abbreviations: ACE, angiotensin-converting enzyme; ARB, angiotensin receptor blocker.
Courtesy of K. Reidy
Based on data collected from Cain JE, Di Giovanni V, Smeeton J, Rosenblum ND. Genetics of renal
hypoplasia: insights into the mechanisms controlling nephron endowment. Pediatr Res. 2010 Aug;68(2):91-8.
In this patient, intrauterine growth restriction is the most likely cause of the small kidneys because the
infant has a history of intrauterine growth retardation, which is associated with renal hypoplasia. In the
absence of family history or abnormal physical findings, a PAX2 mutation (associated with autosomal
dominant renal-coloboma syndrome and renal hypoplasia) is less likely in this infant. Although
prematurity can lead to a decreased nephron number, this infant was only mildly premature (36

weeks’ gestation), at which time ureteric bud branching is complete. Maternal vitamin A deficiency is
associated with renal hypoplasia but is more likely in a underdeveloped country.
There are 3 primitive kidneys that form during human kidney development: the pronephros,
mesonephros, and metanephros. The pronephros forms at 3 weeks’ gestation and consists of simple
tubules that involute. The mesonephros forms caudal to the pronephros and consists of glomeruli and
tubules that filter. As these involute, the mesonephros forms the mesonephric duct (Wolffian duct).
The ureteric bud is an outgrowth of the mesonephric duct that invades the surrounding metanephric
mesenchyme during the fifth week of gestation. The ureteric bud undergoes branching. The number
and pattern of the branches determine the pattern of the adult kidney and the nephron number.
Reciprocal signaling between the ureteric bud branches and the surrounding cap mesenchyme is
required for proper branching and induction of formation of epithelial nephron structures at the tips of
the ureteric bud branches. These epithelial structures (first a renal vesicle, then the comma and S-
shape body) will form the glomeruli, proximal tubule, loop of Henle, and distal tubules of the
nephrons. The branching ureteric bud forms the collecting ducts, calyces, renal pelvis, ureter, and
bladder trigone.
Ureteric bud outgrowth from the mesonephric duct and branching morphogenesis are regulated by
multiple cell signaling pathways. Defects in ureteric bud outgrowth can result in congenital anomalies,
such as renal agenesis (if signals from the ureteric bud do not reach the metanephric mesenchyme,
the metanephric mesenchyme undergoes apoptosis) or duplicated kidneys or collecting systems (if
multiple ureteric buds grow from the mesonephric duct). In addition, buds that form too superiorly or
inferiorly may fail to connect to the bladder properly, leading to ureterovesical junction obstruction or
vesicoureteral reflux. Defects in branching morphogenesis can also result in a spectrum of renal
defects, including low nephron number, renal hypoplasia, and ureteropelvic junction obstruction.
The ureteric bud undergoes iterative branching. In the mouse, the ureteric bud initially bifurcates.
Each tip then trifurcates, but branching afterward is mostly bifurcation at orthogonal angles (ie, the
plane of each successive bifurcation shifts by 90°). Microenvironments, including the surrounding
heparan sulfate extracellular matrix, likely contribute to this process by enabling the ureteric bud tips
to differentiate from the stalk. The ureteric bud tip cells appear to have a self-renewing population of
cells that divide to form ureteric bud trunk and tip cells. In this model, new ureteric bud branches form
when localized growth factors promote budding with an apical actin cytoskeleton “purse-string”
mechanism. Cessation of budding in this model is induced by differentiation of the surround
metanephric mesenchyme (changing the microenvironment) and possibly also by changes in the
extracellular matrix.
Ureteric bud branching and nephron induction continue until 28 to 36 weeks’ gestation. Thus,
nephron number is established at birth. Body weight is associated with nephron number, and low birth
weight and intrauterine growth restriction are associated with decreased nephron number in humans.
Studies of premature infants (born before 36 weeks’ gestation) indicate that although some new
nephrons form after birth, nephron formation terminates early, leading to low nephron number. Low
nephron number is a risk factor for proteinuria and chronic kidney disease (CKD) and end-stage
kidney disease (ESKD) in adulthood. Thus, abnormalities in ureteric branching morphogenesis can
lead to childhood CKD/ESKD attributable to congenital abnormalities of the kidney and urinary tract or
contribute to adult-onset CKD/ESKD.
One of the major molecular signaling pathways regulating both ureteric bud outgrowth and branching
is glial cell–derived neurotrophic factor (GDNF)/Ret signaling. GDNF is a secreted ligand that is
synthesized by the metanephric mesenchyme. Proper GDNF expression in the metanephric
mesenchyme requires multiple transcription factors, including SALL1 (mutations lead to Townes-
Brocks syndrome of imperforate anus, dysplastic ears, thumb malformations, and renal

anomalies), SIX1/5 or EYA1 (mutations lead to branchiootorenal syndrome), or PAX2 (mutations lead
to renal coloboma syndrome). Loss of GDNF expression in mice results in failure of ureteric bud
outgrowth and renal agenesis. Similarly, RET mutations are associated with renal agenesis in
humans. GDNF binds the Ret receptor, which is concentrated at the tip of the ureteric bud. Ret
expression is stimulated by vitamin A (retinoic acid). The Ret receptor is a tyrosine kinase that has a
coreceptor (GDNF family receptor α1 [GFRα1]). Binding by GDNF to Ret/GFRα1 leads to
dimerization of the receptor and phosphorylation of intracellular tyrosine domains that activates the
intracellular signaling pathways, including mitogen-activated protein kinases and phosphoinositide-3-
kinase. These intracellular signaling pathways drive cell proliferation, actin cytoskeleton
rearrangement, cell-matrix adhesion, and cell migration that all contribute to ureteric bud outgrowth
and branching. A tyrosine kinase inhibitor, Sprouty, is required to restrict the location of outgrowth
and the number of ureteric buds. Genetic deletion of Sprouty in mice leads to ectopic and
supernumerary ureteric buds. Interestingly, if both GDNF and its signaling inhibitor Sprouty are
deleted in mice, fibroblast growth factor signaling can compensate and induce ureteric bud outgrowth.
Neural guidance factors Slit2/Robo2 also regulate ureteric bud outgrowth locations, and mutations in
these are associated with vesicoureteral reflux in humans. The transcription factor Foxc1/2 restricts
GDNF expression and thereby ureteric bud outgrowth. FOXC2 mutations are associated with
lymphedema-distichiasis syndrome in humans, which may include renal anomalies, such as duplex
kidneys.
GDNF/Ret signaling is also a key mediator of ureteric bud branching. The high concentration of Ret at
ureteric bud tips appears to drive cellular rearrangements required for branching morphogenesis.
Many other signaling pathways can modulate branching morphogenesis. Some are inhibitory (eg,
transforming growth factor β superfamily proteins activin and bone morphogenic proteins), others are
stimulatory (eg, tyrosine kinases, vascular endothelial growth factor, epidermal growth factor, and
hepatocyte growth factor). In addition, the heparan sulfate proteoglycan content of the extracellular
matrix has also been shown to modulate branching (likely via effects on localization and activity of
bound growth factors). Angiotensin II also stimulates ureteric bud branching. Wnt signaling (likely
canonical β-catenin mediated) modulates ureteric bud branching. Wnt planar cell polarity signaling
has a minor effect on ureteric bud branching but is required for ureteric bud elongation. Sonic
hedgehog signaling affects ureteric bud branching (likely indirectly via effects on the metanephric
mesenchyme and stroma) but also contributes to ureteral smooth muscle differentiation.
The fetal environment also affects ureteric bud branching (Table 2). For example, rodent models of
placental insufficiency lead to decreased nephron number. Although mechanisms have not been
elucidated for all factors, it is likely that some are mediated by effects on the above molecular
signaling pathways (eg, maternal vitamin A deficiency likely affects Ret expression).
PREP Pearls
 Branching morphogenesis determines the pattern and number of nephrons.
 Branching morphogenesis determines the pattern and number of nephrons.
 Defects in ureteric bud outgrowth and branching can lead to congenital abnormalities of the kidney and urinary
tract, including renal agenesis, hypoplasia, duplicated kidneys or ureters, ureterovesical junction obstruction,
and vesicoureteral reflux.
American Board of Pediatrics Content Specification(s)
 Understand the principles of branching morphogenesis in kidney development

Suggested Readings
 Cain JE, Di Giovanni V, Smeeton J, Rosenblum ND. Genetics of renal hypoplasia: insights into the

You are evaluating a 3-week-old newborn with new onset gross hematuria who is in the neonatal
intensive care unit. He has congenital nephrotic syndrome and was born at term. He had been
clinically stable for the past 3 weeks until he developed diarrhea last night. His current weight is 3.8
kg. His weight 72 hours ago was 4.2 kg. His blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg, and he is in no
apparent distress. His abdominal examination reveals a previously undocumented mass in the left
upper quadrant. Laboratory data are shown:
Laboratory Test Result
White blood cell count 6,500/µL (6.5 × 109/L)
Hemoglobin 13.8 g/dL (138 g/L)
Platelet count 67 × 103/µL (67 × 109/L)
Serum chemistry panel Normal
Creatinine 0.5 mg/dL (38 µmol/L)
His previous serum creatinine level was 0.2 mg/dL (15 µmol/L). Two days ago, his platelet count was
260 × 103/µL (260 × 109/L).
You tell the neonatal intensive care unit team to order renal ultrasonography, and you explain that the
MOST likely findings from ultrasonography would be
options: a 5-cm mass in the upper pole of the left kidney
decreased corticomedullary differentiation in the left kidney with decreased Doppler amplitude of venous flow
pronounced fetal lobulations with slightly increased echogenicity but normal corticomedullary differentiation
severe hydronephrosis in the left kidney with debris in the collecting system
explanation:
B. decreased corticomedullary differentiation in the left kidney with decreased Doppler amplitude of
venous flow
The newborn in this vignette has a renal vein thrombosis. Renal vein thrombosis occurs most
commonly in neonates and rarely occurs in ambulatory children. The children who develop renal vein
thrombosis usually have one or more underlying risk factors. The newborn in this vignette has
congenital nephrotic syndrome, which leads to a hypercoagulable state. The acute volume
contraction from diarrhea has lead to sluggish blood flow in his renal venous system and subsequent
thrombosis. The clinical picture of acute kidney injury, hypertension, gross hematuria, and acute
thrombocytopenia is classic for renal vein thrombosis. Other risk factors have been associated with
renal vein thrombosis. Classically, children will have an indwelling umbilical venous catheter that
serves as the nidus for thrombus formation. Birth asphyxia, maternal diabetes, and polycythemia are
also risk factors. Children with renal vein thrombosis should be evaluated for abnormalities that can
lead to thrombosis, such as deficiencies in factor V Leiden, protein S, protein C, or antithrombin III, or
the presence of lupus anticoagulant, especially when there is no obvious etiology of the thrombosis.
The approach to the patient with suspected renal vein thrombosis should include renal
ultrasonography with Doppler. Classic findings on ultrasonography include a hyperechoic cortex with
loss of corticomedullary differentiation. The renal vein may not be collapsible. Doppler amplitudes
may be blunted with absent or severely diminished intrarenal and renal venous flow. Therefore, a
decreased Doppler amplitude of venous flow would correlate to the clinical picture of renal vein
thrombosis as described in this vignette. Although a renal mass could lead to some of the clinical
findings presented, the abrupt nature of this clinical scenario as well as the predisposing factors do
not support a renal mass as the most likely finding. An obstruction with infection could manifest itself
as gross hematuria, but the severe thrombocytopenia and hypertension are more likely to be
secondary to renal vein thrombosis than urinary tract infection. Normal newborn ultrasonography may
reveal pronounced lobulations with normal corticomedullary differentiation and would not be expected
in the case of acute renal vein thrombosis with acute kidney injury.
The best treatment for renal vein thrombosis is unclear. Generally, intravascular volume expansion,
especially in patients with dehydration, is indicated. The use of fibrinolytics and anticoagulation has
not been extensively studied in controlled trials to assess for a true benefit, especially in patients
without acute kidney injury. Data from existing studies is conflicting and does not provide a universal
approach for anticoagulation use in renal vein thrombosis. In general, infants with unilateral renal vein
thrombosis can be managed conservatively, without anticoagulation or fibrinolytics. If an indwelling
umbilical venous catheter is present, it should be removed. If there is extension into the inferior vena
cava, anticoagulation with unfractionated heparin or low molecular weight heparin is often considered.
For infants with bilateral renal vein thrombosis, both heparin and fibrinolytic therapies may be
indicated. Consultation with hematology is warranted to discuss each case. These patients are at
high risk for long-term renal damage, so nephrology follow-up is indicated in all cases.
PREP Pearls
 Gross hematuria and thrombocytopenia in a patient at risk for thrombosis warrants an evaluation for renal vein
thrombosis.
 There is insufficient clinical trial data to decisively warrant a role for anticoagulation in patients with renal vein
thrombosis.
American Board of Pediatrics Content Specification(s)
 Plan the appropriate evaluation of an occluded renal vein
 Know the current therapy/intervention for an occluded renal artery

Suggested Readings
 Ismaili K, Avni FE, Hall M. Antenatal assessment of kidney morphology and function. In: Geary D, Schaefer F,
eds. Comprehensive Pediatric Nephrology. Philadelphia, PA: Mosby Elsevier; 2008:63-78.
 Lau KK, Stoffman JM, Williams S, et al. Neonatal renal vein thrombosis: review of the English-language
literature between 1992 and 2006. Pediatrics. 2007;120(5):e1278-e1284.
doi: http://dx.doi.org/10.1542/peds.2007-0510

You are seeing a 9-year-old girl for evaluation of elevated serum creatinine levels. She has a history
of developmental delay and visual impairments including peripheral vision loss and night blindness.
She is undergoing genetic testing but does not yet have an underlying diagnosis. Her laboratory data,
confirmed on several repeat specimens, are notable for a serum creatinine level of 1.5 mg/dL (133
µmol/L; estimated glomerular filtration rate, 35 mL/min/1.73 m2), a hemoglobin level of 9.9 g/dL (99
g/L), and unremarkable urinalysis results with a specific gravity of 1.010 and no blood or protein.
Renal ultrasonography reveals normal-sized kidneys with markedly increased cortical echogenicity
suggestive of medical renal disease. A review of symptoms reveals nocturnal enuresis but is
otherwise unremarkable. She has no history of urinary tract infections. Her blood pressure is 90/50
mm Hg, and her physical examination findings are otherwise unremarkable.
Her constellation of findings is MOST consistent with which one of the following syndromes?
options: Jeune syndrome
Joubert syndrome
Meckel syndrome
Senior-Loken syndrome
explanation:
D. Senior-Loken syndrome
This patient’s elevated creatinine level, anemia, bland urinary findings with isosthenuria and nocturnal
enuresis, normotension, and echogenic but otherwise normally appearing kidneys are most
consistent with chronic interstitial nephritis associated with nephronophthisis.
Nephronophthisis is characterized by diminished urinary concentration, absence of
proteinuria/hematuria (“bland urinary sediment”), chronic tubulointerstitial nephritis, renal cysts, and
progression to end-stage renal disease by 20 years of age. The syndromes associated with
nephronophthisis are inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern and characterized by their
extrarenal manifestations (Table ).

In this vignette, the patient’s retinitis pigmentosa and lack of additional extrarenal manifestations
make Senior-Loken syndrome the most likely diagnosis.
PREP Pearls
 Nephronophthisis is a renal disorder characterized by urinary concentrating defects, bland urinary sediment,
and progression to end-stage renal disease usually by 20 years of age.
 Nephronophthisis is associated with genetic syndromes that are differentiated by their extrarenal
manifestations.

American Board of Pediatrics Content Specification(s)
 Recognize nephronophthisis-related disorders, including Meckel syndrome. Joubert syndrome, and Senior-
Loken syndrome
Suggested Readings
 Hildebrandt F, Attanasio M, Otto E. Nephronophthisis: disease mechanisms of a ciliopathy. J Am Soc
Nephrol.2009;20(1):23-35. doi: http://dx.doi.org/10.1681/ASN.2008050456
