You are evaluating a 20-month-old male child who was brought to the emergency department with
abdominal pain and decreased urine output. This morning he had 2 episodes of nonbloody nonbilious
emesis at home, and his mother noted abdominal distension. She also reported that his diaper was
dry from overnight. After he refused breakfast, she brought him to the emergency department. He has
a temperature of 37.5°C, respiratory rate of 26 breaths/min, heart rate of 150 beats/min, and blood
pressure measurements of 129/97, 131/95, and 127/94 mm Hg. His weight is 9.35 kg. During
physical examination, he was slightly fussy. The physical examination results were significant for a
soft, slightly tender, distended abdomen and normal active bowel sounds. Abdominal radiography
revealed a significant amount of stool throughout the colon but no obstruction or free air. Renal
ultrasonography revealed bilateral hydroureteronephrosis and a distended urinary bladder.
Laboratory data were notable for:
Laboratory Test Result
Sodium 129 mEq/L (129 mmol/L)
Potassium 5.9 mEq/L (5.9 mmol/L)
Chloride 103 mEq/L (103 mmol/L)
Bicarbonate 13 mEq/L (13 mmol/L)
Blood urea nitrogen 54 mg/dL (19.3 mmol/L)
Creatinine 1.7 mg/dL (150 µmol/L)
Upon placement of a urinary catheter, there is a return of 500 mL urine.
Of the following, the BEST next step in the diagnostic management of this child is
options: computed tomography
cystoscopy
radioisotope renography with MAG3 (mercaptoacetyltriglycine)
voiding cystourethrography
explanation:
D. voiding cystourethrography
The child in this vignette has acute kidney injury and hypertensive urgency secondary to obstructive
uropathy. Obstruction relief is a priority to preserve renal function and augment blood pressure–
lowering efforts. Normal bladder capacity for a child of this age is approximately 100 mL. With 500 mL
urine return after placement of a Foley catheter, you have confirmed that there is at least an
obstruction distal to the bladder. The most common etiology of this type of obstruction in a male child
is posterior urethral valve (PUV). Other etiologies include urethral atresia or stricture or bladder neck
abnormalities.
The child in this vignette has a lower urinary tract obstruction as evidenced by the renal and bladder
ultrasonography findings and the clinical response to Foley catheter insertion. Although PUV is a
likely cause, voiding cystourethrography should be performed prior to surgery to confirm the
diagnosis of PUV and assess for vesicoureteral reflux. After PUV is confirmed, cystoscopy with valve
ablation may be pursued. Incontinent stoma creation is occasionally used in cases where continuous
bladder emptying is required in an infant who is ordinarily incontinent. However, the bladder
thickness, capacity, and distensibility would need to be assessed prior to this procedure. In addition,
the upper tract should be assessed to determine if a more proximal diversion is warranted because of
additional proximal functional or structural obstruction. Radioisotope renography with MAG3
(mercaptoacetyltriglycine) is helpful in determining the presence of ureteropelvic junction (UPJ) and
ureterovesicular junction (UVJ) obstruction, in addition to providing information about differential
kidney function. However, the child in this vignette clearly has a distal obstruction at the level of the
bladder, so this test would not be the best test to perform next. Computed tomography is not
indicated, because the combination of kidney ultrasonography and voiding cystourethrography is
most likely to establish the diagnosis, allowing for rapid transit to cystoscopy and surgical correction.
Obstructive uropathy can be partial or complete. It can also be acute or chronic and can occur at any
location along the urinary tract. Most cases of obstructive uropathy present in infancy because
abnormalities are identified by prenatal ultrasonography. Common causes (in descending anatomic
order) include UPJ obstruction, UVJ obstruction, and posterior urethral valve.
Ureteropelvic junction obstruction is the most common cause of congenital urinary tract obstruction
and is typically diagnosed prenatally. It occurs more often on the left side and is twice as common in
boys than in girls. Although it is usually unilateral, bilateral UPJ obstruction occurs in 10% to 40% of
cases.
With UPJ obstruction, a narrowing of the proximal ureter at the point where the ureter meets the renal
pelvis blocks urine flow from the renal pelvis into the ureter. This obstruction can be due to intrinsic or
extrinsic factors. Intrinsic factors, such as a dysfunctional or adynamic ureteral segment, are much
more common in the pediatric age group. Rarely, polyps or stones can cause obstruction via a valve-
like process. Extrinsic causes, which include aberrant/crossing vessels, kinks, bands, and adhesions,
often lead to intermittent UPJ obstruction.
A distal ureter that is adynamic is usually the cause of UVJ obstruction. This poorly functioning
ureteral segment interrupts the functional continuity of the rest of the ureter, leading to primary
megaureter. Primary megaureter is in contrast to secondary megaureter, which occurs with distal
obstructive processes such as ureteroceles, PUV, and urethral atresia, and in contrast to refluxing
megaureter, which occurs with vesicoureteral reflux.
Posterior urethral valve results in bladder outlet obstruction and is the most common cause of lower
urinary tract obstruction in male infants. The obstruction is caused by an abnormal valve-like
membrane that originates from the verumontanum in the posterior urethra. The embryologic

counterpart of this membrane in females is the hymen. Posterior urethral valves are associated with
small-capacity, thickened, poorly compliant bladders that contribute to poor urinary drainage even
after the obstruction is relieved.
Because these forms of congenital urinary tract obstruction often present prenatally and are managed
soon after birth, many infants are asymptomatic. However, more severe forms of obstructive uropathy
such as PUV can be associated with severe dilatation of the urinary tract, oligohydramnios, and
pulmonary hypoplasia. Generally speaking, the greater the degree of hydronephrosis noted on
prenatal ultrasonography, the greater the likelihood of a more significant urologic abnormality.
The cornerstone of obstructive uropathy management is close monitoring and screening for renal
sequelae. As described below, some obstructions resolve spontaneously and others require surgical
correction.
Infants with UPJ obstruction who are diagnosed prenatally are often asymptomatic, but children who
are diagnosed later in life may develop abrupt-onset flank pain, nausea, vomiting, and dehydration.
These children may report that certain positions (curling up on the floor, leaning over a piece of
furniture) alleviate the symptoms and that pain will later subside after several hours with no fluid
intake. Diagnosis in these children can be challenging, often requiring an imaging study during the
painful episode. Although UPJ obstruction can self-resolve with maturation, self-resolution is less
likely with greater degrees of hydronephrosis. The gold standard management approach is surgical
correction via dismembered pyeloplasty after an initial period of observation and monitoring. Urinary
tract infection is not common with UPJ obstruction. If a urinary tract infection is present, one should
look for comorbid vesicoureteral reflux or bladder abnormalities.
In contrast to UPJ obstruction, UVJ obstruction rarely presents with pain and is often associated with
urinary tract infection. During an infectious episode, the degree of ureteral dilatation may be more
pronounced because of the effect of bacterial toxins on the ureteral smooth muscle. Although UVJ
obstruction can self-resolve, there are no signs or symptoms that predict resolution. If the UVJ
obstruction does not resolve, ureteral reimplantation with an antireflux approach may be required,
particularly in children who experience recurrent urinary tract infections.
As with the other forms of obstructive uropathy, PUV often presents prenatally but can also present in
later childhood. A prenatal diagnosis may be made when ultrasonography reveals a small bladder,
bilateral hydroureteronephrosis, and oligohydramnios. Later presentation may include a history of
urinary incontinence, weak urinary stream, or urinary tract infection, or it may be more significant with
urosepsis and renal failure. Once the diagnosis is established with renal ultrasonography and voiding
cystourethrography that show a dilated posterior urethra, the child should undergo bladder
decompression and endoscopic valve ablation. The bladders in children with PUV are often quite
small, stiff, and poorly compliant. They are often under very high pressure that is exacerbated by the
impaired concentrating ability of the kidneys, which produces a large urinary volume. This
combination of a large urinary volume and high pressure bladder results in high pressures transmitted
to the kidneys and worsening renal function. Therefore, children with PUV require very close follow-
up with ultrasonography and laboratory assessments. Many children with PUV will have poor bladder
function that requires additional surgeries to enhance urinary drainage. Potential interventions include
more proximal urinary diversion (vesicostomy, ureterostomy, pyelostomy), bladder augmentation, and
ureteral tapering with reimplantation. Regular bladder emptying is essential and often requires clean
intermittent catheterization during the day and Foley catheter drainage overnight. In children who are
sensate, catheterization may prove difficult. In these cases, creation of a continent catheterizable
stoma may be necessary.

In all forms of obstructive uropathy, close monitoring before and after surgery is essential to preserve
renal function. Monitoring consists of blood pressure measurement to screen for hypertension,
electrolyte and renal function assessment to screen for chronic kidney disease progression, urine
studies to screen for proteinuria, and imaging studies of the kidneys and bladder to screen for new or
worsening obstruction or reflux. Ideally, the imaging should consist of ultrasonography performed
when the bladder is both full and empty to provide additional functional information. The interval
between follow-up imaging studies is dependent on the initial management approach (watchful
waiting vs decompression) and clinical response (structural and functional). Regardless of the
approach, long-term follow-up is critical to preserve and protect renal function as the child matures
and reaches adulthood.
Families should be counseled on the avoidance of nephrotoxic agents, including nonsteroidal anti-
inflammatory drugs. They should be provided anticipatory guidance regarding early identification and
treatment of urinary tract infections. Due to the impaired renal concentrating ability of most children
with obstructive uropathy, families should also be counseled on providing children free access to
water and ensuring that they remain hydrated. Constipation, which can lead to further difficulties with
bladder emptying, is a frequent comorbid finding in these children. Close monitoring of stool habits
and stool burden is also required, and early treatment of constipation should be encouraged.
PREP Pearls
 Some forms of obstructive uropathy (ureteropelvic junction obstruction, ureterovesicular junction obstruction)
can self-resolve, but others (posterior urethral valve) require immediate intervention and ultimate surgical
correction.
 Close long-term follow-up to screen for hypertension, proteinuria, renal insufficiency, and new or worsening
obstruction is essential for patients with obstructive uropathy.
American Board of Pediatrics Content Specification(s)
 Understand the management options and follow-up for patients with urethral valves, ureterovesicular junction
obstruction, and ureteropelvic junction obstruction
Suggested Readings
 Chevalier RL, Peters CA. Obstructive uropathy. In: Avner E, Harmon W, Niaudet P, Yoshikawa N,
eds. Pediatric Nephrology. 6th ed. Berlin, Germany: Springer-Verlag; 2009:1337-1377.

You are consulted on a 2-week-old male neonate with prenatally enlarged kidneys. Ultrasonography
performed at 22 weeks’ gestation revealed enlarged kidneys along with polydactyly, cerebellar vermis
hypoplasia, and mild ventriculomegaly with a dilated fourth ventricle. The family history is
unremarkable. Postnatal ultrasonography shows enlarged (+1 standard deviation) kidneys for age
and slight loss of corticomedullary differentiation. The physical examination findings are remarkable
for bilateral postaxial polydactyly of the hands.
Of the following, the diagnostic study that would BEST establish the underlying syndrome in this
patient is
options: magnetic resonance imaging of the brain
magnetic resonance imaging of the kidneys
targeted exome sequencing of ciliopathy genes
urine electrolyte analysis
explanation:
A. magnetic resonance imaging of the brain
This patient’s prenatal findings of abnormal brain development have a differential diagnosis that
includes Dandy-Walker syndrome, inferior vermis hypoplasia, physiological incompletely formed
inferior cerebellar vermis, and Joubert syndrome. The kidney abnormalities and polydactyly are
consistent with Joubert syndrome, and magnetic resonance imaging of the brain would be diagnostic
if the molar tooth sign is present (Figure).
Figure: Central nervous system in Joubert syndrome.
Reprinted with permission from Radiopaedia.org - (https://radiopaedia.org/cases/joubert-syndrome-12) - Case
courtesy of Dr Maxime St-Amant, rID: 22264

Joubert syndrome is a ciliopathy with multiple organ system manifestations and an incidence of
approximately 1 in 100,000 live births. The central nervous system is particularly impacted with
hypotonia, rapid breathing, abnormal eye movements, developmental disability, and ataxia. About a
quarter of individuals with Joubert syndrome will have nephronophthisis. Other organs that may be
involved include the eyes (coloboma, retinal dystrophy), liver (fibrosis), and skeleton (polydactyly).
Joubert syndrome has autosomal recessive inheritance, and mutations in at least 20 genes have
been implicated.
Many of the Joubert syndrome–related genes are also causative of nephronophthisis-related
ciliopathy (NEPHRC), for which mutations in at least 30 genes have been implicated. Renal disease
in NEPHRC involves progressive tubular atrophy, tubule basement membrane thinning, interstitial
inflammation, and fibrosis. On ultrasonography, the kidneys may show increased echogenicity that
progresses to small hyperechoic kidneys with poor corticomedullary differentiation. Magnetic
resonance imaging of the kidneys in this case would be nonspecific because there are a multitude of
diseases that cause echogenic kidneys in the newborn (Table 1).
Table 1. Selected Causes of Echogenic Kidneys in the Newborn.
● Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease ● Glomerulocystic kidney disease
● Autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease ● Tuberous sclerosis
● Renal vein thrombosis ● Orofaciodigital syndrome 1
● Congenital nephrotic syndrome ● Trisomy 13
● Renal candidiasis ● Jeune syndrome
● Renal leukemic infiltrate ● Nephronophthisis
● Diffuse cystic renal dysplasia ● Meckel syndrome
● Contrast nephromegaly ● Glutaric aciduria type 2
● Renal glycogen storage disease ● Zellweger syndrome
● Ivemark syndrome ● Goldston syndrome with
Dandy-Walker malformation
Created by D. Kershaw based on data collected from Slovis TL, Bernstein J, Gruskin A. Hyperechoic kidneys
in the newborn and young infant. Pediatr Nephrol. 1993;7(3):294-302.
Genetic diagnosis using whole exome sequencing in NEPHRC is complicated by the number of
genes involved and the overall low rate of mutation detection. Less than a third of phenotypic
NEPHRC patients have detectable mutations or deletions.
The extrarenal findings in NEPHRC can be important for diagnosis because many patients will have
chronic kidney disease with significant anemia, and the biopsy will show nonspecific interstitial
fibrosis and inflammation. In addition, many diseases that cause echogenic kidneys in the newborn
have extensive extrarenal manifestations (Table 2).

Table 2. Nonrenal Clinical Features of Syndromes Associated With Nephronophthisis.
Nonrenal Features Associated With Associated Syndromes
Nephronophthisis
Retinitis pigmentosa Senior-Loken syndrome
Hepatobiliary disease, liver fibrosis Senior-Boichis syndrome
Oculomotor apraxia Cogan syndrome
Cerebellar vermis hypoplasia Joubert syndrome
Neural tube defects Meckel-Gruber syndrome
Shortening of bones, limb deformity Saldino-Mainzer syndrome, short-rib polydactyly
syndrome, Jeune syndrome
Obesity Bardet-Biedl syndrome
Intellectual disability Joubert syndrome, Bardet-Biedl syndrome
Courtesy of A. Weinstein
Over time, the tubulointerstitial disease leads to a lack of concentration ability with polyuria,
polydipsia, and enuresis but no significant proteinuria early in younger children. In this case, urine
electrolyte levels would be unremarkable.
PREP Pearls
 Patients with a urinary concentrating defect should be evaluated for extrarenal manifestations of
nephronophthisis-related ciliopathies.
 Echogenic kidneys in the newborn have a broad differential diagnosis.
American Board of Pediatrics Content Specification(s)
 Know the laboratory and uroradiologic evaluation of nephronophthisis including prenatal diagnosis
Suggested Readings
 Schueler M, Halbritter J, Phelps IG, et al. Large-scale targeted sequencing comparison highlights extreme
genetic heterogeneity in nephronophthisis-related ciliopathies. J Med Genet. 2016;53(3):208-214.
doi: http://dx.doi.org/10.1136/jmedgenet-2015-103304
 Slovis TL, Bernstein J, Gruskin A. Hyperechoic kidneys in the newborn and young infant. Pediatr
Nephrol.1993;7(3):294-302.
 Stokman M, Lilien M, Knoers N. Nephronophthisis. GeneReviews. 2016.
 Wolf MT, Hildebrandt F. Nephronophthisis. Pediatr Nephrol. 2011;26(2):181-194.
doi: http://dx.doi.org/10.1007/s00467-010-1585-z

You are asked to consult on a 13-year-old girl with autoimmune hepatitis causing cirrhosis and portal
hypertension. She has been admitted to the hospital after an episode of gastrointestinal bleeding
without circulatory compromise. Endoscopy revealed grade III esophageal varices, which were
treated with sclerotherapy. The bleeding episode was followed by an acute renal dysfunction with a
serum creatinine level increased to 1.5 mg/dL (133 μmol/L) from a baseline level of 0.8 mg/dL (71
μmol/L) and oliguria, which has not improved after adequate fluid expansion with blood and albumin
infusions during the last 3 days. Her bilirubin level is 15 mg/dL (256.6 μmol/L), serum albumin is 2.5
g/dL (25 g/L), prothrombin time is 20 seconds, and alanine aminotransferase level is 664 U/L. Her
serum sodium levels decreased from 135 to 127 mEq/L (135 to 127 mmol/L). Urinalysis reveals no
protein or blood, a urine specific gravity of 1.025, normal urine sediment and renal ultrasonography
findings. Her urine sodium level is 10 mEq/L (10 mmol/L), and her urine creatinine level is 60 mg/dL
(5,304 μmol/L).
In addition to intravenous 25% albumin, the medication MOST likely to improve her acute kidney
injury is
options: dopamine
furosemide
norepinephrine
spironolactone
explanation:
C. norepinephrine
The patient described in the vignette fulfills the criteria for hepatorenal syndrome (HRS). Of the
choices provided for treatment options, diuretics, which may be used for the treatment of portal
hypertension, would worsen circulating volume. Dopamine, with its partial vasodilatory properties,
could worsen the acute kidney injury (AKI). Therefore, these agents are not the appropriate.
Norepinephrine has been used in the United States for splanchnic vasoconstriction and raising blood
pressure in HRS.
Hepatorenal syndrome describes functional renal failure in patients with chronic liver disease;
however, renal histologic findings would appear unchanged, and tubular function appears intact.
Reportedly, patients with HRS recover kidney function after liver transplantation, and their kidneys
have even been used as renal allografts for kidney transplantation.
The pathophysiology is secondary to splanchnic vasodilatation because of portal hypertension, which
in turn leads to decreased effective circulatory volume, and subsequent decreased glomerular
filtration rate. Activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system worsens this cycle and also
leads to sodium retention. Abnormal renal autoregulation and cirrhotic cardiomyopathy perpetuate
this vicious cycle (Figure).
Figure: The vasodilatation hypothesis of hepatorenal Syndrome.
Reprinted with permission from Adebayo D, Morabito V, Davenport A, Jalan R. Renal dysfunction in cirrhosis is not
just a vasomotor nephropathy. Kidney Int. 2015;87:509–515.

Two types of HRS are recognized. Type 1 has an acute onset of renal failure (within 2 weeks),
whereas type 2 HRS has a more gradual decline in renal function.
The original criteria for diagnosis of HRS included minor criteria, such as urine volume less than 500
mL/d, urine sodium less than 10 mEq/L (10 mmol/L), urine osmolality greater than plasma osmolality,
and a serum sodium concentration less than 130 mEq/L (130 mmol/L). The major criteria initially
included a measured 24-hour creatinine clearance of less than 40 mL/min/1.73 m2 (0.67 mL/s/m2).
Over time, the creatinine clearance criteria was removed and the urine volume and sodium level
criteria were also removed due to nonspecificity. However, a urine sodium level less than 10 mEq/L
(10 mmol/L) helps us differentiate HRS from acute tubular necrosis and other organic causes.
There are problems with these criteria for the pediatric nephrologist, the first being not pediatric
friendly because it relies on an absolute creatinine concentration. Secondly, serum creatinine is not a
good marker of renal function because patients with cirrhosis are malnourished and have increased
creatinine secretion as well.
Potential refinements to this criteria are to include Kidney Disease: Improving Global Outcomes
criteria in diagnosing AKI and the use of newer biomarkers, such as cystatin C and neutrophil
gelatinase-associated lipocalin. Studies are underway to validate these measures.
Prevention strategies focus on avoidance of renal injury in patients with cirrhosis are proposed in
‘World J Nephrol. 2015;4(5):511-520 to include:
 Minimize exposure to iodinated contrast agents
 Prescribe intravenous albumin for volemic filling after large volume paracentesis
 Suspend or limit diuretic therapy
 Prescribe antibiotics to prophylactically prevent infections reducing intestinal bacterial translocation
 Identify and treat adrenal insufficiency
 Adjust drug dosages according to renal function
 Avoid drugs that reduce renal perfusion or nephrotoxic substances
When treating HRS, medical therapy primarily targets the causes by the principal pathogenetic
mechanism. The treatment approach cause splanchnic vasoconstriction, which reduces portal
hypertension. This in turn increases the circulating volume, which improves renal perfusion. The
vasoconstrictor agents that are used are terlipressin, norepinephrine, and midodrine.
The treatment of choice for HRS is intravenous terlipressin with albumin. In addition to expanding
the the circulating volume; albumin binds to bile acids, bilirubin, and endotoxins produced in liver
dysfunction, thereby exerting metabolic and some immune effects as well. This combination has a
favorable outcome in 40% to 60% of patients. Once the serum creatinine level is below 1.5 mg/dL
(133 μmol/L), the treatment is stopped in adults. The recovery time is between 1 and 2 weeks, and
after 2 weeks, if there is no improvement, treatment should be stopped. Recurrence is seen in almost
50% of patients. However, terlipressin is not available in the United States and Canada.
Norepinephrine, which is an ɑ-adrenergic agent, has also been used in HRS. The aim of treatment is
to increase the mean arterial pressure by 10 mm Hg, thereby increasing urine output. Another
alternative to norepinephrine is midodrine, another ?-adrenergic agent. It is a prodrug metabolized to
its active metabolite desglymidodrine by the liver. Midodrine is used in combination with octreotide,
which is a somatostatin analog and splanchnic vasodilator; this combination has a 50% chance of

reversing HRS. Octreotide alone has no effect on kidney function in HRS. Both norepinephrine and
the midodrine-octreotide combination have been used in the United States for HRS.
Some other modalities that are tried in HRS and outlined in ‘World J Nephrol. 2015;4(5):511-520’ are
as follows:
 Transjugular Intrahepatic Portosystemic Shunt - The transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt
increases venous return to the right side of the heart and increases the effective blood volume, thereby
improving renal function in HRS.
 Renal Replacement Therapy - Indications for renal replacement therapy (RRT) are no different than
any other cause of AKI. RRT is used as a bridging therapy for HRS until liver transplantation; however,
there is no evidence of improvement of survival of patients awaiting liver transplantation.
 Extracorporeal Artificial Liver Support Therapy - Although RRT improves removal of water soluble
toxins, such as ammonia, most toxins that accumulate in liver failure are albumin bound and are not
removed by conventional RRT. Liver support therapies are designed to remove both albumin-bound
and water-soluble toxins and have been used as bridging therapies for patients awaiting liver
transplantation.
 Liver Transplantation - Liver transplantation is the treatment of choice for HRS. However, recovery of
renal function is not universal. In fact, a quarter of patients did not recover renal function in a small
series of 28 patients with HRS who underwent liver transplantation. Even with renal recovery, although
sodium excretion and renal function normalize within a month, renovascular resistance may take longer
to recover (as much as a year).
All of these treatment recommendations are based mainly on adult experience.
PREP Pearls
 Hepatorenal syndrome is traditionally ascribed to functional acute kidney injury in patients with chronic liver
disease associated with no significant morphologic changes in renal histologic features and with largely
preserved tubular function.
 The ideal treatment is to improve liver function by causing splanchnic vasoconstriction, which reduces portal
hypertension and thereby increases circulating volume, which in turn causes renal vasodilation.
American Board of Pediatrics Content Specification(s)
 Understand ways of preventing and treating hepatorenal syndrome
Suggested Readings
 Adebayo D, Morabito V, Davenport A, Jalan R. Renal dysfunction in cirrhosis is not just a vasomotor
nephropathy. Kidney Int. 2015;87:509–515. doi: http://dx.doi.org/10.1038/ki.2014.338
 Baraldi O, Valentini C, Donati G, et al. Hepatorenal syndrome: update on diagnosis and treatment. World J
Nephrol. 2015;4(5):511-520. doi: http://dx.doi.org/10.5527/wjn.v4.i5.511

You are evaluating a 7-year-old boy who has headache and dark urine. He was diagnosed with type
1 diabetes mellitus 1 year ago. He had an upper respiratory infection about a week ago. He takes
insulin for his diabetes, which is well managed; otherwise, he takes no other medications or
supplements. His blood pressure is 140/90 mm Hg, and he has mild periorbital and pitting edema.
The remainder of his physical examination is normal. Laboratory results are shown:
Laboratory Test Result
White blood cell count Normal
Hemoglobin 10.2 g/dL (102 g/L)
Platelet count Normal
Electrolytes Normal
Blood urea nitrogen 46 mg/dL (16 mmol/L)
Creatinine 2.3 mg/dL (203 µmol/L)
Albumin 3.6 g/dL (36 g/L)
The remainder of the liver function test results are normal. Urinalysis results are positive for large
blood, large leukocyte esterase, and 1+ protein.
Further evaluation of the most likely cause of his acute kidney injury is MOST likely to reveal
options: eosinophils in the urine
normal complement levels
positive anti-streptococcal serologies
schistocytes
explanation:
C. positive anti-streptococcal serologies
This 7-year-old boy with acute kidney injury (AKI) has findings suggestive of an acute
glomerulonephritis. Given the recent respiratory illness and high prevalence of streptococcal infection
in school-aged children, an infection-associated glomerulonephritis, such as post-streptococcal
glomerulonephritis (PSGN), is most likely. With PSGN, complement 3 levels would be expected to be
low. Both hematuria and pyuria are common with PSGN, and the pyuria is generally a predominance
of neutrophils rather than eosinophils. Eosinophils might be expected in medication-induced
tubulointerstitial nephritis; however, the boy in this vignette has not taken medications that cause
tubulointerstitial nephritis. His recent infection could be consistent with an infectious trigger for
tubulointerstitial nephritis; however, this condition is much less common than PSGN. Schistocytes in
the blood might be expected with a thrombotic microangiopathy. These microangiopathies, in
particular hemolytic uremic syndrome, can lead to AKI; however, in this case, thrombocytopenia
would also be expected.
The etiologies of AKI include decreased circulatory volume and impaired renal perfusion, intrinsic
injury to the kidney, or obstruction of outflow from the kidney. The intrinsic causes of AKI include
glomerular etiologies and tubulointerstitial etiologies, including tubulointerstitial nephritis. Another
common tubulointerstitial cause of AKI is acute tubular necrosis from hypoxic kidney injury or
nephrotoxic kidney injury. Glomerular etiologies for AKI are now less common than tubulointerstitial
causes; however, they remain important to consider in the differential diagnosis. Any
glomerulonephritis, if sufficiently severe in presentation and pathology, may present with AKI. Certain
glomerular disorders, such as hemolytic uremic syndrome, and pulmonary renal syndromes, such as
antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibody–associated vasculitides, typically present severely and are
commonly associated with AKI. But, common glomerular disorders, such as PSGN and IgA
nephropathy, can have severe presentations with AKI and require renal replacement therapy.
PREP Pearls
 Acute kidney injury may be caused by decreased circulatory volume and impaired renal perfusion, intrinsic
injury to the kidney, or obstruction of outflow from the kidney.
 Intrinsic causes of kidney injury include glomerular etiologies and tubulointerstitial etiologies.
 Any glomerulonephritis, if sufficiently severe in presentation and pathology, may present with acute kidney
injury, including conditions such as postinfectious glomerulonephritis and IgA nephropathy that typically have
less severe presentations.
American Board of Pediatrics Content Specification(s)
 Recognize that certain primary kidney disorders (such as hemolytic-uremic syndrome, glomerular disorders,
and tubulointerstitial nephritis) may present with acute kidney injury
Suggested Readings
 Selewski DT, Symons JM. Acute kidney injury. Pediatr Rev. 2014;35(1):30-41.
doi: http://dx.doi.org/10.1542/pir.35-1-30

A healthy 5-year-old girl was seen in her pediatrician’s office for a well-child visit. Urinalysis showed a
specific gravity 1.020, no protein or blood, 3+ glucose, and a normal microscopic analysis. The child
reports occasional loose stools but has normal growth parameters and blood pressure. A urine test
strip analysis performed 1 week later confirmed the isolated presence of glucose in the urine. Serum
electrolytes obtained in the fasting state were within normal limits, including a blood glucose
concentration of 95 mg/dL (5.3 mmol/L). Her parents are inquiring if their daughter has diabetes
mellitus, given that her maternal aunt has type 2 diabetes. The pediatrician refers the patient to the
pediatric nephrology clinic for further management and parental counseling.
Of the following diagnoses, the MOST likely cause of glucosuria in this patient is
options: Fanconi-Bickel syndrome
glucose-galactose malabsorption
intermittent hyperglycemia associated with early diabetes mellitus
isolated renal glucosuria
explanation:
D. isolated renal glucosuria
The girl in this vignette has asymptomatic isolated glucosuria in the absence of proteinuria,
phosphaturia, acidosis, or clinical signs of rickets. She also has normal growth and development.
Most importantly, she has normoglycemia. Accordingly, the most likely cause of glucosuria in this
patient is isolated renal glucosuria, also known as hereditary glucosuria or familial renal glucosuria.
Renal glucose reabsorption occurs in the proximal tubule and is achieved by the concerted actions of
luminal and basolateral transporters. The S2 segment of the proximal convoluted tubule expresses a
luminal sodium-dependent glucose transporter (SGLT2), which is a low-affinity high-capacity glucose
transporter encoded by SLC5A2. Following transport by SGLT2, glucose is transported out of the cell
to the peritubular capillaries via the sodium-independent transporter GLUT2, which is encoded
by SLC2A2. The concerted actions of SGLT2 and GLUT2 mediate the bulk of glucose absorption in
the early proximal tubule. The late or straight S3 segment of the proximal tubule expresses a luminal
high-affinity, low-capacity sodium-glucose transporter called SGLT1, which is encoded by SLC5A1,
and a basolateral sodium-independent transporter GLUT1, which is encoded by SLC2A1. These 2
transporters mediate absorption of the filtered glucose that escaped reabsorption in the early proximal
tubule. SGLT1 has affinity for both glucose and galactose.
Under normal conditions, the urine is glucose-free. Physiologic glucosuria occurs in premature
infants. Tubular reabsorption of glucose matures by 30 weeks of gestation. Glucosuria occasionally
occurs in patients with heavy proteinuria and damage to the early proximal tubule, such as patients
with early focal and segmental glomerulosclerosis. Glucosuria, generalized aminoaciduria,
phosphaturia, renal tubular acidosis, and rickets occur in patients with renal Fanconi syndrome
caused by disorders such as cystinosis, Fanconi-Bickel syndrome, toxic nephropathies, and
tyrosinemia. Of course, glucosuria is a cardinal sign of hyperglycemia when filtered glucose exceeds
the tubular maximum for glucose of the proximal tubule.
The presence of isolated glucosuria in the absence of fasting hyperglycemia in an otherwise healthy
child should raise suspicion for familial renal glucosuria (OMIM [Online Mendelian Inheritance in Man]
phenotype #233100), an autosomal recessive disorder of renal glucose reabsorption. Familial renal
glucosuria is caused by mutations in SLC5A2, which encodes SGLT2. Patients with familial renal
glucosuria are typically asymptomatic, except in some cases during pregnancy or extreme starvation.
Familial renal glucosuria is not associated with intestinal malabsorption of glucose, hence the lack of
significant gastrointestinal symptoms. Patients with mutations in SLC2A2, which encodes GLUT2,
manifest Fanconi-Bickel syndrome, which is characterised by aminoaciduria, phosphaturia, and
rickets, in addition to glucosuria. Patients typically also have hepatosplenomegaly. Presumably,
accumulation of excess glucose in the cell harms the proximal tubular cell, causing apoptosis and a
generalized proximal tubulopathy. Mutations in SLC5A1, which encodes SGLT1, cause glucose-
galactose malabsorption in the kidney and intestine. This autosomal recessive disorder may be fatal,
causing severe neonatal diarrhea, if not recognized early and treated by elimination of glucose and
galactose from the diet.
The patient in this vignette does not have a generalized tubulopathy caused by Fanconi-Bickel
syndrome, hyperglycemia caused by diabetes mellitus, or glucose-galactose malabsorption.
PREP Pearls
 Isolated renal glucosuria is generally a benign disorder of renal glucose transport caused by mutations in the
luminal sodium-dependent glucose transporter 2, which is expressed in the S2 segment of the early proximal
tubule.

 Mutations in the basolateral glucose transporter 2 cause Fanconi-Bickel syndrome, a generalized proximal
tubulopathy and glucosuria.
 Hereditary renal glucosuria (mutations in sodium-dependent glucose transporter 2) should be distinguished
from glucose-galactose malabsorption (mutations in sodium-dependent glucose transporter 1), given the
significantly different clinical courses and management of these 2 disorders.
American Board of Pediatrics Content Specification(s)
 Know the differential diagnosis of glucosuria
Suggested Readings
 Santer R, Calado J. Familial renal glucosuria and SGLT2: from a Mendelian trait to a therapeutic target. Clin J
Am Soc Nephrol. 2010;5(1):133-141. doi: http://dx.doi.org/10.2215/CJN.04010609
 Thorens B, Mueckler M. Glucose transporters in the 21st century. Am J Physiol Endocrinol Metab. 2010;
298(2):E141-E145. doi: http://dx.doi.org/10.1152/ajpendo.00712.2009

stem:
A 6-week-old male infant is referred to you for evaluation of antenatal hydronephrosis.
Ultrasonography performed at 28 weeks’ gestation revealed unilateral hydronephrosis. His mother
had an uneventful pregnancy. Ultrasonography performed 2 days after birth demonstrated moderate
left-sided hydronephrosis. The ureter was not visualized. During the next 6 weeks, he had an
uncomplicated course. Prior to your visit today, he underwent 99mTc MAG3 (mercaptoacetyltriglycine)
diuretic renography that demonstrated retention of radiotracer in the left renal pelvis with delayed
excretion as compared to the right side after furosemide administration.
Of the following, the MOST likely cause of this condition is
options: abnormal collections of collagen and smooth muscle fibers and an adynamic segment of the ureter
a benign fibroepithelial outgrowth within the lumen of the ureter leading to a valve-like obstruction
ectopic ureteric bud induction leading to an ectopic distal ureteral insertion in the vas deferens
extrinsic compression of the ureter caused by an aberrant left renal vein
explanation:
A. abnormal collections of collagen and smooth muscle fibers and an adynamic segment of the
ureter
The patient in this vignette has a ureteropelvic junction (UPJ) obstruction leading to hydronephrosis.
He has unilateral hydronephrosis without hydroureter, suggesting that the lesion is above the
ureterovesical junction. The MAG3 (mercaptoacetyltriglycine) scan findings of left-sided radiotracer
retention with delayed excretion suggest an obstruction and not a physiologic or nonobstructive cause
of hydronephrosis. Voiding cystourethrography in the clinical setting of UPJ obstruction should not
demonstrate bladder or urethral abnormalities or reflux.
Ureteropelvic junction obstructions are the second leading pathologic cause of antenatal
hydronephrosis; the most common cause is vesicoureteral reflux. Ureteropelvic junction obstructions
are relatively common and occur in 1 per 1,000 to 2,000 newborns. Pathophysiological causes can be
categorized as extramural, mural, or intramural in regards to the site of the ureteral abnormality
leading to obstruction. The most common cause of UPJ obstruction in the newborn is mural causes.
Kajbafzadeh et al assessed histologic components of the UPJ following pyeloplasty in 23 patients
with obstruction as compared to 25 autopsies from patients without UPJ obstruction. They found that
smooth muscle cell apoptosis was increased in the obstructed segment of the ureter as compared to
nonobstructed segments within the same patients and the autopsy controls. They also found a higher
amount of collagen deposition and lower number of nerve endings at the site of obstruction. These
histologic findings appear to result in the adynamic segment of ureter and subsequent obstruction.
Less commonly, extramural impingement of the ureter by surrounding structures can also cause UPJ
obstruction. Aberrant vessels or adhesions can lead to intermittent extrinsic compression of the ureter
but are more rare than mural abnormalities. Intramural obstructions such as fibroepithelial outgrowths
can also cause UPJ obstruction by occluding the lumen of the ureter. However, these lesions are a
very rare cause of UPJ obstruction in newborns. Finally, while an ectopic ureteric bud can lead to
abnormal interaction with the metanephric mesenchyme and a theoretically abnormal UPJ, response
choice C suggests that an ectopic insertion distally would manifest itself more as a ureterovesical
junction obstruction rather than a proximal ureter obstruction.
PREP Pearls
 Ureteropelvic junction obstruction is most commonly associated with abnormal collections of collagen and
smooth muscle fibers within the ureter and an adynamic segment of the ureter.
 External compression and intraluminal obstructions are rare causes of ureteropelvic junction obstruction.
American Board of Pediatrics Content Specification(s)
 Know how to diagnose and evaluate obstructive lesions at the ureterovesicular junction and the ureteropelvic
junction
 Know how to diagnose and evaluate obstructive lesions at the ureterovesicular junction and the ureteropelvic
junction
Suggested Readings
 Kajbafzadeh AM, Payabvash S, Salmasi AH, Monajemzadeh M, Tavangar SM. Smooth muscle cell apoptosis
and defective neural development in congenital ureteropelvic junction obstruction. J Urol. 2006;176:718-723.
doi: http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.juro.2006.03.041
 Lorenzo AJ, Csaicsich D, Aufricht C, Khoury AE. Obstructive genitourinary disorders. In: Geary D, Schaefer F,
eds.Comprehensive Pediatric Nephrology. Philadelphia, PA: Mosby Elsevier; 2008:561-586.

stem:
A 16-year-old male adolescent visits his primary care provider for evaluation of severe muscle
cramping associated with soccer practice. He was recently promoted to the varsity team, and his
practices have been on particularly hot days. He has otherwise been healthy, but he notes that he is
prone to muscle cramping, either with vigorous activity or with intercurrent illnesses like
gastroenteritis. On physical examination, his blood pressure is normal, perfusion is normal, and there
are no focal findings; strength is full and symmetric. Reflexes are 2+ bilaterally. Laboratory data are
shown:
Laboratory Test Result
Sodium 135 mEq/L (135 mmol/L)
Potassium 2.6 mEq/L (2.6 mmol/L)
Chloride 92 mEq/L (92 mmol/L)
Carbon dioxide 34 mEq/L (34 mmol/L)
Blood urea nitrogen 14 mg/dL (5 mmol/L)
Creatinine 0.7 mg/dL (62 µmol/L)
Calcium 9.6 mg/dL (2.4 mmol/L)
Magnesium 1.3 mEq/dL (0.65 mmol/L)
The urine calcium-creatinine ratio is 0.06 mg/mg.
Of the following, the MOST appropriate first step in the management of this patient’s condition is
options: high sodium and high potassium diet
ibuprofen
lisinopril
spironolactone
explanation:
A. high sodium and high potassium diet
The teenager in this vignette most likely has Gitelman syndrome, which is caused by autosomal
recessive loss-of-function of the sodium-chloride cotransporter expressed on the apical membranes
of distal convoluted tubular cells. This loss of function leads to inappropriate loss of sodium chloride in
the urine and resulting hypovolemia. The hypovolemia stimulates the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone
system, enhancing excretion of K+ and H+ in the cortical collecting duct, leading to hypokalemia and
metabolic alkalosis. Loss of function of the sodium-chloride cotransporter also leads to impaired
magnesium reabsorption by the distal convoluted tubule and resulting hypomagnesemia. Because of
the activated renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system and compensatory mechanisms to enhance
sodium reabsorption in the proximal convoluted tubule and thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle,
calcium reabsorption is also stimulated through paracellular mechanisms. Therefore, urine calcium
levels are normal or even somewhat low, which helps to distinguish Gitelman Syndrome from Bartter
syndrome.
The teenager in this vignette displays all of the diagnostic features of Gitelman syndrome, including
hypovolemia (worse during vigorous activity or dehydrating illness), hypokalemia, metabolic alkalosis,
hypomagnesemia, and normal urine calcium levels. Gitelman syndrome typically presents in school-
aged children, teenagers, or young adults, in contrast to Bartter syndrome, which often presents in
the neonatal period. This difference is because the loop of Henle, the site of the dysfunction in Bartter
syndrome, is responsible for reabsorbing a much greater sodium/volume load as compared to the
distal convoluted tubule. Presenting symptoms of Gitelman syndrome are hypovolemia, hypokalemia,
and/or hypomagnesemia (eg, weakness, muscle cramps), which are escalated during vigorous
activity or dehydrating illness. Complications are generally directly related to fluid and electrolyte
abnormalities. Notably, glomerular filtration rate and other renal functional parameters are generally
maintained in Gitelman syndrome, whereas the hypercalciuria in Bartter syndrome can lead to
nephrocalcinosis, tubulointerstitial damage, and eventual progressive impairment in glomerular
filtration rate.
The first step in the treatment of Gitelman syndrome is to replace the urinary losses of sodium
chloride and potassium with a high sodium, high potassium diet. Most patients naturally crave this
diet and may have already adopted it prior to diagnosis. A diet high in magnesium is also indicated.
Potassium and magnesium supplements are often required in addition to dietary management.
Lisinopril or spironolactone can be considered to manage the often very significant hypokalemia
associated with Gitelman syndrome. However, these medications block important compensatory
mechanisms for hypovolemia, so they should not be first-line therapies for Gitelman syndrome;
rather, they should only be used for severe, refractory, symptomatic hypokalemia. When these
medications are started, the patient requires close monitoring for signs and symptoms of worsening
hypovolemia. Ibuprofen can also be a helpful therapy, mitigating the amount of sodium chloride
wasting that occurs by constricting the afferent arteriole of the glomerulus. This is a mainstay of
treatment for Bartter syndrome, but is not always necessary in Gitelman syndrome; so, it is not
considered a first-line therapy. Chronic ibuprofen use can result in gastric irritation and worsening
kidney function.
PREP Pearls
 Gitelman syndrome, which is caused by loss of function of the sodium-chloride cotransporter, presents with
hypovolemia, hypokalemia, metabolic alkalosis, and hypomagnesemia.
 Initial treatment should include a diet high in sodium, potassium, and magnesium. Most patients also require
potassium and magnesium supplementation.

 Angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors and aldosterone antagonists may also be used to treat hypokalemia
but carry risks of worsening hypovolemia; therefore, patient monitoring is needed if these medications are
started.
American Board of Pediatrics Content Specification(s)
 Know the clinical and laboratory features of Gitelman syndrome
 Know the treatment and the complications of treatment for Gitelman syndrome
Suggested Readings
 Seyberth HW. Pathophysiology and clinical presentations of salt-losing tubulopathies. Pediatr
Nephrol.2016;31(3):407-418. doi: http://dx.doi.org/10.1007/s00467-015-3143-1

stem:
You are planning a multicenter research project that will investigate possible microbial triggers for
relapse of childhood nephrotic syndrome. You will prospectively collect blood, urine, stool, and nasal
swab samples from 100 children with steroid-responsive nephrotic syndrome at initial presentation, at
first remission, at onset of first relapse, and at remission from first relapse. Your hypothesis is that
viral infections trigger a relapse. You will perform unbiased nucleic acid sequencing from the samples
for known viral genome sequences and associate the biological data to the clinical events.
In preparation for handling the large amount of data that you expect to collect and analyze, you will
need to
options: compare your sequences to known reference genomes in international biological databases
confirm any identified nucleic acid sequences by targeted western blotting
use multiple comparisons to overcome sampling error
utilize manual methods of data reduction and analysis
explanation:
A. compare your sequences to known reference genomes in international biological databases
This vignette highlights the challenges of modern technologies that can provide enormous amounts of
biological data and the role of bioinformatics.
According to the National Center for Biotechnology Information (Molecular Biology Review:
Bioinformatics. National Center for Biotechnology Information
website. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/Class/MLACourse/Modules/MolBioReview/bioinformatics.html):
Bioinformatics is the field of science in which biology, computer science, and information technology
merge into a single discipline. There are three important sub-disciplines within bioinformatics: the
development of new algorithms and statistics with which to assess relationships among members of
large data sets; the analysis and interpretation of various types of data including nucleotide and
amino acid sequences, protein domains, and protein structures; and the development and
implementation of tools that enable efficient access and management of different types of information.
Bioinformatics includes all of the “omics,” such as genomics, proteomics, and metabolomics (Figure).
Figure. Schematic overview of main OMICS data.
Adapted and reprinted with permission from Chadeau-Hyam M. Campanella G, Jombart T, et al. Deciphering
the complex: methodological overview of statistical models to derive OMICS-based biomarkers. Environ Mol
Mutagen. 2013;54(7):542-557.
The flood of data from biology, mainly in the form of DNA, RNA, and protein sequences, has placed a
heavy demand on computers and computational scientists, while also demanding a transformation of
the basic ethos of biological sciences. These activities have generated terabytes of data that are
being analyzed with computer, statistical, and machine learning techniques.
Bioinformatics represents the convergence of genomics, biotechnology, and information technology
and encompasses analysis and interpretation of data, modeling of biological phenomena, and
development of algorithms and statistics. Bioinformatics has typically been used to describe the
analytics applied to basic research (T1 informatics) or translational studies (T2 informatics). In
contrast, clinical informatics is more specific to improving health care and encompasses implementing
and evaluating guidelines (T3 informatics) as well as using data from clinical practice epidemiology
and population health to inform research (T4 informatics). In each case, the challenges are similar.

To address the large data problem, several organizations have created large, open access,
multinational biological databases. For example, a genome biodatabase can comprise sequence data
from many genome sequencing projects worldwide.Most of these tools are available over the Internet.
As the databases continue to grow, mining them offers newer challenges.
The field of bioinformatics has evolved such that the most pressing task now involves the analysis
and interpretation of various types of data, which include nucleotide and amino acid sequences,
protein domains, and protein structures. Therefore, bioinformatics also includes the development and
implementation of computer programs that enable efficient access to, use, and management of
various types of information. It also includes the development of algorithms and statistical measures
that assess relationships among members of large data sets.
The statistical testing of mega data sets has imposed serious methodological challenges. One of the
challenges is the “small n, large p” problem, wherein a relatively small number of observations “n” (in
this vignette, n = 100) was greatly exceeded by the number of measurements “p” or variables (in this
vignette, several thousands or more). Theoretically, every measurement or variable could be tested
for each observation, but then by chance alone, some associations might be deemed significant. Two
strategies are used to address this problem. First, the measurements can be reduced to smaller
groups by building upon the biological correlation within the data, eg, viruses that cluster together
phylogenetically can be lumped into one group by evolutionary algorithms. Second, multiple statistical
correction strategies have to be used. Multiple comparisons cannot overcome sampling error; in fact
a lower p-value is needed to achieve significance. The Table details some of the most common
methods for statistical analyses of mega datasets.
Table. Common Statistical Methods of Analyzing Very Large Biological Datasets.
Method Family Model
Univariate approaches Regression: linear, logistic, poisson, linear mixed models
Dimension reduction Principal component analysis, discriminant analysis, penalized dimension
strategies regression methods
Variable selection Evolutionary stochastic search, ridge regression
Courtesy of V. Dharnidharka.
Based on data collected from Schmidt A, Forne I, Imhof A. Bioinformatic analyses of proteomic data. BMC Syst Biol.
2014;8:(suppl 2)S3.
Western blotting is used to identify protein sequences, not DNA sequences, which are generally
confirmed by targeted polymerase chain reaction. The “large p, small n” problem cannot be ignored,
as discussed above. Computers and software packages are used to analyze these large datasets;
manual analysis would take months to years. The only correct option is that the sequences generated
must be compared to known viral sequences in publicly available datasets for identification.
PREP Pearls
 The newer technologies generate very large masses of data, requiring bioinformatics techniques.
 Multiple international databases exist to provide easy access to known biological DNA, RNA, and protein
sequences.
American Board of Pediatrics Content Specification(s)
 Understand the role of bioinformatics with mass data handling

You have just diagnosed a 16-year-old adolescent girl with primary hypertension. She is
asymptomatic and her average blood pressure is just below the 99th percentile for her age, sex, and
height percentile. She has no comorbidities other than being overweight, and her echocardiogram
results are unremarkable.
Of the following, which is the BEST initial treatment approach for this patient?
options: initiate a calcium channel blocker as she works on prescribed lifestyle modifications
limit sodium intake to 2 g/d
start exercising 30 min/d on most days of the week
work on weight loss to achieve a normal body mass index
explanation:
D. work on weight loss to achieve a normal body mass index
All children who are diagnosed with primary or secondary hypertension should be counseled on
therapeutic lifestyle changes (Table).
Table. Recommended Therapeutic Lifestyle Changes.
Lose weight if overweight, with a goal of:
● Body mass index < 85th percentile if < 20 years of age
● Body mass index < 25 kg/m2 if ≥ 20 years of age
Achieve ≥ 1 hour of moderate to vigorous exercise (eg, jogging, baseball) every daya
Engage in vigorous activity (eg, running, tennis, soccer) on 3 d/wk
Decrease sedentary activities (television and video games) to < 2 h/d
Institute the Cardiovascular Health Integrated Lifestyle diet (CHILD-1 ) and DASH eating plan:
● Increase intake of fresh vegetables, fruits, and low-fat dairy
● Reduced carbohydrate, fat, and processed sugar intake
● Limit/avoid sugar-sweetened beverages
● Encourage foods with high dietary fiber content (age + 5 = number of grams per day)
Limit sodium intake
Stop smoking
Abbreviation: DASH, Dietary Approaches to Stop Hypertension.
aFor children ≥ 5 years of age
Courtesy of T. Brady
Each component of these recommended modifications lowers blood pressure, and there is evidence
for an amplified response when the modifications are adopted together. If an asymptomatic child with
primary hypertension and no target organ damage is unsuccessful in making the recommended
lifestyle changes or remains hypertensive after 6 to 12 months of therapeutic lifestyle changes, then
an antihypertensive medication should be prescribed. In contrast, children with secondary
hypertension, symptomatic hypertension, type 1 or 2 diabetes, or left ventricular hypertrophy should
be prescribed an antihypertensive medication at diagnosis while also working on a heart healthy
lifestyle.
Body size is a determinant of blood pressure in children. Across all ages, increasing body weight is
associated with increasing blood pressure and with hypertension. Weight loss lowers blood pressure
in children and adults. In adults, a 5% reduction in body weight decreases systolic blood pressure by
1.8 to 3.8 mm Hg. Although weight loss has not been as extensively studied in children, overweight
and obese children who lose weight may have a more substantial drop in systolic blood pressure,
with studies reporting a decrease ranging from 6 to 16 mm Hg. Because of this beneficial
cardiovascular effect of weight loss, all children with hypertension should be counseled on the
importance of maintaining a normal body mass index. Furthermore, among children with obesity-
related primary hypertension, weight loss should be considered first-line therapy. In this patient
population, weight loss is not only effective, but it addresses the underlying cause, improves
comorbidities, and reduces sympathetic nervous system activation that contributes to the
development of hypertension in the overweight or obese individual.
Exercise is also effective in reducing blood pressure. Children who engage in moderate to vigorous
activity are less likely to have elevated blood pressure and hypertension than children who are less
active. The effect of exercise on blood pressure is more pronounced when it is sustained and when it
is combined with weight loss.
The impact of diet quality and sodium reduction on blood pressure is best demonstrated in adults in
the Dietary Approaches to Stop Hypertension (DASH) and DASH-Sodium trials. Independently,

improving diet quality (increased intake of fruits, vegetables, low-fat dairy) and decreasing sodium
intake each lowers blood pressure among adults. Systolic blood pressure was reduced by 6.6 mm Hg
(95% confidence interval, 4.0 to 9.1 mm Hg) when following a DASH diet with a high sodium intake
(compared to a usual diet with high sodium intake) and by 8.3 mm Hg (95% confidence interval, 6.6
to 10.0 mm Hg) when following a low sodium diet in the setting of a usual diet (compared to a low
sodium usual diet) among adults with hypertension. When implemented together (a DASH diet plus
sodium reduction), blood pressure is lowered even further; systolic blood pressure was reduced by
11.5 mm Hg (95% confidence interval, 8.9 to 14.1 mm Hg) when a low sodium, DASH diet was
followed. These adult studies have formed the basis of the Dietary Guidelines for Americans and the
Cardiovascular Health Integrated Lifestyle Diet (CHILD-1) described in the Table.
The guidelines are vague regarding sodium intake, recommending only to “limit sodium intake.” The
Institute of Medicine provides recommended sodium intake by age, with the following maximum
recommended daily intake:
 1 to 3 years of age, 1,500 mg
 4 to 8 years of age, 1,900 mg
 9 to 13 years of age, 2,200 mg
 14 to 18 years of age, 2,300 mg
The 2010 Dietary Guidelines for Americans recommend that the general population ingest less than
2,300 mg/d of sodium. Individuals with certain characteristics (age > 50 years; African American race;
history of hypertension, diabetes, or chronic kidney disease) should target a daily sodium intake of
less than 1,500 mg. These guidelines do not provide specific recommended intakes for children. The
Dietary Guidelines for Americans were updated in 2015 and, while not specifically addressing
children, recommended that sodium intake remain less than 2,300 mg/d for the general population or
below age-appropriate upper limits established by the Institute of Medicine.
Smoking increases cardiovascular disease risk and can lead to blood pressure elevations, particularly
within 30 minutes of smoking. Many individuals begin smoking cigarettes in their teenage years, so
regular screening for tobacco use and cessation counseling is important in this age group.
The patient in this vignette is an asymptomatic adolescent with primary, stage I hypertension. She
has no comorbidities or evidence of target organ damage, so the immediate initiation of an
antihypertensive medication is not warranted. Excess weight may be contributing to her hypertension,
so weight loss should be a priority in the management approach. In addition, she should be
counseled on implementing the other components of a heart healthy lifestyle (Table). These healthy
behaviors include an hour of moderate to vigorous activity each day and limiting sodium intake.
PREP Pearls
 Therapeutic lifestyle change should be prescribed to all children who are diagnosed with hypertension.
 Weight loss should be prescribed to all children with a body mass index greater than the 85th percentile and all
young adults older than 20 years with a body mass index greater than 25 kg/m2 who are also hypertensive.
American Board of Pediatrics Content Specification(s)
 Understand the contribution of diet, BMI, and exercise to blood pressure control

Suggested Readings
 Appel LJ, Lichtenstein AH, Callahan EA, Sinaiko A, Van Horn L, Whitsel L. Reducing sodium intake in children:
a public health investment. J Clin Hypertens (Greenwich). 2015;17(9):657-662.
doi: http://dx.doi.org/10.1111/jch.12615
 Expert Panel on Integrated Guidelines for Cardiovascular Health and Risk Reduction in Children and
Adolescents: summary report. Pediatrics. 2011;128 (suppl 5):S213-S256.
doi: http://dx.doi.org/10.1542/peds.2009-2107C
 Sacks FM, Svetkey LP, Vollmer WM, et al. Effects on blood pressure of reduced dietary sodium and the
Dietary Approaches to Stop Hypertension (DASH) diet. DASH-Sodium Collaborative Research Group. N Engl
J Med. 2001;344(1):3-10. doi: http://dx.doi.org/10.1056/NEJM200101043440101

A previously healthy 8-year-old girl presents with chest pain, shortness of breath, and fatigue. For the
past 4 days, she has noted easy bruising and orange-colored urine. She has felt nauseated with
decreased oral intake and had 2 episodes of nonbloody diarrhea. Vital signs are as follows:
temperature, 37.1℃ blood pressure, 132/76 mm Hg; heart rate, 110 beats/min; respiratory rate, 22
breaths/min; and oxygen saturation, 98% on room air. Physical examination findings are notable for
pallor and bruising of the upper and lower extremities. She has mild tachycardia without murmur. Her
chest is clear, and her abdomen is soft, nondistended, and nontender, with no hepatosplenomegaly.
Laboratory testing findings are as follows:
White blood cells 12,000/μL (12.1 × 109/L)
Hemoglobin 5.3 g/dL (53 g/L)
Hematocrit 15% (0.15)
Platelets 36 × 103/μL (36 × 109/L)
Lactate dehydrogenase 3332 U/L (55.6 μkat/L)
Sodium 137 mEq/L (137 mmol/L)
Potassium 4 mEq/L (4 mmol/L)
Chloride 98 mEq/L (98 mmol/L)
Bicarbonate 23 mEq/L (23 mmol/L)
Blood urea nitrogen 72 mg/dL (25.7 mmol/L)
Creatinine 2.5 mg/dL (221 μmol/L)
Calcium 9.3 mg/dL (2.33 mmol/L)
Total protein 6.8 g/dL (68 g/L)
Albumin 3.8 g/dL (38 g/L)
Total bilirubin 2.2 mg/dL (37.6 μmol/L)
Direct bilirubin 0.4 mg/dL (6.8 μmol/L)
Direct Coombs test result Negative
Shiga toxin-producing Escherichia Negative
coli test result
Urine dipstick has 2+ blood and trace protein. Schistocytes are identified on the peripheral blood
smear.
Of the following, which is MOST likely to be identified in this patient?
options: complement C1q deficiency
complement factor H antibodies
genomic mutations in ankyrin 1
somatic mutation of phosphatidylinositol glycan class A
explanation:
B. complement factor H antibodies
For the patient described in the vignette, complement factor H (CFH) antibodies are most likely to be
associated with hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS). Complement C1q deficiency is rare but
associated with the risk of systemic lupus erythematosus with rash and glomerulonephritis. Acquired
somatic mutations of phosphatidylinositol glycan class A in red blood cell precursors lead to
paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria. Mutations in ankyrin 1 lead to hereditary spherocytosis not
atypical hemolytic uremic syndrome (aHUS).
The patient in the vignette presents with triad of anemia, thrombocytopenia, and acute renal failure
consistent with HUS. The underlying pathophysiologic mechanism of HUS is a thrombotic
microangiopathy (TMA). Endothelial injury in the glomeruli leads to renal failure, and the
microangiopathy results in platelet consumption and hemolysis, leading to anemia and
thrombocytopenia. The microangiopathy can affect other vessels, leading to other complications,
such as neurologic symptoms of seizures, coma, and death.
The most common type of HUS (90%) is diarrhea-associated forms of HUS (D+ HUS) typically
caused by Shigatoxin-producing Escherichia coli (STEC). Atypical HUS (aHUS) refers to nondiarrheal
HUS. However, D+ HUS and aHUS may be difficult to differentiate from one another because up to
one-third patients with aHUS may have diarrhea, as in this vignette. There are other (nondiarrheal)
infections that can also induce HUS, such as Streptococcus pneumonia.
The complement pathway is a component of the innate immune system and contributes to immune
activation by generation of cytokines, opsonization of pathogens, and cell lysis by the membrane
attack complex (MAC). There are 3 mechanisms for complement activation: the classic complement
pathway, the lectin pathway, and the alternative complement pathways (Figure 1).

Figure 1:
Simplified version of complement activation:
Complement fixing antibodies (IgG, IgM) activate the classic pathway via binding of C1q. This leads to a complex that
cleave C2 and C4, allowing C4 convertase to form. C4 convertase cleaves C3 to C3b. Mannose binding lectins bind
sugars on surfaces of bacteria. They form complexes also able to cleave C2 and C4 to form the C4 convertase.
The alternative complement pathway is constitutively active with a constant tickover cleavage to form C3bBb
complexes (C3 convertase). C3 convertase cleave more C3, amplifying the complement response. Inhibitors of this
cleavage (eg. Factor H, Factor I) regulate immune activation on cell surfaces. Mutations that lead to dysregulated
alternative complement activation result in aHUS.
All three pathways converge with generation of C3b. C3b binds either C4aC2b or C3bBb to form C5 convertase. C5
convertase cleaves C5 to C5b, allowing MAC complex formation. (membrane attack complex = MAC)
Courtesy of K. Reidy
The alternative complement pathway is constitutively active with a constant “tick over” of C3 to C3b.
Complement factor D cleaves complement factor B (CFB), and a C3bBb complex forms (C3
convertase). The C3 convertase cleaves more C3 to C3b to amplify the activation. C3bBbC3b
complexes form, known as C5 convertase. This cleaves C5 to C5a, allowing the MAC to form. The
MAC can insert in cell membranes to induce cell lysis. Cleavages of C3 and C5 also release C3a and
C5a, which serve as anaphylotoxins (cytokine-like peptides that stimulate leukocyte phagocytosis,
increase endothelial permeability, induce arterial smooth muscle wall contraction, and drive neutrophil
chemotaxis).
The alternative complement system is tightly regulated to prevent activation. CFH is a cofactor for
complement factor I (CFI). CFH prevents binding of C3b to cell surfaces and degrades C3 convertase
(the C3bBb complex). CFI cleaves C3b to an inactive form. The membrane cofactor protein (MCP) is
a cofactor for CFI and promotes cleavage of C3b to the inactive form (iC3b). There are additional
mechanisms to prevent activation. Complement receptor 1 also promotes the inactivation of C3b to
iC3b. There is a decay accelerating factor (DAF or CD55) that promotes degradation of C3 and C5
convertases. Finally, protectin (CD59) blocks the formation of the MAC.
Defects in regulation of the alternative complement system that lead to overactivation of complement
are associated with development of aHUS (Figure 2).

Figure 2:
Alternative complement system highlighting how mutations and antibodies can lead to activation of complement and
aHUS (lightning symbol). Eculizumab inhibits incorporation of C5 into the MAC complex and is a treatment for aHUS.
Courtesy of K. Reidy
These defects include mutations in CFH, CFI, MCP, C3, C4-binding protein, CFB, thrombomodulin,
and CFH-related protein (CFHR) 1 or 3 (Table).

Table. Defects in Alternative Complement Regulation Associated With Atypical Hemolytic Uremic
Syndromea
Alternative Complement Factor Role and Effects on Alternative Complement
System
Complement factor H (CFH) loss-of-function mutations Inhibits C3b binding and degrades C3b
Complement factor I (CFI) loss-of-function mutations Degrade C3b and C4b
Membrane cofactor protein (MCP) loss-of-function Cofactor for CFI
mutations
C4b-binding protein (C4BP) loss-of-function mutations Cofactor for CFI
C3-activating mutations Generates C3a, C3b
Complement factor B (CFB)–activating mutations Mutations lead to increased stability of C3
convertase (C3bBb)
Complement factor H (CFH)–related proteins 1 or 3 Inhibits C5 cleavage and membrane attack
(CFHR1/3) deletions complex formation
Mutations are associated with formation of CFH
antibodies
Thrombomodulin (THBD) loss-of-function mutations Mutations result in less efficient inactivation of
C3b
Courtesy of K. Reidy.
Based on data collected from Alasfar S, Alachkar N. Atypical hemolytic uremic syndrome post-kidney transplantation: two case
reports and review of the literature. Front Med. 2014;1:52 and Schmidtko J, Peine S, El-Housseini Y, et al. Treatment of Atypical
Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome and Thrombotic Microangiopathies: A Focus on Eculizumab. Am J Kidney Dis. 2013;61(2):289-29
Complement component C3 is most often low with C3 and CFB mutations but can be low with all but
CFHR 1 or 3 mutations. Antibodies to the complement regulatory system (anti-CFH or anti-CFI
antibodies) also lead to aHUS. Anti-CFH antibodies are present in up to 6% of aHUS cases. They
result in a functional deficiency of CFH and prevent CFH binding to C3b. Because of the similarity
between CFHR and CFH proteins, in addition to a direct effect on complement activation, CFHR
mutations may predispose patients to form anti-CFH antibodies. Interestingly, mutations in
diacylglycerol kinase (DGKE) have been associated with aHUS but do NOT appear linked to
complement activation.
Up to 70% of aHUS cases will have an identifiable mutation. Approximately 10% may have more than
1 mutation in different complement components. Identification of mutations may be helpful to predict
prognosis in some cases. For example, mutations in MCP are one of the most common genetic
causes of aHUS and are primarily identified in children. Mutations in CFH, CFI, and CFB are
associated with high risk of aHUS recurrence after renal transplant, whereas MCP mutations have
low risk of recurrence after transplant. Complement mutations may also be present in secondary
TMAs, such as TMAs associated with pregnancy, cobalamin C deficiency, malignant hypertension,
and medication-related TMAs.
Eculizumab is a humanized monoclonal antibody that inhibits cleavage and C5 incorporation in MAC
and thus prevents terminal complement activation. Eculizumab is approved by the US Food and Drug
Administration for the treatment of aHUS. Because it prevents activation of alternative complement
pathway, patients are at higher risk of infection by encapsulated organisms, such as Neisseria
meningitidis. Thus, vaccination against meningitis is required before treatment.
PREP Pearls
 Dysregulation of the alternative complement system leads to atypical hemolytic uremic syndrome.

 Mutations in the alternative complement system
American Board of Pediatrics Content Specification(s)
 Know the role of complement abnormalities in atypical hemolytic uremic syndrome
Suggested Readings
 Alasfar S, Alachkar N. Atypical hemolytic uremic syndrome post-kidney transplantation: two case reports and
review of the literature. Front Med. 2014;1:52.
 Degn SE, Jensenius JC, Thiel S. Disease-causing mutations in genes of the complement system. Am J
Human Genet. 2011;88(6):689-705. doi: http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.ajhg.2011.05.011
 Teoh CW, Riedl M, Licht C. The alternative pathway of complement and the thrombotic
microangiopathies. Transfus Apher Sci. 2016;54(2):220-231.
doi: http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.transci.2016.04.012

You are seeing a 13-year-old previously healthy black female patient with a history of passing bright
red urine with small clots. She does not have any additional urinary symptoms, abdominal symptoms,
or flank pain. She has recently been very active playing volleyball, but reports no history of trauma.
Her mother recalls a similar incident a few years ago that was diagnosed as a urinary tract infection in
an urgent care clinic and seemed to improve with antibiotics. Her family history is remarkable for
multiple members on the maternal side of her family with sickle cell disease.
Her urinalysis results are positive for moderate blood and a specific gravity of 1.005, but negative for
protein, leukocyte esterase, and nitrite. Urine microscopy reveals 50 red blood cells per high power
field.
Which of the following statements is MOST appropriate to tell her family regarding the episode of
hematuria?
options: further evaluation will most likely reveal a coagulation disorder
sickle cell trait likely largely contributed to this presentation
strenuous exercise such as volleyball most likely is the etiology
thin glomerular basement membranes likely lead to the hematuria
explanation:
B. sickle cell trait likely largely contributed to this presentation
The patient in this clinical vignette has papillary necrosis secondary to sickle cell trait. Given her age
and unremarkable medical history, sickle cell disease is unlikely. The presentation of painless gross
hematuria in patients with sickle cell disease or trait should prompt the physician to include papillary
necrosis in the differential diagnosis. Although the clinical vignette could also indicate crystalluria or
stones, the asymptomatic clinical presentation and family history do not support this diagnosis.
Although exercise can induce transient gross and microscopic hematuria, exercise-induced hematuria
should be a diagnosis of exclusion and clots are unusual. A bleeding diathesis could lead to gross
hematuria, but usually the patient will have other signs and symptoms of clotting abnormalities.
Furthermore, a bleeding diathesis is rare compared to sickle cell trait. Thin glomerular basement
membrane disease rarely results in gross hematuria and is less likely than sickle cell trait. Of note,
sickle cell trait is a risk factor for medullary renal cell carcinoma, which would be included in the
differential diagnosis for a patient with sickle cell trait and gross hematuria.
Papillary necrosis occurs focally when the vasculature in the medulla becomes infarcted. This
infarction leads to medullary fibrosis and loss of medullary collecting ducts. When the infarction is
large enough, the papilla can be sloughed, and the patient can experience gross hematuria with
“clots” as seen in this vignette. The “clots” are actually papillary tissue and not true fibrin clots. These
sloughed tissue fragments can be large enough to cause obstruction and can lead to unilateral flank
pain.
Papillary necrosis is associated with different conditions and clinical contexts. Sickle cell disease and
sickle cell trait lead to sickling events in the vasa rectae in the medulla. Because the medulla has low
oxygen tension and pH, this scenario promotes sickling events even in patients with only sickle cell
trait. Diabetes, pyelonephritis, and analgesic abuse or chronic use are also associated with papillary
necrosis. Analgesic-associated papillary necrosis usually occurs in older patients with a history of
long-term use ofnonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs or combination analgesics. Phenacetin was
once the analgesic most associated with papillary necrosis, but it was removed from the market in
1983. Interestingly, in contrast to sickle cell disease or trait, analgesic-associated papillary necrosis
primarily involves peritubular capillaries instead of the vasa rectae. During pyelonephritis, local
inflammation in the medulla can lead to local impingement of vasculature and papillary necrosis. The
patient in this vignette was asymptomatic, thus, pyelonephritis is unlikely.
Although intravenous pyelography or computed tomography urography are not routinely performed
during clinical evaluation because of unnecessary radiation exposure, these imaging studies will
demonstrate extracalyceal contrast agent at the papillary tip, which is described as a “ball-on-tee” and
shown by the arrows in the Figure.

Figure: Angiomyolipoma. Sagittal ultrasound image of the left kidney shows a hyperechoic mass (arrow) arising
from the lower pole of the kidney.
Reprinted with permission from Curran-Melendez SM, Hartman MS, Heller MT, Okechukwu N. Sorting the
alphabet soup of renal pathology: a review. Curr Probl Diagn Radiol.2016;pii:S0363-0188(15)30049-9.

Historically, papillary necrosis was also known as renal medullary necrosis. The preferred terminology
now is papillary necrosis. Cortical necrosis, however, is a unique entity distinct from papillary
necrosis. Cortical necrosis usually occurs in patients with profound or prolonged hypoperfusion of the
kidneys. In patients who have severe sepsis, endotoxin can damage endothelial cells and activate
thrombosis accumulation in cortical vasculature. During complicated newborn deliveries, especially
with placental abruption, neonates may develop cortical necrosis if renal perfusion is significantly
impaired.
PREP Pearls
 Sickle cell disease and sickle cell trait should be included in the differential diagnosis of the child who has
painless gross hematuria.
 Diabetes, pyelonephritis, and analgesic abuse or chronic use are also associated with papillary necrosis.
American Board of Pediatrics Content Specification(s)
 Know the potential etiologic agents of cortical/medullary/papillary necrosis
 Recognize the possible association of cortical/ medullary/papillary necrosis with systemic conditions, including
sickle-cell trait and disease
Suggested Readings
 Curran-Melendez SM, Hartman MS, Heller MT, Okechukwu N. Sorting the alphabet soup of renal pathology: a
review. Curr Probl Diagn Radiol. 2016;pii:S0363-0188(15)30049-9.
doi: http://dx.doi.org/10.1067/j.cpradiol.2016.01.003
 Kovacevic L, Bernstein J, Valentini RP, Imam A, Gupta N, Mattoo TK. Renal papillary necrosis induced by
naproxen. Pediatr Nephrol. 2003;18(8):826-829. doi: http://dx.doi.org/10.1007/s00467-003-1167-4
 Scheinman JI. Sickle cell nephropathy. In: Kher KK, Schnaper HW, Makker SP eds. Clinical
Pediatric Nephrology. 2nd ed. London, UK: Informa Healthcare; 2007:289-298.
