You are evaluating a 4-year-old girl with persistently elevated serum creatinine levels. She was born
at 39 weeks of gestation, but was noted to have poor weight gain and linear growth. Her parents
report that she is always thirsty and produces copious amounts of urine, as compared to her older
siblings. She has had several hospitalizations because of fever, vomiting, and dehydration. There is
no history of recurrent urinary tract infections. On physical examination, she is below the third
percentile for weight and height, and her blood pressure is 105/60 mm Hg. Abnormal serum
laboratory findings as well as urinalysis results are shown:
Laboratory Test Result
Serum
Creatinine 1.2 mg/dL (92 µmol/L)
Bicarbonate 18 mEq/L (18 mmol/L)
Hemoglobin 9.2 g/dL (92 g/L)
Urine
Specific gravity 1.012
Protein 2+
Blood Negative
Glucose Negative
Contrast-enhanced computed tomography performed for an unrelated illness revealed small kidneys
with thickened renal cortex and medulla bilaterally and striated nephrograms in the absence of
hydronephrosis or renal vein thrombosis (Figure).

Figure: Computed tomography for
the girl described in the vignette.
Reprinted with permission from
Hopkins K, Mowry J, Houghton D. Clin
Pract. 2013;3(2):e31.
Of the following, the MOST correct statement describing the prognosis of this child is
options: angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors will prevent the progression of chronic kidney disease
poor growth in this child will be resistant to growth hormone therapy, vitamin D, and salt supplementation
renal function is likely to remain stable over time as long as the child remains normotensive
this child will develop progressive chronic kidney disease and worsening proteinuria in the next decade
explanation:
D. this child will develop progressive chronic kidney disease and worsening proteinuria in the next
decade
The patient in this vignette has polyuria, polydipsia, and failure to thrive. Laboratory and imaging
investigations revealed evidence of chronic kidney disease, bilaterally small kidneys, and thickened
renal cortex with nephrograms that is consistent with oligomeganephronic renal hypoplasia. Renal
ultrasonography would show 2 small kidneys (less than fifth percentile for height), poor
corticomedullary differentiation, and no evidence of hydronephrosis. A renal biopsy, which is not
necessary for diagnosis, would show paucity of glomeruli that are 4 times the size of normal
glomeruli, mesangial matrix expansion, tubular dilation, and mild tubulointerstitial fibrosis.
Renal hypoplasia should be distinguished from other forms of congenital anomalies of the kidney and
urinary tract characterized by small kidneys, such as renal hypodysplasia, segmental scarring caused
by vesicoureteral reflux, diffuse scarring caused by congenital renal artery stenosis, and infantile
nephronophthisis.
The 2 histological forms of renal hypoplasia are simple hypoplasia and oligomeganephronia, which
are characterized by severe reduction in renal size and up to an 80% decrease in the number of
nephrons (glomeruli). The glomeruli retain a normal volume in simple hypoplasia but are
hypertrophied (at least 3-fold larger than normal age-adjusted glomeruli) in oligomeganephronia.
Other features of oligomeganephronia are less than 5 renal lobes (normal number is more than 10),
as well as a lack of cone-shaped medullary pyramids and the presence of thickened renal cortex and
striated nephrograms on contrast-enhanced computed tomography due to glomerular and proximal
tubular hypertrophy. The prognosis in oligomeganephronia is guarded. Experimental studies of
reduced renal mass in rodents have shown that glomerular hypertrophy is accompanied by
glomerular hypertension, mesangial stretch, and activation of the local renin-angiotensin system,
leading to release of inflammatory and fibrotic cytokines. The fibrotic cytokines lead to progressive
renal dysfunction and proteinuria. Most patients develop worsening proteinuria and renal function
over 10 to 15 years, which results in end-stage renal disease. Accordingly, close monitoring and
follow-up of these patients is warranted.
Management of patients with renal hypoplasia depends on early identification of renal disease,
prevention of repeated episodes of dehydration with adequate water and salt supplementation, and
appropriate medical management of anemia and renal osteodystrophy. Some patients require gastric
tube placement for continuous water and salt supplementation. Data from animal studies also
suggest that early initiation of angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors may lower the proteinuria and
slow (but not prevent) the progression of chronic renal disease.
PREP Pearls
 The 2 types of renal hypoplasia are simple hypoplasia and oligomeganephronic hypoplasia. The latter is
associated with cortical thickening and striated nephrograms on computed tomography scan.
 In oligomeganephronic hypoplasia, glomerular hypertrophy is accompanied by progressive renal disease and
proteinuria.
 Management of renal hypoplasia relies on judicious replacement of urinary fluid and electrolyte losses, as well
as management of metabolic bone disease and anemia. The use of angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors
may slow the progression of renal disease and lessen the proteinuria.
American Board of Pediatrics Content Specification(s)
 Know the management and prognosis of renal hypoplasia/oligomeganephronia

Suggested Readings
 Carter JE, Lirenman DS. Bilateral renal hypoplasia with oligomeganephronia: oligomeganephronic renal
hypoplasia. Am J Dis Child. 1970;120(6):537-542.
 Hopkins K, Mowry J, Houghton D. Congenital oligomeganephronia: computed tomography appearance. Clin
Pract.2013;3e31(2):87-90. doi: http://dx.doi.org/10.4081/cp.2013.e31
 Liapis H, Winyard P. Cystic diseases and developmental kidney defects. In: Heptinstall’s Pathology of the
Kidney.6th ed. Philadelphia, PA: Lippincott Williams & Wilkins. 2007:1296-1297.

stem:
A 17-year-old male adolescent who received a deceased donor kidney transplant for focal segmental
glomerulosclerosis 4 months ago has missed his last few clinic appointments. He is experiencing
decreased urine output, swelling, and hypertension, and his laboratory test results are notable for a
serum creatinine level of 4.1 mg/dL (313 µmol/L) and an albumin level of 1.2 g/dL (12 g/L). The urine
protein-creatinine ratio is greater than 8 mg/mg. A renal biopsy is performed and the preliminary
pathology report reads:
One core of tissue was submitted for light microscopy consisting entirely of cortex tissue. It is 15 mm
in length and contains 9 glomeruli and 2 arteries….One core of tissue was submitted for
immunofluorescence consisting of both cortex and medullary tissue, containing 3 glomeruli….One
core of tissue was submitted for electron microscopy consisting almost entirely of cortex
tissue….Although this is not considered an adequate sample….
The characteristic that MOST likely makes this sample considered not adequate is
options: only 2 arteries on the light microscopy sample
only 3 glomeruli on the immunofluorescence microscopy sample
only 9 glomeruli on the light microscopy sample
only cortical tissue on the light microscopy sample
explanation:
C. only 9 glomeruli on the light microscopy sample
Renal biopsy is often needed to accurately diagnose renal pathology. This procedure is not without
risk, especially in children. Therefore, steps should be taken to ensure that the obtained kidney tissue
specimen is adequate for accurate diagnosis, while also minimizing the risk of morbidity by limiting
the number of passes of the biopsy needle, and thus also the number of tissue cores obtained.
However, the characteristics that make a kidney biopsy specimen adequate are not the same for all
biopsies. Specimen adequacy may vary according to the tissue source (native vs graft kidney) and
the clinical conditions being evaluated.
Renal diseases may affect the different compartments of the kidney. Therefore, biopsy specimens
should allow for examination of each of the histologic elements (glomeruli, tubules, interstitium, and
vasculature). Additionally, the specimens should be large enough to allow for light microscopy (LM),
immunofluorescence microscopy (IFM), and electron microscopy (EM) examinations of a native
kidney biopsy. For certain diagnoses, IFM or EM findings are essential. In a review of adult native
kidney biopsies, findings from EM were necessary for diagnosis in 21% of cases and provided
significant refinement to the diagnosis in an additional 24% of cases. The diagnosis of IgA
nephropathy/Henoch-Schonlein purpura, IgM nephropathy, C1q nephropathy, anti-glomerular
basement membrane disease, humoral (C4d) transplant rejection, or amyloidosis in children may be
missed without IFM. Moreover, the diagnosis of nail-patella syndrome, dense deposit disease, Alport
syndrome, or thin basement membrane disease in children may be missed without EM.
For transplant biopsy, LM and IFM are considered standard, and repeat biopsies often require only
LM. However, with newer histopathologic findings associated with humoral rejection, such as C4d
deposition, IFM or immunohistochemistry is now considered requisite for most transplant biopsies,
including repeat biopsies. For the vast majority of these cases, the IFM is performed to identify C4d
deposition in the peritubular capillaries or arteries; thus, the number of glomeruli would not matter as
much. However, there can be occasions when the number of glomeruli on IFM specimen of a
transplant kidney biopsy is critical, such as in recurrence of IgA nephropathy or de novo
antiglomerular basement membrane disease. Similarly, there are other renal disorders that might
have early changes on EM, such as focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) with early podocyte
effacement, and EM may be requisite for accurate analysis in these cases. In this vignette, with
recurrence of FSGS being a strong possibility, a limited number of glomeruli on IFM is not critical for
specimen adequacy.
The volume of each tissue specimen is determined by the length of the tissue core and the caliber (or
gauge) of the biopsy needle. Recommendations for adult renal biopsies have included obtaining 2
cores, each at least 1 cm in length, by using a 14- or 16-gauge needle, as this approach provides at
least 5 mm2 of renal cortex. Eighteen-gauge needles give very narrow samples and may provide an
inadequate representation of vessels. Studies in adults comparing 18-gauge needle biopsy
specimens to lower gauge (larger caliber) needles have shown a lower number of glomeruli sampled
with the narrower needles. However, in smaller pediatric patients, an 18-gauge needle may be more
appropriate to avoid biopsy-related bleeding complications; the 18-gauge needles have been
associated with a lower incidence of macroscopic hematuria in this population, while still yielding
enough tissue for accurate diagnosis.
Longer tissue cores are more likely to provide more renal tissue overall, but may not necessarily
provide a greater yield of glomeruli. Medullary tissue, which has a very sparse distribution of
glomeruli, is not considered requisite for specimen adequacy. However, the juxtamedullary glomeruli
are the earliest to be affected by FSGS, so the deeper region of cortex may be more helpful in
diagnosing FSGS. Additionally,the subcapsular cortex may have an overrepresentation of glomeruli

with nonspecific scarring from hypertension or aging, especially in a transplant graft, so very
superficial samples of the cortex may not accurately reflect the findings in its other parts.
For certain diffuse disorders, like membranous glomerulonephritis or amyloidosis, in which most
glomeruli are affected, identification of a single glomerulus with classic findings is usually sufficient for
diagnosis. However, focal disorders, like FSGS, may have only a percentage of the glomeruli
involved. Therefore, the biopsy sample must be large enough to contain these affected glomeruli in
order to make an accurate diagnosis. As the prevalence of any focal disease is unknown prior to
performing a biopsy, some presumptions may be needed to improve the probability of making an
accurate diagnosis. In a 1988 editorial, Corwin et al explained the statistics behind biopsy sampling:
“If the actual prevalence of diseased glomeruli… is 10%, there is a 35% probability that no abnormal
glomeruli will be found in a sample (of) only 10 glomeruli. When the biopsy contains 20 glomeruli, the
probability…is still 12%” (Am J Nephrol. 1988;8[2]:85-89). Others have cited 25 glomeruli as a
standard of adequacy, because this is the number needed to have a greater than 95% chance of
detecting low prevalence lesions on LM. Therefore, only 9 glomeruli on LM may be considered an
inadequate number when looking for FSGS.
Sample size also plays a role when trying to quantify the extent of injury seen on biopsy. Whether
trying to determine the amount of interstitial fibrosis or the number of glomeruli with crescentic
change, a limited sample size may contribute to misclassification of disease extent, especially in
patients diagnosed with moderate (vs mild or severe) disease. Corwin et al statistically modeled the
accuracy of certain classification schema and found that the classification of moderate disease may
be accurate 75% of the time when only 10 glomeruli are sampled, but the accuracy would improve to
85% when 20 glomeruli are sampled.
A systematic approach of semiquantitative evaluation of renal biopsy specimens has been endorsed
in several instances, such as the Oxford classification system for IgA nephropathy or the World
Health Organization classification system for lupus nephritis. In 1991, the Banff classification system
defined an adequate sample as containing at least 7 glomeruli and 1 artery. However, this definition
was refined in 1997 (published in 1999) to a minimum of 10 glomeruli and 2 arteries, while a marginal
sample contains 7 to 10 glomeruli or 1 artery, and an unsatisfactory sample contains less than 7
glomeruli or no arteries. By applying these criteria to the sample in this vignette, the presence of 2
arteries is considered adequate, and the presence of 9 glomeruli is considered marginal but not
adequate. The marginal number of glomeruli does not mean that the biopsy results are inaccurate,
because there may still be extensive rejection findings or findings of segmental sclerosis in several
glomeruli.
PREP Pearls
 For native kidney biopsy specimens, an adequate tissue specimen to allow for light, immunofluorescence, and
electron microscopy is necessary. For a transplant biopsy, only light microscopy and immunofluorescence
microscopy may be needed, although electron microscopy may be helpful in some cases.
 If a disorder with focal findings (eg, focal segmental glomerulosclerosis) is being strongly considered, a larger
sample size of glomeruli may be needed for an accurate diagnosis.
American Board of Pediatrics Content Specification(s)
 Assess the adequacy of biopsy specimens
Suggested Readings
 Corwin HL, Schwartz MM, Lewis EJ. The importance of sample size in the interpretation of the renal
biopsy. Am J Nephrol. 1988;8(2):85-89.

 Durkan AM, Beattie TJ, Howatson A, McColl JH, Ramage IJ. Renal transplant biopsy specimen adequacy in a
paediatric population. Pediatr Nephrol. 2006;21(2):265-269. doi: http://dx.doi.org/10.1007/s00467-005-2076-5
 Fogo AB. Approach to renal biopsy. Am J Kidney Dis. 2003;42(4):826-836.
 Walker PD, Cavallo T, Bonsib SM, Ad Hoc Committee on Renal Biopsy Guidelines of the Renal Pathology
Society. Practice guidelines for the renal biopsy. Mod Pathol. 2004;17(12):1555-1563.
doi: http://dx.doi.org/10.1038/modpathol.3800239

A 10-year-old boy received a kidney transplant at 3 years of age for bilateral renal hypoplasia. His
posttransplant course was stable for 7 years, with no major acute rejection episodes and a steady
baseline serum creatinine level of approximately 0.6 mg/dL (53 µmol/L). His maintenance
immunosuppression regimen consists of tacrolimus (target level, 6-8 ng/mL), mycophenolate mofetil
600 mg twice daily, and prednisolone 10 mg once daily. He has developed fever, left-sided
weakness, multiple cervical lymphadenopathy, and anemia. Lymph node biopsy reveals a
monomorphic and monoclonal posttransplant lymphoproliferative disorder. Cerebrospinal fluid
contains malignant cells, and neuroimaging reveals a small mass in the right parietal lobe.
Chemotherapy is started.
The BEST approach regarding this patient’s immunosuppression regimen is to
options: discontinue all immunosuppressive medications immediately
discontinue the tacrolimus and mycophenolate, continue prednisolone
maintain current levels and doses of all immunosuppressive agents
reduce the tacrolimus target level to 3 to 5 ng/mL, reduce the mycophenolate mofetil and prednisolone by 50%
explanation:
B. discontinue the tacrolimus and mycophenolate, continue prednisolone
The patient in this vignette has a severe posttransplant lymphoproliferative disorder (PTLD), including
central nervous system involvement. Despite improvements in treatment and prognosis, PTLD
remains a serious complication of kidney transplantation and continues to be associated with
suboptimal outcomes, such as significant mortality. In particular, central nervous system PTLD carries
a very high mortality rate.
Although there are no randomized clinical trials of PTLD treatments, most guidelines and opinion
papers recommend a reduction of overall immunosuppression as the first strategy in the management
of PTLD. The type and extent of reduction is not clear and thus can be varied, such as reduction in all
agents or selective elimination of certain agents. A common approach would be to eliminate the
mycophenolate and decrease the goal tacrolimus level with no change in steroid dosing. In milder or
earlier cases of PTLD, such reduction may be sufficient to restore immune responses to the PTLD,
especially if driven by Epstein-Barr virus replication.
In moderately severe cases of PTLD or cases that do not respond to initial immunosuppression
reduction, a variety of other agents are then recommended, such as rituximab, chemotherapy
medications, or both. Gross et al have demonstrated a 70% complete response rate of a composite
outcome (patient survival, relapse-free, allograft survival) of a rituximab–low dose chemotherapy
regimen in a multicenter cohort of children with PTLD after solid organ transplant. In adults, the
multicenter PTLD-1 trial showed similar efficacy of a rituximab–standard chemotherapy regimen.
When a patient has central nervous system PTLD, the prognosis is much worse. In such situations,
most transplantation professionals agree that a staged approach starting with reduction of
immunosuppression is not enough. Therefore, an almost complete elimination of immunosuppression
is recommended. If the patient is on a steroid-free regimen, then complete elimination is advised.
Steroids, however, are part of the lymphoma-based chemotherapy regimens used in the treatment of
PTLD. Therefore, continuing prednisolone would be appropriate in this situation. An immediate and
abrupt withdrawal of prednisolone that has been administered for a long time is not advisable,
because it poses a risk for inducing pseudotumor cerebri. Therefore, discontinuation of tacrolimus
and mycophenolate and continued prednisolone is the preferred treatment approach.
This case highlights the dilemma of having to choose between patient survival and allograft survival.
A near or complete cessation of immunosuppression would expose the allograft to an acute rejection
episode and create a 4-fold higher risk of allograft failure. In kidney transplantation, there is the
fallback option of maintaining a patient on chronic dialysis in case the allograft fails. Therefore, patient
survival should always take precedence over allograft survival in such situations. Unfortunately, other
solid organ recipients, such as lung and heart transplant recipients, may not have this luxury,
because in these situations, allograft failure can frequently mean patient death. When PTLD occurs in
a lung transplant recipient, chemotherapy is instituted in the context of maintained
immunosuppression.
PREP Pearls
 In the appropriate context, patient survival generally takes preference over allograft survival.
American Board of Pediatrics Content Specification(s)
 Understand the post-transplant dilemmas of choosing patient survival at the expense of graft survival
Suggested Readings
 Dharnidharka VR, Webster AC, Martinez OM, Preiksaitis JK, Leblond V, Choquet S. Post-transplant
lymphoproliferative disorders. Nat Rev Dis Primers. 2016;2:15088. doi: http://dx.doi.org/10.1038/nrdp.2015.88

 Gross TG, Orjuela MA, Perkins S, et al. Low-dose chemotherapy and rituximab for posttransplant
lymphoproliferative disease (PTLD): a Children's Oncology Group Report. Am J Transplant. 2012;12(11):3069-
3075. doi: http://dx.doi.org/10.1111/j.1600-6143.2012.04206.x
 Trappe R, Oertel S, Leblond V, et al. Sequential treatment with rituximab followed by CHOP chemotherapy in
adult B-cell post-transplant lymphoproliferative disorder (PTLD): the prospective international multicentre
phase 2 PTLD-1 trial. Lancet Oncol. 2012;13(2):196-206. doi: http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/S1470-2045(11)70300-

A 5-year-old girl is being evaluated for concerns of autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease.
She had an older sibling who died at 16 years of age from liver complications of autosomal recessive
polycystic kidney disease (cholangitis). The family history is otherwise unremarkable. On physical
examination, the girl’s blood pressure is 100/56 mm Hg, and her height and weight are at the 50th
percentile. On abdominal examination, a firm liver edge is felt but the kidneys are not palpable. The
remainder of the examination is unremarkable. Urinalysis shows no blood or protein, and the
creatinine level is 0.4 mg/dL (35 µmol/L) (estimated glomerular filtration rate, 100 mL/min/1.73 m2).
Renal ultrasonography was normal with the right kidney at 7 cm in size and the left kidney at 6.8 cm
in size.
Of the following, the MOST accurate statement regarding this patient is that
options: genetic testing of PKHD1 will definitively determine if she has autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease
her liver synthetic function (factor V) should be assessed for autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease changes
she does not have autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease based on her ultrasonography results
she should have liver ultrasonography to look for liver fibrosis and bile duct dilatation associated with autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease
explanation:
D. she should have liver ultrasonography to look for liver fibrosis and bile duct dilatation associated
with autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease
Patients with autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease (ARPKD) uniformly have liver fibrosis on
a microscopic level at birth, with about half having clinically detectable disease (hepatosplenomegaly,
esophageal varices, or both) as neonates. Liver manifestations include congenital hepatic fibrosis,
Caroli syndrome (nonobstructed dilatation of the intrahepatic bile ducts), and common bile duct
dilatation. About three-fourths of patients will develop portal hypertension related to hepatic fibrosis.
About two-thirds of patients will have bile duct abnormalities that can lead to cholangitis, vitamin
malabsorption (fat soluble vitamins including A, D, E, and K), and long-term risk of tumors (both
benign and malignant including cholangiocarcinoma). Some patients manifest a predominantly
hepatic phenotype with minimal or no renal involvement. The percentage of such patients is
unknown. Thus, in this patient with a severely affected sibling with liver involvement, normal renal
ultrasonography results would not exclude ARPKD, and high resolution ultrasonography of the liver
should be performed, especially with the clinical findings of a firm liver edge.
As noted above, portal hypertension and biliary disease are common manifestations of ARPKD.
Synthetic dysfunction is rare, especially early in the disease. Thus, checking liver synthetic function in
this child is unlikely to be helpful in making a diagnosis.
The polycystic kidney and hepatic disease 1 gene (PKHD1) is a large gene (470 kb) with 86 exons
and alternative splice variants. In patients with clinical ARPKD, genetic analysis requires both
sequence analysis and deletion/duplication analysis to reach an almost 80% detection rate for
pathologic variants (ie, genetic confirmation). Thus, genetic testing is uninformative (negative test
result with positive phenotype, false negative) in about 20% of patients with clinical ARPKD.
However, if the pathologic gene variants of the deceased sibling are known, then genetic analysis for
this child can determine if similar variants are present. In older studies, the detection of pathologic
mutations in patients with liver-predominant disease was about half that of patients with a severe
renal phenotype.
The age at presentation influences survival and phenotype. Individuals diagnosed at less than 1 year
of age typically have renal enlargement, and about half have hepatosplenomegaly. The 10-year
survival rate is about 70%. In children who are diagnosed at older than 1 year of age, liver
complications such as variceal bleeding or cholangitis are more common at presentation, with renal
enlargement being less common (about one-third). The 10-year survival rate is over 90% in this
group. At 10 years of age, about 10% of diagnosed ARPKD patients will have required a liver
transplant, and about 60% will have received a kidney transplant. In one series of children with
ARPKD who received a kidney transplant, 80% of the early deaths were related to liver disease
(mostly infection related to bile duct disease). In addition, the liver disease typically progresses with
worsening of portal hypertension that may require sclerotherapy, banding of varices, or transjugular
intrahepatic portosystemic shunt placement for management.
PREP Pearls
 Individuals with autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease may have severe liver disease with minimal or
no kidney disease.
 For screening purposes, both kidney and liver high-resolution ultrasonography are needed.
 Individuals with autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease who have a kidney transplant may experience
significant morbidity and mortality related to liver disease.

American Board of Pediatrics Content Specification(s)
 Know the spectrum of liver disease in autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease, including long term
complications
Suggested Readings
 Adeva M, El-Youssef M, Rossetti S, et al. Clinical and molecular characterization defines a broadened
spectrum of autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease (ARPKD). Medicine (Baltimore). 2006;85(1):1-21.
 Hoyer PF. Clinical manifestations of autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease. Curr Opin
Pediatr.2015;27(2):186-192. doi: http://dx.doi.org/10.1097/MOP.0000000000000196
 Khan K, Schwarzenberg SJ, Sharp HL, Matas AJ, Chavers BM. Morbidity from congenital hepatic fibrosis after
renal transplantation for autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease. Am J Transplant. 2002;2(4):360-365.
doi: http://dx.doi.org/10.1034/j.1600-6143.2002.20412.x

stem:
You are meeting with expectant parents during a prenatal consultation for diagnosis of posterior
urethral valves. Bilateral hydroureteronephrosis was identified during ultrasonography performed at
20 weeks, and oligohydramnios has complicated the pregnancy since that time. The parents are
asking questions regarding their unborn child’s prognosis.
Of the following, the BEST response about his prognosis is
options: early intervention will ensure normal bladder function
he is likely to develop renal insufficiency by 10 years of age
he will never need renal replacement therapy if he does not require dialysis by puberty
prenatal diagnosis will result in normal renal function
explanation:
B. he is likely to develop renal insufficiency by 10 years of age
Obstructive uropathy is one of the most common causes of chronic kidney disease and end-stage
renal disease in children. Obstruction can occur anywhere along the urinary tract and can range from
partial unilateral obstruction to complete bilateral obstruction. In each scenario, increased pressure is
transmitted to the renal interstitium. When present before birth, this elevated pressure can lead to
renal maldevelopment. When present in infancy and early childhood, the elevated pressure can lead
to progressive renal failure. When urinary obstruction persists, irreversible interstitial fibrosis and
glomerulosclerosis can develop. Animal studies have provided evidence that the severity of renal
damage is associated with the duration and severity of obstruction before birth. Early diagnosis and
postnatal intervention is therefore essential to preserve renal function and prevent further decline.
Although relieving obstruction soon after birth can halt this process and improve functional
parameters, such as blood pressure and serum creatinine levels, it does not eliminate the risk for
chronic kidney disease progression. Interstitial fibrosis, glomerulosclerosis, and tubular atrophy can
occur and progress in the previously obstructed kidney, as well as in the nonobstructed kidney in
individuals with unilateral disease. Therefore, individuals with a history of obstructive uropathy are at
risk for glomerular filtration rate decline as well as the development of proteinuria and hypertension
throughout their lifespan, and they require follow-up throughout adulthood.
The clinical outcomes of children with urinary tract obstruction are wide and varied. A child with mild
unilateral ureteropelvic junction obstruction may experience minimal renal sequelae, whereas a child
with bladder outlet obstruction may develop severe renal injury with complete loss of function. It is
often difficult to predict renal function and outcome; but, in general, the duration of obstruction
(chronic vs acute), the timing of obstruction (prenatal vs after nephrogenesis is complete), the degree
of obstruction (complete vs partial, bilateral vs unilateral), and the immediate response after relief of
obstruction can be used to risk stratify individuals for progressive kidney disease. In addition,
characteristics associated with worse renal prognosis include earlier gestational age at diagnosis,
coexisting vesicoureteral reflux, echogenic kidneys on ultrasonography, history of urinary tract
infections, higher creatinine level at 1 year of age, development of hypertension, and the presence of
proteinuria.
In the vignette above, there is evidence of significant obstructive uropathy with a diagnosis of
posterior urethral valves (PUV), bilateral ureteronephrosis, and oligohydramnios. In severe cases of
PUV, the kidneys are poorly developed and have minimal function. In addition, many children have
associated pulmonary hypoplasia, which causes mortality among children with PUV.
In developed countries, mortality among children with severe PUV has decreased from 50% in the
1950s to close to 1% currently. Although overall survival has improved dramatically, the majority of
children with prenatally diagnosed PUV will experience renal insufficiency and complications related
to chronic kidney disease before their 10th birthday. A small subset of children experience no long-
term effects related to PUV, but this outcome cannot be predicted with precision; therefore, close
long-term follow-up is essential.
Prenatal diagnosis may help prevent the development of fatal pulmonary hypoplasia by interventions
such as decompression of the urinary system, but there is no evidence that prenatal diagnosis
changes long-term renal outcome.
PREP Pearls
 The clinical outcomes of children with urinary tract obstruction range from minimal renal sequelae to end-stage
renal disease.

 Children with obstructive uropathy must be closely followed through adulthood to monitor for the progression of
chronic kidney disease.
American Board of Pediatrics Content Specification(s)
 Know the renal prognosis for patients with urethral valves, ureterovesicular junction obstruction, and
ureteropelvic junction obstruction
Suggested Readings
 Chevalier RL, Peters CA. Obstructive uropathy. In: Avner E, Harmon W, Niaudet P, Yoshikawa N,
eds. Pediatric Nephrology. 6th ed. Berlin, Germany: Springer-Verlag; 2009:1337-1377.



November 2017

stem:
You are seeing a 14-year-old adolescent boy with persistent nephrotic-range proteinuria. He was first
noted to have proteinuria and hematuria at 1 year of age. A kidney biopsy performed at 18 months of
age showed mild podocyte effacement with glomerulosclerosis and areas of chronic interstitial
fibrosis. Immunofluorescence showed no deposits. For the past 10 years, he has been without pitting
edema and has received an angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor. His serum creatinine level is 0.8
mg/dL (61 µmol/L) (estimated glomerular filtration rate, 75 mL/min/1.73 m2), and a recent
ultrasonography examination showed mild nephrocalcinosis. There is a family history of Bright
disease and night blindness in the maternal grandfather.
Of the following, which statement is MOST likely to be true in this patient?
options: he is at risk for nephrolithiasis and rickets
he is likely to develop untreatable night blindness
he will progress to end-stage renal disease with a risk of recurrent disease after transplant
his sister is not at risk of renal disease
explanation:
A. he is at risk for nephrolithiasis and rickets
The adolescent boy in this vignette has Dent disease, which is an X-linked inherited tubular disorder.
Individuals with Dent disease typically have hypercalciuria along with low molecular weight
proteinuria. Urinary protein electrophoresis showing a mixed glomerular and tubular pattern and the
presence of elevated urinary β2-microglobulin levels (greater than 5 times the upper limit of normal)
are consistent with a diagnosis of Dent disease. Microscopic hematuria is very common. Tubular
dysfunction can manifest with a urine concentrating defect, hypophosphatemia, amino aciduria, and
rickets. Some patients have nephrotic-range proteinuria with glomerulosclerosis. Other patients have
hypokalemia and metabolic alkalosis similar to Bartter syndrome. In addition, vitamin A–responsive
night blindness occurs in some patients.
Diagnostic findings in Dent disease can include:
 Low molecular weight proteinuria (typically present)
 Hypercalciuria (typically present)
 Hematuria
 Nephrocalcinosis/nephrolithiasis
 Hypophosphatemia
Approximately 60% of individuals with Dent disease have a mutation in CLCN5 (Dent disease type 1),
which encodes a voltage-gated chloride proton exchanger. Approximately 15% of individuals with
Dent disease have a mutation in OCRL1 (Dent disease type 2), which encodes an inositol
polyphosphate 5 phosphatase. Interestingly, about 15% of individuals with Lowe syndrome have
mutations in OCRL1. Therefore, individuals suspected of having Dent disease should be assessed for
eye diseases (congenital cataracts and glaucoma) and developmental issues associated with Lowe
syndrome.
Dent disease is typically described as an X-linked recessive disorder. However, female carriers can
have high levels of urinary β2-microglobulin, and some carriers progress to severe nephrocalcinosis
and renal failure. This progression is thought to be caused by unfavorable X inactivation.
Studies of Dent disease families reveal that progressive nephrocalcinosis and chronic kidney disease
are more common in families with CLCN5 mutations. However, the disease can have variable
severity even within a kindred. Hypercalciuria and low molecular weight proteinuria are consistent
findings, while nephrocalcinosis develops in three-fourths of patients and renal insufficiency develops
in two-thirds of patients. End-stage kidney disease typically occurs in the fourth or fifth decade of life,
and the disease does not recur after transplant. Rickets or osteomalacia occurs in one-fourth of male
individuals with disease.
Treatment of hypercalciuria is similar to treatment of patients with idiopathic hypercalciuria and stone
disease (sodium restriction and thiazide diuretics). Because proteinuria is mostly tubular, the role for
angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors is not well defined, and caution must be exercised in
patients with polyuria, especially if they take a thiazide diuretic. Administration of phosphate,
potassium, vitamin D, or citrate may also be needed. Vitamin A may be needed for patients who
develop night blindness.
PREP Pearls
 In patients with hypercalciuria and proteinuria, Dent disease should be considered and urinary β2-
microglobulin should be measured.

 Dent disease may cause chronic kidney disease with nephrolithiasis.
 Female carriers of Dent disease may develop renal disease.

 Know the treatment, complications and long-term outcome of Dent disease

A pediatrician asks for advice regarding additional evaluation for an 8-year-old girl with newly
diagnosed hypertension. Multiple blood pressure measurements taken over several weeks yielded an
average manual blood pressure at the 99th percentile. Four limb blood pressures were similar. She
has no significant past medical history, was born full term, and is not taking any medications. Her
father is hypertensive and on medications since his initial diagnosis in his early 20s. Her paternal
grandfather is also hypertensive and had a myocardial infarction at 52 years of age. The girl is active
and plays soccer. She is not overweight and her physical examination results are unremarkable.
Renal and bladder ultrasonography reveals 2 normally sized kidneys with normal echogenicity and no
hydronephrosis. Laboratory data are shown:
Laboratory Test Result

Of the following, the MOST likely testing to reveal the etiology of this child’s hypertension is
options: 24-hour ambulatory blood pressure monitoring
echocardiography
plasma renin activity and serum aldosterone level
polysomnography
explanation:
C. plasma renin activity and serum aldosterone level
Hypertension is diagnosed when the average blood pressure measured by manual auscultation at
least 3 times on 3 separate occasions is at or above the 95th percentile for the child’s age, sex, and
height. Once diagnosed, all children should be evaluated for secondary causes. A secondary etiology
of hypertension is more likely in younger children and in children with higher blood pressure at initial
presentation. In this vignette, the child is school age with an average blood pressure in the upper half
of the blood pressure range for stage I hypertension. Her age and blood pressure, along with her
nonobese status and her family history of early onset hypertension and early myocardial infarction,
make it more likely that there is a secondary cause for her hypertension.
In addition to a thorough history and physical examination, the initial evaluation of pediatric
hypertension should include laboratory testing to screen for kidney disease (urinalysis, blood urea
nitrogen, creatinine), chronic illness (hemoglobin), and monogenic/endocrine forms of hypertension
(electrolytes). Renal and bladder ultrasonography should also be obtained to screen for congenital
anomalies of the kidneys and urologic tract. Investigation for comorbidities (fasting glucose, fasting
lipids) and target organ damage (echocardiography) should also be performed at the initial diagnosis.
Additional testing should be performed if no secondary cause is identified from the initial evaluation of
a child likely to have a secondary form of hypertension. These studies should be tailored to each
patient and include polysomnography, urine toxicology, 24-hour ambulatory blood pressure
monitoring, plasma renin activity, serum aldosterone level, renovascular imaging (computed
tomography angiography, magnetic resonance angiography, angiography), plasma metanephrines,
and plasma and urine steroid levels. The results of these studies should bring one closer to a
diagnosis, which may or may not need to be confirmed with additional testing. A differential diagnosis
of secondary causes of sustained hypertension, along with classic history, physical examination
findings, and the laboratory testing and imaging from the initial evaluation can be helpful in identifying

The physical examination results and past medical history of the child in this vignette are
unremarkable, and the laboratory test results are only notable for hypokalemia. This presentation,
along with her family history, raises concern for a monogenic cause of hypertension. Therefore, the
measurement of plasma renin activity and serum aldosterone levels would be the most likely testing
to reveal the etiology of her hypertension. Among children with an elevated clinic blood pressure, 24-
hour ambulatory blood pressure monitoring is most useful when evaluating for white coat
hypertension and for individuals with persistent hypertension despite escalating doses of
antihypertensive medications; however, nothing from her history is suggestive of these possibilities.
Echocardiography would be helpful in determining if she has left ventricular hypertrophy but will not
help diagnose the underlying cause for hypertension. If she had a cardiac cause of her hypertension,
it would likely have been evident from history or physical examination. Polysomnography is helpful in
evaluating for obstructive sleep apnea, which can cause resistant hypertension; however, she does
not have any risk factors (obesity), physical examination findings (adenotonsillar hypertrophy), or
history (snoring, daytime somnolence) suggestive of obstructive sleep apnea.
PREP Pearls
 All children with confirmed hypertension should be evaluated for a secondary cause of hypertension.
 Initial evaluation of hypertension should include a detailed history (including medical, family, and birth history),
physical examination, laboratory testing (electrolytes, blood urea nitrogen, creatinine, urinalysis, fasting
glucose, fasting lipids), and imaging (renal and bladder ultrasonography, echocardiography).

American Board of Pediatrics Content Specification(s)
 Know the differential diagnosis of sustained hypertension

2013; 34(13):951-961. doi: http://dx.doi.org/10.1093/eurheartj/ehs455
 National High Blood Pressure Education Program Working Group on High Blood Pressure in Children and
Adolescents. The fourth report on the diagnosis, evaluation, and treatment of high blood pressure in children
and adolescents. Pediatrics. 2004;114(suppl 2):555-576.

You were consulted in the neonatal intensive care unit for evaluation of a 2-day-old male neonate
born at 38 weeks’ gestation. Moderate prenatal unilateral hydronephrosis was noted at 28 weeks, but
the rest of the pregnancy was uncomplicated. On day 2 after birth, the patient had renal
ultrasonography that demonstrated moderate hydroureteronephrosis of the left kidney, which
measured at the 50th percentile for length. The right kidney was normal in size and echotexture with
no hydronephrosis. A voiding cystourethrogram was performed, and the results were considered
normal.
You see the patient in clinic at 2 months of age, and renal ultrasonography demonstrates persistent
moderate hydroureteronephrosis of the left kidney. The patient has been growing and developing
well. Laboratory test results are normal with a serum creatinine level of 0.2 mg/dL (15 µmol/L). The
patient had a urinary tract infection last week and is currently receiving antibiotics.
Which of the following is the BEST imaging radiopharmaceutical to establish the diagnosis in this
patient?
options: 99mTc-coupled radiotracer that is cleared by tubular secretion
99mTc-coupled radiotracer that is filtered and excreted in the urine (40%) and fixated in tubular cells (60%)
99mTc-coupled radiotracer that is filtered by glomeruli and excreted
99mTc-coupled radiotracer that is injected intravesically
explanation:
A. 99mTc-coupled radiotracer that is cleared by tubular secretion
Hydronephrosis is the most common prenatal ultrasound finding, and its detection has increased in
recent years with advanced ultrasonography equipment and techniques. The majority (50%-70%) of
prenatal hydronephrosis is transient and most likely physiologic. When hydronephrosis persists or
urinary tract infection occurs, follow-up studies are needed to exclude the possibility of a congenital
anomaly. Specifically, vesicoureteral reflux (VUR) and obstruction must be considered as potential
etiologies. A voiding cystourethrogram can assess bladder morphology and urethral abnormalities
such as posterior urethral valves.
To assess obstructions at the ureterovesical or ureteropelvic junctions, MAG3
(mercaptoacetyltriglycine) diuretic renography is the test of choice. The procedure involves
radiotracer injection into a peripheral intravenous site. A urinary catheter is recommended to eliminate
any intravesicular pressure that may prevent upper tract drainage. Unlike a DMSA
(dimercaptosuccinic acid) scan, which requires circulation and parenchymal uptake for a period of
time, MAG3 images are recorded immediately. Usually, 20 minutes after injection, a dose of
furosemide is given and drainage is further recorded. Time-course drainage curves and image
examination can determine split function of kidneys as well as laterality of obstructions. Because of
tubular immaturity, this test is more likely to be accurate after 6 to 8 weeks of age.
In the patient in this vignette, a voiding cystourethrogram excluded VUR and urethral anomalies such
as posterior urethral valves. A 99mTc-coupled radiotracer is filtered by glomeruli and excreted during
DTPA (diethylene triamine pentaacetic acid) scintigraphy, which would be useful in determining
glomerular filtration rate and can provide drainage information. Compared to a MAG3 scan, this test is
inferior in providing drainage information because of a lower target to background ratio leading to
poorer image quality, especially in the setting of obstruction. Because this child does not have an
abnormal serum creatinine level, assessment of glomerular filtration rate is not indicated. A 99mTc-
coupled radiotracer is injected intravesically in radionuclide cystography. This test is a nuclear
medicine study used to assess for VUR, but with less radiation than a typical voiding
cystourethrogram and increased sensitivity. The likelihood of high-grade VUR leading to
hydronephrosis is low because the initial voiding cystourethrogram had negative results; therefore,
radionuclide cystography is of low yield. A 99mTc-coupled radiotracer is filtered and excreted in the
urine (40%) and fix in tubular cells (60%) during DMSA scintigraphy. A DMSA scan can be helpful in
assessing parenchymal defects that would be seen in VUR nephropathy but is not particularly helpful
in assessing obstruction. The best study to determine drainage of the urinary tract is MAG3 diuretic
renography, which will demonstrate delayed drainage in an obstructed system. A 99mTc-coupled
radiotracer cleared by tubular secretion is used in MAG3 renography. Radionuclides and their uses
are summarized in the Table.

Table. Types of Radionuclide Agents and Uses.
Agent Administration Mechanism of Excretion Clinical Information Gained
Route
MAG3 Peripheral IV line Tubular secretion Drainage and split renal
function
DTPA Peripheral IV line 100% filtered and excreted Glomerular filtration rate and
drainage
DMSA Peripheral IV line 40% filtered and excreted with Parenchymal defects
60% fixated to tubular epithelia (pyelonephritis and/or scar)
Radionuclide Intravesicular Micturation Presence and grade of
cystography vesicoureteral reflux
Abbreviations: DMSA, dimercaptosuccinic acid; DTPA, diethylene triamine pentaacetic acid; IV,
intravenous; MAG3, mercaptoacetyltriglycine.
Courtesy of D. Hains
PREP Pearls
 The test of choice for urinary tract obstruction is 99mTc MAG3 (mercaptoacetyltriglycine) diuretic renography,
which utilizes a radiotracer that is excreted via tubular secretion.
 Radionuclide imaging can assess glomerular filtration rate, excretion, and parenchymal defects depending on
the agent used.
American Board of Pediatrics Content Specification(s)
 Know how to establish a diagnosis of urinary tract obstruction
Suggested Readings

eds. Clinical Pediatric Nephrology. 2nd ed. London, United Kingdom: Informa Healthcare; 2007:111-128.
 Traubici J, Lim R. Imaging the pediatric urinary tract. In: Geary D, Schaefer F, eds. Comprehensive Pediatric
Nephrology. Philadelphia, PA: Mosby Elsevier; 2008:1-38.
 Yamaçake KG, Nguyen HT. Current management of antenatal hydronephrosis. Pediatr
Nephrol. 2013;28(2):237-243. doi: http://dx.doi.org/10.1007/s00467-012-2240-7

A 15-year-old adolescent girl is being evaluated for pallor, fatigue, and secondary amenorrhea. She is
otherwise healthy and without known chronic illness. She has healthy dietary and fluid intake habits.
She estimates drinking 2 to 3 L/d and also wakes up at night to drink a glass of water and to urinate.
As an infant she was diagnosed with oculomotor apraxia, which has since resolved. Her blood
pressure is normal, and her height and weight have been tracking at the 10th percentile. Her physical
examination results are otherwise normal. Diagnostic testing reveals:
Laboratory test Result
Hemoglobin 7 g/dL (70 g/L)
Mean corpuscular volume 85 µm3 (85 fL)
Electrolyte levels Normal
Blood urea nitrogen 58 mg/dL (20.7 mmol/L)
Creatinine 3.6 mg/dL (318 µmol/L)
Calcium 8.5 mg/dL (2.1 mmol/L)
Phosphorus 5.8 mg/dL (1.87 mmol/L)
Parathyroid hormone 318 pg/mL (318 ng/L)
Of the following, the test that would BEST identify her underlying diagnosis is
options: analysis of NPHP1
iron and total iron-binding capacity
renal ultrasonography
urinalysis with microscopy
explanation:
A. analysis of NPHP1
The adolescent girl in this vignette most likely has nephronophthisis, an autosomal recessive disorder
with progressive chronic tubulointerstitial fibrosis and medullary cysts. Classic renal manifestations of
nephronophthisis include progressive chronic kidney disease, impaired urinary concentration function
presenting as polydipsia and polyuria (in particular, nocturnal polyuria), relative short stature, and
marked anemia from erythropoietin deficiency disproportionate to the degree of renal insufficiency.
The renal insufficiency relates to the marked tubulointerstitial fibrosis.
Nephronophthisis may also be associated with nonrenal clinical features (Table) that are sometimes
correlated with the specific genotypes.
Table. Nonrenal Clinical Features and Syndromes Associated With Nephronophthisis.
Nonrenal Features Associated With Nephronophthisis Associated Syndromes
Retinitis pigmentosa Senior-Loken syndrome
Hepatobiliary disease, liver fibrosis Senior-Boichis syndrome
Oculomotor apraxia Cogan syndrome
Cerebellar vermis hypoplasia Joubert syndrome
Neural tube defects Meckel-Gruber syndrome
Shortening of bones, limb deformity Saldino-Mainzer syndrome, short-rib
polydactyly syndrome, Jeune syndrome
Obesity Bardet-Biedl syndrome
Intellectual disability Joubert syndrome, Bardet-Biedl syndrome
Courtesy of A. Weinstein
Depending on the combination of nonrenal features, the condition may be part of a multisystem
syndrome, such as Joubert syndrome (nephronophthisis, cerebellar vermis hypoplasia, and
brainstem anomalies) or Senior-Loken syndrome. Senior-Loken syndrome is a more common
nephronophthisis syndrome that presents with classic renal features together with impaired night
vision (from retinitis pigmentosa) often in the school-aged to adolescent years. Infantile oculomotor
apraxia (difficulty in controlled eye movement) may be another nonrenal clinical presentation of
nephronophthisis, as seen in the adolescent girl in this vignette.
NPHP1 mutations are the most common genetic etiology of nephronophthisis and are seen in almost
half of cases presenting in the school-aged or adolescent years. Of the answer choices
listed, NPHP1 mutation analysis is the most likely test to be diagnostic. NPHP1 encodes the protein
nephrocystin-1. However, genetic testing is not required for clinical diagnosis and may not always be
definitive. Infantile presentations may be associated with NPHP2, NPHP3, and NPHP9 mutations,
although NPHP2 mutations exclusively cause an infantile presentation. An increasing number of
genes are being identified as genetic etiologies of nephronophthisis, yet many cases remain
genetically unexplained. Nearly all the genes identified are directly or indirectly related to nonmotile
cilia function. Therefore, nephronophthisis is generally classified as a “ciliopathy.”
The anemia of the adolescent girl in this vignette, in particular with a normal mean corpuscular
volume, is most likely secondary to erythropoietin deficiency rather than iron deficiency. Results of
urinalysis and microscopy in nephronophthisis are most often bland and unrevealing. Although
urinalysis may be helpful in excluding alternative diagnoses, the results are unlikely to be diagnostic
in this case. Renal ultrasonography may reveal smaller than normal, hyperechoic kidneys. Medullary
cysts are sometimes but not always seen. Such findings might be suggestive of nephronophthisis but
would not be diagnostic.

PREP Pearls
 Renal manifestations of nephronophthisis include progressive chronic kidney disease in childhood, urinary
concentrating impairment, short stature, and marked anemia.
 Nephronophthisis may be associated with extrarenal manifestations including retinal, oculomotor, central
nervous system, skeletal, and hepatobiliary conditions.
American Board of Pediatrics Content Specification(s)
 Know the renal and nonrenal features of nephronophthisis including infantile and syndromic forms
Suggested Readings
 Arts HH, Knoers NVAM. Current insights into renal ciliopathies: what can genetics teach us? Pediatr Nephrol.
2013;28(6):863-874. doi: http://dx.doi.org/10.1007/s00467-012-2259-9
 Turagam MK, Velagapudi P, Holley JL. Senior-Loken and other renal-retinal syndromes: a case report and
review.Int J Nephrol Urol. 2009;1(2):143-152.

stem:
You are seeing a 2-day-old neonate with a prenatal diagnosis of congenital anomalies of the kidney
and urinary tract. There are no other associated congenital abnormalities. A pediatric resident asks
you about the molecular toolbox that is available to the clinician to determine an accurate etiology of
congenital anomalies of the kidney and urinary tract in this patient.
Of the following, the molecular test that is MOST likely to yield a specific cause for the anomalies in
this neonate is
options: array comparative genome hybridization
mass spectrometry of the urinary proteome
next-generation whole exome sequencing
urinary and blood metabolomics profile
explanation:
C. next-generation whole exome sequencing
In the current era of precision medicine, the most likely molecular test to yield a specific etiology in a
child with congenital anomalies of the kidney and urinary tract (CAKUT) is whole exome or genome
sequencing. Array comparative genome hybridization, mass spectrometry of the urinary proteome,
and urinary and blood metabolomics profiles can be helpful in identifying defective biochemical
pathways but are unlikely to identify the specific defect causing CAKUT.
Initial studies of CAKUT (and other renal disease such as IgA nephropathy and idiopathic
membranous nephropathy) relied on genome-wide association studies. For example, a large family
pedigree showed that a chromosomal region statistically co-segregates with CAKUT, leading to the
identification of a disease locus (usually stretching over 1 or more megabases). Direct DNA
sequencing of suspected target genes can identify the co-segregating mutation. But, the proof that
this mutation is harmful relies on additional family members with the same genotype/phenotype
correlation as well as demonstration of pathogenicity in animal or cell model systems.
Changes in DNA copy number (copy number variations), which are caused by duplication or loss of
genetic material and usually encompass multiple genes, can be detected by array comparative
genomic hybridization. This technique is used in clinical practice, especially in prenatal care and for
the diagnosis of developmental defects. Copy number variations are found in a significant number of
developmental disorders, ranging from random isolated organ dysgenesis to multi–organ system
syndromes. Copy number variations are defined as gain or loss of at least 1 kb of DNA (up to several
megabases). An example of a disorder discovered by array comparative genomic hybridization is the
child with CAKUT and severe developmental delay who has subtelomeric deletion of chromosome 9
containing the gene encoding human histone lysine methyltransferase 1 (mutated in Kleefstra
syndrome). A multicenter study identified a copy number variation of 250 kb or greater in 17% of
patients with CAKUT. Interestingly, known copy-number genetic syndromes are frequently
accompanied by an abnormal urinary tract (eg, DiGeorge syndrome, Wolf-Hirschhorn syndrome).
However, with the continuous decrease in costs of next-generation whole genome or exome
sequencing, it is likely that these technologies will enhance the ability to detect rare genetic variants.
In addition to analysis of DNA sequence and structural variants, metabolic, genetic, and acquired
disorders can be classified based on their proteomic profiles determined by 2-dimensional gel
electrophoresis and mass spectrometry. However, these techniques are labor intensive, and a
peptide mass fingerprint is lacking for most common disorders. On the other hand, tests of urinary
biomarkers, such as KIM-1 (kidney injury molecule 1) and NGAL (neutrophil gelatinase-associated
lipocalin), are available and can guide diagnosis and treatment options for acute and chronic kidney
injury as well as aid in renal research.
PREP Pearls
 In the current genomic era, several molecular tools are available to the clinician. Perhaps the most useful
application involves the widespread use of array comparative genome hybridization.
 The decreasing costs and turn-around time for next-generation whole exome or genome sequencing will likely
make these techniques the tests of choice for the diagnosis of both rare and common disorders.
 Urinary biomarkers have the potential to illuminate diagnosis, management, and prognosis in acute and
chronic renal disease.
American Board of Pediatrics Content Specification(s)
 Understand the applications of genomics, proteomics and metabolomics in the field of renal research

Suggested Readings
 Decramer S, Wittke S, Mischak H, et al. Predicting the clinical outcome of congenital unilateral ureteropelvic
junction obstruction in newborn by urinary proteome analysis. Nat Med. 2006;12(4):398-400. .
 Saisawat P, Kohl S, Hilger AC, et al. Whole-exome resequencing reveals recessive mutations in TRAP1 in
individuals with CAKUT and VACTERL association. Kidney Int. 2014;85(6):1310-1317.
doi: http://dx.doi.org/10.1038/ki.2013.417
 Sebat J, Lakshmi B, Malhotra D, et al. Strong association of de novo copy number mutations with
autism. Science.2007;316(5823):445-449. doi: http://dx.doi.org/10.1126/science.1138659

Which of the following is the MOST likely gene defect in this patient?

explanation:
D. OCRL1
Lowe (oculocerebrorenal) syndrome is characterized by ophthalmic, cerebral, and renal defects.
Lowe syndrome is rare, with an estimated disease prevalence of 1:500,000. The manifestations of
Lowe syndrome vary with age. Lowe syndrome is caused by mutations in OCRL1. OCRL1 is located
on the X chromosome, and Lowe syndrome has an X-linked recessive mode of inheritance. The
OCRL-1 protein is an inositol polyphosphate 5-phosphatase.
The classic renal manifestations of Lowe syndrome are low molecular weight proteinuria and
albuminuria. Low molecular weight proteinuria can be defined by assessing retinol-binding protein or
α1- or β2-microglobulin. Albumin excretion is often in the nephrotic range (>1 g/m2/d) but serum
albumin levels remain normal. The albuminuria is thought to result from impaired megalin-mediated
endocytosis of filtered albumin in the proximal tubule. Hypercalciuria and nephrocalcinosis are
present in two-thirds of patients. About one-third of patients have renal tubular acidosis. Renal
manifestations generally appear in the first weeks or months after birth. More than 70% of patients
with Lowe syndrome develop progressive renal failure that requires dialysis. Secondary focal
glomerulosclerotic lesions may be seen on biopsy. The most common ophthalmic presentation is
congenital bilateral cataracts. Intellectual disability is the most common central nervous system
manifestation. However, Lowe syndrome affects multiple organs and has many manifestations
(Table).

Lowe: an update. Pediatr Nephrol. 2016;31(12):2201-2212.
Some important clinical features differentiate Lowe syndrome from other proximal tubular defects.
First, glycosuria is rare in Lowe syndrome. Phosphaturia may be present in up to 40% of patients, but
is thought to be primarily caused by elevated parathyroid hormone. Defects in absorption of vitamin
D–binding protein, rather than in the level of vitamin D, appear to cause the rickets and osteomalacia
that are present in up to 50% of patients with Lowe syndrome.
OCRL1 has 2 splice variants, with an alternative larger splice variant of exon 18a predominantly
expressed in the brain. Over 200 gene variants are associated with Lowe syndrome, and 10% to 20%
of patients have no identifiable mutations. Two-thirds of patients with Lowe syndrome have mutations
(frameshift, nonsense, or splice site) that lead to loss of gene expression by mRNA decay or
premature truncation. The remaining one-third have complete deletions or missense mutations.

Interestingly, OCRL1 variants are also associated with Dent disease type 2. OCRL1 has 23 exons;
patients with Dent disease type 2 have frameshift or nonsense mutations in the first 7 exons or
missense mutations in exons 9 to 21. Dent disease type 2 is characterized by hypercalciuria and the
low molecular weight proteinuria that is typical of all types of Dent disease. In addition, a small
proportion of the patients have mild intellectual deficits, hypotonia, and subclinical cataracts.
However, genotype-phenotype correlations are variable as the same mutation may present in Dent
syndrome or Lowe syndrome.
The OCRL1 protein is an inositol polyphosphate 5-phosphatase that removes a phosphate from
phosphatidylinositol 4,5-bisphosphate to generate phosphatidylinositol 4-phosphate. It has several
protein domains, including actin and GTPase binding domains. OCRL1 localizes to the trans-Golgi
network and clathrin-coated endocytic structures (Figure).
Figure. Effects of OCRL1 loss of function.
Abbreviations: N, nucleus; TGN, trans-Golgi network. Courtesy of K. Reidy
In vitro studies have demonstrated that loss of OCRL1 perturbs several cellular processes, including
GTPase-regulated membrane trafficking to apical and basolateral domains and actin remodeling. In
addition, effects on cell migration, ciliogenesis, and cell division have been reported. It is not entirely
clear how these defects translate into the Lowe phenotype, but human mutations affect localization of
OCRL1 to the endosome, suggesting that its role in endocytic recycling is important. All affected cell
types (neurons, optic lens epithelium, and renal epithelial cells) are highly polarized, suggesting that
defects in polarity may also be important in the phenotype.
There are limited treatment options for renal manifestations of Lowe syndrome. The long-term
outcome is typically slow progression to end-stage kidney disease by 20 to 30 years of
age. Potassium citrate may be used in the setting of acidosis and with nephrocalcinosis. Thiazide
diuretics, while helpful for nephrocalcinosis, carry a greater risk of electrolyte disturbances in Lowe
syndrome and would need to be used with caution. Patients with hypophosphatemic rickets may
require 1-OH cholecalciferol and phosphate supplements. Dental, ophthalmologic, orthopedic, and
neurology specialists may be necessary for management of extrarenal disease. Because of bleeding
disorders, a hematologist should be consulted prior to surgical procedures. Angiotensin-converting
enzyme inhibitors may be considered to slow progression of chronic kidney disease.

The patient in this vignette exhibits the triad of congenital cataracts, cognitive impairment, and
proteinuria as well as seizures, hypercalciuria, and nephrocalcinosis, which are typical of Lowe
syndrome. Thus, mutations in OCRL1are the most likely genetic defect. Mutations in ATP6V1B1,
which encodes the B1-subunit of H+-ATPase, are also associated with hypercalciuria and
nephrocalcinosis, but would also be expected to cause significant renal tubular
acidosis. CTNS1 mutations are associated with nephropathic cystinosis, which would be expected to
present with more generalized Fanconi syndrome with more severe acidosis and glucosuria and does
not typically present with seizures or cataracts. Mutations in NKCC2 are associated with Bartter
syndrome, which can exhibit nephrocalcinosis and hypercalciuria; however, the patient in this vignette
lacks alkalosis and hypokalemia.
PREP Pearls
 Classic Lowe syndrome presents with the triad of congenital cataracts, intellectual disability, and low molecular
weight proteinuria and albuminuria.
 OCRL1 mutations are associated with both Lowe syndrome and Dent disease type 2.
 Lowe syndrome presents with selective proximal tubular defects; low molecular weight proteinuria and
albuminuria, hypercalciuria, and nephrocalcinosis are common, but persistent glucosuria is not common and
acidosis is often mild.
American Board of Pediatrics Content Specification(s)
 Know the molecular and genetic basis for Lowe syndrome
 Know clinical features of Lowe syndrome
 Know the treatment, complications and long-term outcomes of Lowe syndrome

You are seeing a 12-year-old Amish boy for evaluation of hypertension. He was found to have a
blood pressure of 150/85 mm Hg during an emergency department visit for a laceration. He was born
at term and has no relevant medical or surgical history. He has 2 older sisters with hypertension
identified during pregnancies, and his father has untreated hypertension. All of these family members
have a normal body habitus and high physical activity levels. The boy’s diet is low in salt. He has no
drug or tobacco use, no obstructive sleep apnea symptoms, and no hypertensive symptoms. His
weight and height are at the 70th percentile. His blood pressure in clinic is 140/85 mm Hg (> 99th
percentile plus 5 mm Hg on 3 separate readings), and his physical examination results are
unremarkable. Results of first-tier blood pressure studies, including ultrasonography and
echocardiography, are unremarkable. A pediatric resident asks whether this patient has a monogenic
cause of hypertension and if that influences treatment.
Of the following, the MOST appropriate response is
options: he does not have the stigmata or findings expected with a monogenic cause of hypertension, and having a monogenic cause does not influence treatment
he is at elevated risk for having hypertension susceptibility risk alleles, and mechanistic treatment with a diuretic may be indicated
monogenic causes of hypertension are common (> 20%) and are usually treated mechanistically with calcium channel blockers
monogenic hypertension susceptibility risk alleles are present in less than 5% of hypertensive Europeans and do not influence treatment
explanation:
B. he is at elevated risk for having hypertension susceptibility risk alleles, and mechanistic treatment
with a diuretic may be indicated
The patient in this vignette is Amish. The ancestors of the Amish people were a limited number of
immigrants from Switzerland in the early 18th century; thus, the founder population was small. The
Amish population is relatively closed, leading to a higher risk of recessive genetic disease. These
characteristics combined with a fairly uniform lifestyle have facilitated the discovery of hypertensive
susceptibility genes by using genome-wide association studies in a limited Amish population. The first
hypertensive susceptibility gene identified in this fashion is STK39, the serine threonine kinase 39
gene, which encodes the Ste20-related proline-alanine–rich kinase (SPAK) protein involved in sodium
channel function. This protein regulates the Na+/K+/2Cl− cotransporter 1 (NKCC1) function and
phosphorylates the thiazide-sensitive Na+/Cl− cotransporter (NCC), which is loop diuretic sensitive. In
the initial description, the risk alleles were associated with about a 10 mm Hg difference in systolic
blood pressure.
This finding has been confirmed and expanded in a Belgian study of STK39 and the upstream
regulatory protein with no lysine kinase 1 (WNK1). A homozygous susceptibility genotype (single
nucleotide polymorphism) in STK39was found in 7.3% of the hypertensive population, rendering an
almost 6-fold odds ratio of hypertension and a 10 mm Hg increase in systolic blood pressure.
Similarly, a homozygous risk allele in WNK1 was found in 5.5% of the hypertensive population,
rendering a 4-fold odds ratio of hypertension and a slightly less than 10 mm Hg increase in systolic
blood pressure.
Traditional monogenic causes of hypertension may be associated with physical signs (Table 1),
which may be related to elevated renin production (polycystic kidney disease, conditions associated
with renal or aortic stenosis, or renal masses).

As shown in Table 2, the correct diagnosis can lead to mechanistic treatment with often just 1 or 2

PREP Pearls
 Initial examination of a hypertensive patient should include assessment of clinical/laboratory findings
associated with monogenic causes of hypertension.
 Identification of monogenic secondary hypertension may facilitate rational choice of therapy.
