A urologist has opened a practice in a hospital several hours from your pediatric referral center and
states that he is very comfortable treating pediatric urolithiasis patients with extracorporeal shock
wave lithotripsy. He asks that you consider referring your patients to him, because of the convenience
to families in being managed locally when acutely “passing stones” as well as having extracorporeal
shock wave lithotripsy performed. You have 4 adolescent patients who live in that area and have a
history of recurrent urolithiasis.
Which of the following patients, if failing medical management, would be MOST appropriate to receive
this treatment?
options: 15-year-old female adolescent with uric acid stones with a history of stones obstructing the distal right ureter
16-year-old female adolescent with a 1.5-cm calcium oxalate dihydrate stone in the right upper pole
17-year-old male adolescent with a staghorn calculus in the left renal pelvis
18-year-old male adolescent with 1-cm cystine stones in both lower poles
explanation:
B. 16-year-old female adolescent with a 1.5-cm calcium oxalate dihydrate stone in the right upper
pole
Extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy (ESWL) was first used clinically in 1980 to treat adults with
urolithiasis. Because it is less invasive, has a high safety profile, and has minimal morbidity, it is a
popular treatment alternative when medical management fails with symptomatic kidney stones. Since
its first use in children in 1986, it has also become a preferred first-line treatment in pediatric
urolithiasis. However, ESWL is not always the best treatment option for some types of urolithiasis or
under certain treatment conditions.
High-energy shock waves are generated by an electrical discharge within the lithotripter that is
directed by using radiography. When there is a change in tissue density from soft (like the kidney and
other organs) to hard (like the stone), there is a release of energy at the interface of these different
densities, in this case the stone’s surface. This energy release can cause stress waves from the
external surface of the stone, which travel internally within the stone and can be amplified by
irregularities and angles on the stone surface. The result is a compressive effect directed inwardly
that, when done repetitively and with enough intensity, causes stone fragmentation from within.
Additionally, the release of energy from shock waves may also cause the formation of bubbles, or
cavitation, on the surface of the stone. These bubbles may burst, and the pressure from the collapse
of these bubbles may erode the stone’s outer surface. Thus, these 2 processes, the internal direct
stress and the external cavitation effect, may act in concert to pulverize the stone into smaller
fragments.
The targeted width of the lithotripter, in essence the focal width of shock waves, should be just slightly
wider than the stone size for greatest efficacy. Lower frequency (60 Hz) shock wave pulses are more
effective than higher frequency (120 Hz) treatments, possibly by allowing more time for the formation
of cavitating bubbles. The initiation of treatment with lower power pulses with a gradual increase over
time is also more effective than using higher power pulses throughout the treatment.
Factors that influence the success of ESWL in adults are summarized in the Table.
Table. Patient and stone predictors of the success of extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy.
Calculus size Size is inversely proportional to the extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy results (> 2
cm has poorer results).
Calculus density High density (> 1000 Hounsfield units) calculi have worse results.
Calculus location Lower pole calculi have worse results than upper and mid-pole.
Calyceal calculi have worse outcomes than renal pelvis.
Distal ureteral calculi have worse outcomes than proximal ureter.
Skin-to-stone Distances > 9 cm negatively affect results.
distance
Renal anomalies Kidneys with congenital anomalies have lower elimination rates.
Excretory path Infundibulopelvic angle > 90°, infundibular length > 3 cm, and width < 5 mm are less
favorable anatomy with worse outcomes.
Adapted and reprinted with permission from Torricelli FCM, Danilovic A, Vicentini FC, Marchini GS, Srougi M, Mazzucchi E.
Extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy in the treatment of renal and ureteral stones. Rev Assoc Med Bras. 2015; 61(1):65-71.
Clearance rates are 66% to 99% for calculi less than 2 cm in diameter and 45% to 70% for calculi 20
to 30 mm in diameter. Therefore, the American Urological Association (AUA) guidelines for the
management of stones in adults recommend that ESWL should not be offered as first-line therapy for
stones bigger than 20 mm, although it should be considered a first-line therapy, along with
ureteroscopy, in pediatric patients with stones smaller than 20 mm.

Staghorn calculi, which branch out to fill the renal pelvis and sometimes extend into calyces, are very
large and have a high recurrence rate if not completely cleared. Percutaneous nephrolithotomy, not
ESWL, is the first-line treatment for such stones.
Denser stone material is more difficult to pulverize with ESWL. Cystine, calcium oxalate
monohydrate, and calcium phosphate (brushite) are harder crystalline materials that are less
successfully treated with ESWL. Calcium oxalate dihydrate, uric acid, and magnesium ammonium
phosphate (struvite) have softer compositions and are more amenable to shock wave treatment.
However, uric acid calculi are radiolucent and therefore may not be as easily located for directing
shock wave treatments.
Extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy may be used to treat both renal and ureteral stones, but yields
different results based on the location of the calculus. Upper and mid-pole kidney stones have very
good clearance rates, as do stones in the renal pelvis, as compared to stones within the calyx. Lower
pole stones have decreased success rates with ESWL, likely because of poorer clearance of stone
fragments. Therefore, the AUA guidelines indicate that ESWL should not be the first-line therapy for
lower pole stones that are bigger than 10 mm.
Similarly, for ureteral stones, ESWL may be considered for mid and distal ureteral stones, but
ureteroscopy has significantly better results for stones in these locations and should be the preferred
first-line therapy. A meta-analysis of studies comparing stone-free rates for distal ureteral stones
showed ureteroscopy to be effective 92% of the time with a single treatment, as compared to a 65%
success rate for ESWL. Additionally, ESWL is even less effective with ureteral stones composed of
cystine and uric acid, so it is recommended that ureteroscopy be considered specifically when these
types of ureteral calculi are suspected. Ureteroscopy does have a slightly higher complication risk
than ESWL, specifically for ureteral perforation. For women of childbearing age with mid or distal
ureteral calculi, ESWL should be used conservatively because the effects of shock waves on the
ovary have not been completely elucidated.
The indications for ESWL in pediatric patients are similar to its indications in adults. It should be
offered to patients who do not pass ureteral stones after a period of observation or are unlikely to
pass stones spontaneously because of their size. It should also be considered in patients with kidney
stones that are unlikely to pass without significant risk of obstruction or other complications,
especially in patients with a solitary functioning kidney. Acute indications for ESWL include
uncontrolled pain, persistent visible hematuria, or obstruction secondary to urolithiasis.
Contraindications to ESWL are based on higher risks of complications from urinary obstruction or
local tissue injury caused by shock waves. These contraindications include coagulopathy, abdominal
aortic or renal artery aneurysms, severe skeletal abnormalities, pregnancy, untreated urinary tract
infection, obstruction distal to the calculus (such as ureteropelvic junction narrowing or megaureter),
or a more distal stone.
A female patient with uric acid stones that previously lodged in her distal right ureter (Response
choice A) has calculi of softer composition but they may be difficult to locate because of radiolucency.
However, more importantly, this patient has issues with calculi lodging in the distal ureter, possibly
because of relative narrowing. The distal ureter is a less optimal location for ESWL, because
ureteroscopy has a much greater success rate, and ESWL has a higher risk of morbidity in female
patients of childbearing age. A male patient with a staghorn calculus in the left renal pelvis (Response
choice C) has a calculus material (struvite) that is amenable to shock wave therapy. However, the
size of staghorn calculi and the high likelihood of recurrence if not completely cleared make ESWL a
much less desirable therapy, with nephrolithotomy often recommended. A patient with 1-cm cystine
stones in both lower poles (Response choice D) has calculi composed of a denser material and

located in a more difficult position for fragment clearance, making the patient a less than ideal
candidate. Lastly, a patient with a 1.5-cm calcium oxalate dihydrate stone in the upper right pole
(Response choice B) has a calculus composed of softer material, located in a position with good
outcome, and sufficiently sized (< 20 mm) so that ESWL is likely to completely clear the stone.
PREP Pearls
 Extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy has a relatively high rate of complete stone clearance in pediatric
patients who are properly selected.
 For stones greater than 20 mm in length, extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy has a significantly lower
success rate than for stones less than 20 mm in length, especially in cases of staghorn calculi.
 Cystine and other denser stone materials are less likely to respond to extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy.
American Board of Pediatrics Content Specification(s)
 Understand the principles of extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy
 Know the indications of extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy in different types of nephrolithiasis
Suggested Readings
 Assimos D, Krambeck A, Miller NL, et al. Surgical management of stones: American Urological
Association/Endourological Society guideline. 2016. https://www.auanet.org/education/guidelines/surgical-
management-of-stones.cfm
 Torricelli FCM, Danilovic A, Vicentini FC, Marchini GS, Srougi M, Mazzucchi E. Extracorporeal shock wave
lithotripsy in the treatment of renal and ureteral stones. Rev Assoc Med Bras. 2015; 61(1):65-71.

A 9-year-old boy has a long-standing history of nighttime enuresis and nocturia. A review of systems
is remarkable for polydipsia, polyuria, and increasing tiredness. His father and many family members
on the father’s side have chronic kidney disease and gout. Physical examination reveals a normal
blood pressure, weight at the 50th percentile for age, and height at the 3rd percentile for age.
Pertinent laboratory results are shown:
Laboratory Test Result
Serum
Hemoglobin 7.1 g/dL (71 g/L)
Electrolytes Normal
Glucose Normal
Creatinine 1.2 mg/dL (106 µmol/L)
Uric acid 8.9 mg/dL (529 µmol/L)
Urine (first morning sample)
Specific gravity 1.010
Glucose, protein, blood, cellular elements, or casts Negative
Renal ultrasonography showed 2 normal sized kidneys with increased echogenicity. The patient is
diagnosed with chronic kidney disease, and genetic testing is performed.
Of the following, the MOST likely gene mutation in this patient is in
options: exon 4 of the uromodulin gene (UMOD)
the hepatocyte nuclear factor 1β gene (HNF1B)
the nephronophthisis gene (NPHP1), which encodes nephrocystin-1
the renin gene (REN), which prevents processing of pre-prorenin to prorenin
explanation:
A. exon 4 of the uromodulin gene (UMOD)
The constellation of clinical, laboratory, and imaging findings in this young patient —hyposthenuria
associated with enuresis, nocturia, polydipsia, polyuria, a bland urine sediment, normal blood
pressure, anemia disproportional to the degree of reduced glomerular filtration rate, growth failure,
and increased echogenicity on renal ultrasonography —is characteristic of a group of inherited
interstitial kidney diseases (IKDs) with overlapping clinical presentations.
Interstitial kidney disorders can be autosomal recessive (nephronophthisis) or autosomal dominant.
Distinguishing features of autosomal recessive IKD are extrarenal manifestations and earlier onset of
end-stage kidney disease (before age 25 years). Hyperuricemia is a distinguishing feature of
autosomal dominant IKD (ADIKD), also referred to as autosomal dominant tubulointerstitial kidney
disease. The family history in this patient is more consistent with an autosomal dominant inheritance
pattern. Other features suggestive of ADIKD in this patient are the presence of hyperuricemia and the
absence of extrarenal manifestations.
Four related groups of autosomal dominant genetic renal diseases compose ADIKD:
 Mucin-1–associated ADIKD (also known as medullary cystic kidney disease, type 1) presents
later in life (mean age, 62 years), usually with chronic kidney disease. Mucin-1–associated
ADIKD disease is not associated with hyperuricemia early in life. Approximately 40% of these
patients display 1 or more small corticomedullary cysts on renal ultrasonography; the cysts
may be unilateral or bilateral.
 Uromodulin-associated ADIKD (also known as familial juvenile hyperuricemic nephropathy or
medullary cystic kidney disease, type 2) results in end-stage kidney disease at a mean age of
32 years and is characterized by early onset hyperuricemia and hypouricosuria. Uromodulin
(Tamm-Horsfall protein) is a kidney-specific protein that is expressed in the thick ascending
limb of Henle. Most mutations in the uromodulin gene, UMOD, are clustered in exons 4 or 5
and result in an abnormal uromodulin protein that obstructs the lumen of the thick ascending
limb of Henle; this obstruction leads to tubular dilation, disruption of the basement membrane,
and interstitial fibrosis with inflammation. Corticomedullary cysts are found in uromodulin-
associated disease but at a much lower frequency than in mucin-1–associated disease.
 Renin-associated ADIKD is a very rare disorder that has only been identified in a few families
worldwide. Renin-associated ADIKD is caused by a mutation that prevents processing of the
signal peptide in the pre-prorenin protein, resulting in accumulation of immature renin in the
cell cytoplasm, which leads to apoptosis and tubular loss. Renin-associated ADIKD usually
presents in early life with salt-losing nephropathy, hyperkalemia, and hyperuricemia.
 Hepatocyte nuclear factor 1β–associated ADIKD (glomerulocystic kidney disease) is relatively
common, presents early in life, and is associated with cortical renal cysts. It can be
distinguished from other forms of ADIKD by the presence of diabetes mellitus (previously
called maturity-onset diabetes of the young [MODY] with renal cysts or MODY-5).
For the patient in this vignette, a mutation in the renin gene (REN) is unlikely given the absence of
salt wasting and hyperkalemia and the relatively late-onset presentation, despite the presence of
hyperuricemia. A mutation in the hepatocyte nuclear factor 1β gene (HNF1B) is also less likely given
the absence of cortical renal cysts and diabetes. Nephronophthisis (an autosomal recessive disease)

caused by a mutation in NPHP1, which encodes nephrocystin-1, is unlikely because of the autosomal
dominant pattern of inheritance and hyperuricemia.
PREP Pearls
 A child exhibiting urinary concentrating defect, anemia, chronic kidney disease, and growth failure should be
suspected of having an inherited interstitial kidney disease.
 Autosomal dominant inheritance, the absence of extrarenal manifestations, and the presence of hyperuricemia
favor a diagnosis of autosomal dominant interstitial kidney disease rather than autosomal recessive interstitial
kidney disease (nephronophthisis).
 Hyperuricemia in a patient with clinical autosomal dominant interstitial kidney disease suggests uromodulin-
associated disease (medullary cystic kidney disease, type 2).
 The absence of corticomedullary renal cysts does not exclude the diagnosis of interstitial kidney disease.
American Board of Pediatrics Content Specification(s)
 Recognize related disorders such as familial juvenile hyperuricemic nephropathy and glomerular cystic disease
Suggested Readings

classi?cation, and management–a KDIGO consensus report. Kidney Int. 2015;88(4):676-683.
DOI: http://dx.doi.org/10.1038/ki.2015.28
 Ekici AB, Hackenbeck T, Morinière V, et al. Renal ?brosis is the common feature of autosomal dominant
tubulointerstitial kidney diseases caused by mutations in mucin 1 or uromodulin. Kidney Int. 2014;86(3):589-
599. DOI: http://doi.org/10.1038/ki.2014.72

A 10-month-old male infant with a history of kidney disease is vacationing with his parents and is
brought to a local emergency department for an episode of fever and fatigue. The parents are unable
to explain the exact diagnosis but report that the infant has worsening polyuria and is taking sodium
and potassium supplements and ibuprofen 2 mL (40 mg) twice daily. The infant weighs 7 kg and is
just below the fifth percentile for both length and weight. His heart rate is 112 beats/min, and his
blood pressure is 80/50 mm Hg. Physical examination reveals acute otitis media. Laboratory data are
shown:
Laboratory Test Result
Serum
Sodium 151 mEq/L (151 mmol/L)
Potassium 3.3 mEq/L (3.3 mmol/L)
Bicarbonate 31 mEq/L (31 mmol/L)
Creatinine 0.3 mg/dL (27 µmol/L)
Osmolality 309 mOsm/kg (309 mmol/kg)
Urine
Osmolality 240 mOsm/kg (240 mmol/kg)
The urine calcium-creatinine ratio is 1.4 mg/mg.
In addition to treating the otitis media, the next steps in the management of this patient might include
options: starting an angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor
starting desmopressin
starting thiazide diuretic
increasing ibuprofen dose
explanation:
D. increasing ibuprofen dose
This vignette describes an infant who has Bartter syndrome. Bartter syndrome encompases a related
group of disorders that involve impaired sodium chloride reabsorption in the thick ascending limb of
the loop of Henle. Patients have downstream compensations, including overproduction of renal
prostaglandin E2 and activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system, that result in secondary
hypokalemia and metabolic alkalosis. Inhibitors of prostaglandin synthesis (nonsteroidal anti-
inflammatory drugs), such as ibuprofen or indomethacin, are effective treatments for Bartter
syndrome. Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs reduce glomerular filtration rate and natriuresis and
consequently reduce polyuria and electrolyte wasting. These reductions will decrease the stimulation
of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system and also improve the associated hypokalemia and
metabolic alkalosis. Because the patient in this vignette has worsening polyuria and failure to thrive,
increasing his ibuprofen dose would be an appropriate treatment option.
Patients with Bartter syndrome typically pass isotonic urine, reflecting the loss of function of the loop
of Henle’s concentrating mechanism. Patients with type 1 Bartter syndrome may develop hypotonic
urine when the distal convoluted tubule is stimulated to reabsorb sodium in the absence of water.
Therefore, secondary nephrogenic diabetes insipidus is a relatively well-understood complication
associated with Bartter syndrome, but it does not respond to desmopressin. Further evaluation to
assess the response to desmopressin would not be necessary, nor would genetic testing for
vasopressin 2 receptor mutations. Thiazide diuretics, a well-studied therapy for primary nephrogenic
diabetes insipidus, and also a potential therapeutic option for hypercalciuria, would inhibit an
important compensatory mechanism that prevents worsening hypovolemia in Bartter syndrome. They
are typically not well tolerated in patients with Bartter syndrome and should be avoided. Angiotensin-
converting enzyme inhibitor therapy is sometimes used to decrease potassium excretion and improve
hypokalemia in Bartter syndrome. However, this treatment does not improve polyuria and may
worsen hypovolemia, posing a risk for hypotension. In this patient with near normal potassium levels,
maximizing other therapeutic options such as prostaglandin inhibition would be preferred.
Over the past few decades, the molecular genetics of Bartter syndrome have been clarified, allowing
for a markedly enhanced understanding of sodium chloride reabsorption at the thick ascending limb
of the loop of Henle. This transcellular sodium chloride reabsorption requires a number of
transporters, channels, and proteins that include:
 NKCC2 (furosemide-sensitive sodium-potassium-chloride cotransporter 2), a cotransporter that
permits movement of sodium, potassium, and chloride from the tubular lumen into the tubular
cell and is defective in type 1 Bartter syndrome
 ROMK (renal outer medullary potassium channel), an apical potassium channel that recycles
potassium back into the tubular lumen, maintaining adequate luminal levels for NKCC2 to
move potassium intracellularly; defective in type 2 Bartter syndrome
 CLCNKB (chloride channel Kb), a basolateral chloride channel that moves chloride
extracellularly, providing a favorable chloride gradient for NKCC2; defective in type 3 Bartter
syndrome
 Barttin, a subunit necessary for the function of CLCNKB; defective in type 4 Bartter syndrome
The molecular effects of the genetic defects associated with Bartter syndrome are shown in
the Figure.

Additional figure from previous prep.Courtesy of Kim REidy.: Genetic Defects Associated With Bartter
Syndrome
Courtesy of K. Reidy
Each type of Bartter syndrome is treated similarly with sodium and potassium supplementation and
nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs as the mainstay of therapy. However, there may be subtle
differences in the clinical presentations of the different types (Table).
Table. Characteristics of Bartter Syndrome.
Type (Defect) Age at Nephrocalcinosis Urinary Serum Sensorineural
Diagnosis Leading to Concentrating Magnesium Hearing Loss
Progressive Impairment Level
CKD
1 (NKCC2) Neonatal ++ ++ Normal -
2 (ROMK) Neonatal ++ ++ Normal -
3 (CLCNKB) School age +/- - Often low -
4 (Barttin) Neonatal + + Often low +
5 (CaSRa ) Toddler or +++ (often with ++ Normal -
school age hypocalcemia)
Abbreviations: CaSR, calcium-sensing receptor; CKD, chronic kidney disease; CLCNKB, chloride channel
Kb; NKCC2, sodium-potassium-chloride cotransporter 2; ROMK, renal outer medullary potassium channel.
aType 5 is caused by gain of function, activating mutations in CaSR.
Courtesy of A. Weinstein
Bartter syndrome type 1, caused by the loss of function of NKCC2, typically presents in the neonatal
period with marked, often life-threatening, polyuria and urinary sodium chloride wasting.
Polyhydramnios and premature delivery are common. As compensatory mechanisms in proximal and
distal segments of the nephron mature, the polyuria becomes less severe, but hypokalemic metabolic
alkalosis, hypercalciuria, and nephrocalcinosis predominate. Hypercalciuria and nephrocalcinosis are
important prognostic factors that are challenging to treat because thiazide diuretics are not well

tolerated. As nephrocalcinosis develops and progresses, Bartter syndrome patients will be at risk for
chronic kidney disease and progressive loss of renal function.
Bartter syndrome types 2 and 4 also typically present in the neonatal period. Type 3 often presents
later during the school-aged years because its severity is mitigated by a chloride channel, CLCNKA,
that is expressed at lower levels in the basolateral membrane of the thick ascending limb of the loop
of Henle. Patients with type 2 Bartter syndrome in the neonatal period may have less significant
hypokalemia, and some may have hyperkalemia because this type of Bartter syndrome is caused by
mutation of a potassium channel that has important potassium excretion function in more distal
nephron segments. Patients with type 4 Bartter syndrome can develop sensorineural deafness
because barttin is a necessary subunit for chloride channels in the inner ear as well.
More recently, pediatric nephrologists and molecular geneticists have identified type 5 Bartter
syndrome, which is caused by a gain of function mutation in the calcium-sensing receptor. When
activated, the calcium-sensing receptor inhibits the ROMK channel in the thick ascending limb of the
loop of Henle. This interaction is physiologically intuitive because it inhibits the electrochemical
gradient that stimulates paracellular calcium reabsorption. Therefore, such activating mutations may
create a similar clinical presentation to type 2 Bartter syndrome. Type 5 Bartter syndrome is
particularly associated with hypercalciuria, nephrocalcinosis, and hypocalcemia.
PREP Pearls
 Bartter syndrome is a related group of disorders involving impaired sodium chloride reabsorption in the thick
ascending limb of the loop of Henle. Patients have downstream compensations, including overproduction of
renal prostaglandin E2 and activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system, which results in secondary
hypokalemia and metabolic alkalosis.
 Types 1 through 4 of Bartter syndrome are caused by defects in NKCC2, ROMK, CLCNKB, and barttin,
respectively. Type 5 Bartter syndrome is caused by gain of function, activating mutations of the calcium-
sensing receptor.
 Each type of Bartter syndrome is treated similarly with sodium and potassium supplementation and
nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs being the mainstay of therapy. However, there may be some subtle
differences in clinical presentation of the different types.
 Patients with type 1 Bartter syndrome may develop hypotonic urine when the distal convoluted tubule is
stimulated to reabsorb sodium in the absence of water. Therefore, secondary nephrogenic diabetes insipidus is
a relatively well-understood complication associated with Bartter syndrome.
American Board of Pediatrics Content Specification(s)
 Know the clinical and laboratory features of the various forms of Bartter syndrome
 Know the treatment and the complications of treatment for the various forms of Bartter syndrome
 Know the natural history of the various forms of Bartter syndrome
Suggested Readings
 Kleta R, Bockenhauer D. Bartter syndromes and other salt-losing tubulopathies. Nephron Physiol.
2006;104(2):73-80. DOI: http://dx.doi.org/10.1159/000094001

 Proesmans W. Threading through the mizmaze of Bartter syndrome. Pediatr Nephrol. 2006;21(7):896-902.
DOI: http://dx.doi.org/10.1007/s00467-006-0113-7
 Seyberth, H. Pathophysiology and clinical presentations of salt-losing tubulopathies. Pediatr Nephrol.
2016;31(3):407-418. DOI: http://dx.doi.org/10.1007/s00467-015-3143-1

You are called to the intensive care unit to evaluate a patient with oliguria and acute kidney injury.
The patient is a 14-year-old adolescent boy who was admitted overnight. He has a complicated
medical history of cerebral palsy and short bowel syndrome secondary to an ischemic event during
delivery. About a week ago, he was started on enteral nystatin and acyclovir for skin breakdown and
suspicious lesions around his ostomy site. Yesterday, he was brought to the emergency department
for a 3-day history of abdominal pain and excessive sleepiness. His caretaker reports that he has had
a mild increase in ostomy output over the last few days.
His laboratory tests on admission revealed birefringent needle-shaped crystals on urinalysis, a
fractional excretion of sodium of 4.2%, and the following levels:
Laboratory Test Result
Sodium 143 mEq/L (143 mmol/L)
Potassium 5.2 mEq/L (5.2 mmol/L)
Chloride 110 mEq/L (110 mmol/L)
Carbon dioxide 21 mEq/L (21 mmol/L)
Blood urea nitrogen 68 mg/dL (24 mmol/L)
Creatinine 3.1 mg/dL (274 µmol/L)
His laboratory test results 6 weeks ago revealed normal blood chemistry with a creatinine level of 0.8
mg/dL (71 µmol/L). Renal ultrasonography that was performed in the emergency department showed
normal-sized mildly echogenic kidneys.
Of the following, which characteristic is MOST consistent with the underlying etiology of acute kidney
injury in this patient?
options: echogenic kidneys on ultrasonography
fractional excretion of sodium of 4.2%
increase in serum creatinine level
urinalysis with birefringent needle-shaped crystals
explanation:
D. urinalysis with birefringent needle-shaped crystals
Acute kidney injury (AKI) is a common occurrence in critically ill patients. Nephrotoxin exposure
causes at least 25% of the episodes of AKI. Advanced age, female sex, chronic kidney disease, low
cardiac output, and decreased intravascular volume status are risk factors for AKI following
nephrotoxin exposure. The total dose and duration of nephrotoxin exposure also correlate with the
risk for AKI. Prevention and drug level monitoring are the mainstays to avoiding adverse clinical
outcomes from nephrotoxin exposure.
Nephrotoxin-induced AKI can occur by direct tubular cell toxicity, as seen with aminoglycosides and
computed tomography contrast agents, or by ischemic injury caused by alterations of the renal
autoregulatory mechanism that influence blood flow, as seen with nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory
drugs and angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors.
The patient in this vignette most likely has AKI secondary to acyclovir administration in the face of
intravascular volume depletion. Toxicity occurs when acyclovir precipitates in the distal nephron and
causes obstruction in the distal tubules. The urine may demonstrate birefringent needle-shaped
crystals. Patients may experience pain or nausea similar to nephrolithiasis-related renal colic that is
secondary to these tubular obstruction events. Usually, the toxicity is enhanced or evident in the face
of intravascular volume depletion. The AKI is usually mild but can be severe and is usually evident
within 1 or 2 days of starting therapy. Hydration to flush the tubules and decrease the increased
intratubular concentration of acyclovir is the primary treatment. Theoretically, loop diuretics can be
used to flush the distal nephron, but increased intravenous hydration is needed concurrently.
Switching to a less nephrotoxic agent such as ganciclovir should also be considered if antiviral
therapy is indicated.
Nephrotoxin-induced AKI can be distinguished from ischemic/vasomotor AKI in a number of ways.
First, prerenal azotemia, oliguria, and a low fractional excretion of sodium will precede tubular injury
in ischemic AKI. As renal blood flow decreases, prostaglandin synthesis relaxes glomerular afferent
arterioles and angiotensin II constricts efferent arterioles. If hypoperfusion persists, tubular epithelial
cells, especially in the S3 segment of the proximal tubule and thick ascending limb of the loop of
Henle, become damaged secondary to hypoxia. Tubular cells lose polarity and start to undergo
dysfunction, which leads to worsening salt/water losses that accelerate the intravascular volume
depletion. This finding is also compounded with tubular sloughing/cast formation, damage to the
endothelium, and tubular leaks leading to inflammation and generation of damaging reactive oxygen
species.

the Table.

While this patient has volume depletion, the fractional excretion of sodium of 4.2% does not support
the diagnosis of prerenal AKI. The increased serum creatinine level and echogenicity on
ultrasonography point to renal dysfunction but are nonspecific and do not offer much insight into the
etiology of AKI.
PREP Pearls
 Nephrotoxic acute kidney injury can occur from direct tubular toxicity, crystal tubular obstruction, or altered
autoregulatory mechanisms and ischemia.
 Acyclovir precipitates in the distal nephron and causes obstruction in the distal tubules.
American Board of Pediatrics Content Specification(s)
 Recognize the clinical presentation and factors predisposing to ischemic, toxic, or vasomotor kidney injury
 Understand the pathophysiology and natural history of acute ischemic, toxic, or vasomotor kidney injury

You are seeing a 2-week-old female newborn with a clinical diagnosis of Beckwith-Wiedemann
syndrome for evaluation of prenatal hydronephrosis. Left hydronephrosis was detected at 25 weeks
of gestation. The pregnancy was otherwise unremarkable. She was born at 3,800 g and 53 cm (both
> 95th percentile). She remained in the hospital for 4 days because of hypoglycemia. Physical
examination reveals a large tongue, right periauricular pit, and umbilical hernia. Renal
ultrasonography reveals kidneys at 4 cm bilaterally without hydronephrosis. The mother asks about
the role of genetic testing and renal involvement.
Of the following, the MOST accurate statement is
options: depending on genotype, some patients will require yearly magnetic resonance imaging screening until 8 years of age
genetic testing can confirm the diagnosis, and renal imaging is recommended yearly
genetic testing can help predict risk of malignancy, and renal imaging is recommended every 3 months until 8 years of age
renal complications are limited to hyperplasia and malignancy, which can be predicted by genotype
explanation:
C. genetic testing can help predict risk of malignancy, and renal imaging is recommended every 3
months until 8 years of age
Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome is an overgrowth syndrome with a multitude of manifestations (Table
1). Patients with one or more criteria should be suspected of having the syndrome. Renal involvement
may present early with structural abnormalities (eg, duplicated collecting system, cystic changes,
diverticula), nephromegaly, and hyperechogenicity of the cortex/medulla or present later with
nephrocalcinosis, nephrolithiasis, and medullary sponge kidney.
The most concerning complication is malignancy (overall risk, 7.5%). Virtually all Beckwith-
Wiedemann syndrome–associated malignancies occur during the first 10 years of age. The most
common malignancies are Wilms tumor (approximately 40%) and hepatoblastoma (approximately
20%). Less common malignancies include neuroblastoma, pancreatoblastoma, adrenocortical
carcinoma, rhabdomyosarcoma, and leukemia.
The risk for Wilms tumor is concentrated in the first 8 years of age, with a median age of presentation
of 24 months. Although there is no uniform international consensus on tumor surveillance,
ultrasonography screening for the detection of Wilms tumor is often recommended every 3 months
until 8 years of age. The risk of Wilms tumor development after 8 years of age is minimal.
Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome can be caused by a number of genetic and epigenetic disorders on
chromosomal region 11p15 (Table 2). Less than 15% of cases are familial, and no genetic or
epigenetic cause is found in 10% to 15% of cases. The 11p15 region harbors clusters of genes under
the control of DNA methylation and regulatory regions. One region includes imprinting center 1, which
regulates H19 (a non-protein coding gene) and IGF2(encodes insulin-like growth factor 2). Normally,
only the paternal allele is methylated, and IGF2 is only expressed from that allele (H19 is only
transcribed from maternal allele). Imprinting center 2 controls KCNQ1OT1 (a non-protein coding
gene) and CDKN1C (encodes cyclin-dependent kinase inhibitor 1C) such that imprinting center 2 is
normally methylated only on the maternal allele and CDKN1C/p57 is only expressed from that allele.
The usual problem in individuals with Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome is aberrant methylation of
these regions that is sometimes caused by paternal uniparental disomy (2 copies of the chromosomal
region are inherited from the father).
The cancer risk varies depending on the individual’s genetic characteristics. Individuals with aberrant
methylation of imprinting center 1 have the highest cancer risk (28%), as determined by data pooled
from 8 studies (almost 2,000 patients). Wilms tumor accounted for 85% of these cancers; the
remaining 15% of cancers were hepatoblastoma and other cancers. Individuals with uniparental
disomy had the second highest cancer risk (15%), and approximately 50% of these cancers were
Wilms tumor. Individuals with abnormalities in imprinting center 2 had the lowest cancer risk (2.6%);
only 7% of these cancers were Wilms tumor, 27% were hepatoblastoma, and the remainder were
other tumors. Some practitioners have advocated a personalized screening regimen based on
individual genetic profiles.
In addition to ultrasonography every 3 months, screening for hepatoblastoma by serum α-fetoprotein
measurement is recommended every 3 months until 4 years of age.
PREP Pearls
 Individuals with Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome require ultrasonography every 3 months until 8 years of age
to screen for Wilms tumor.
 Individuals with Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome can have a variety of renal lesions including nephrocalcinosis
and nephrolithiasis.

 Individuals with aberrant methylation of imprinting center 1 have the highest cancer risk.
American Board of Pediatrics Content Specification(s)
 Know the complications of Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome including malignancy and the role of monitoring
Suggested Readings
 Kalish JM, Deardorff MA. Tumor screening in Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome—To screen or not to
screen? Am J Med Genet A. 2016;170(9):2261-2264. DOI: http://dx.doi.org/10.1002/ajmg.a.37881
 Maas SM, Vansenne F, Kadouch DJ, et al. Phenotype, cancer risk, and surveillance in Beckwith-Wiedemann
syndrome depending on molecular genetic subgroups. Am J Med Genet A. 2016;170(9):2248-2260.
DOI: http://dx.doi.org/10.1002/ajmg.a.37801
 Mussa A, Di Candia S, Russo S, et al. Recommendations of the Scientific Committee of the Italian Beckwith-
Wiedemann Syndrome Association on the diagnosis, management and follow-up of the syndrome. Eur J Med
Genet. 2016;59(1):52-64. DOI: http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.ejmg.2015.11.008
 Shuman C, Beckwith JB, Weksberg R. Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome. GeneReviews.
